PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth their deep concern that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
1. (a) makes inadequate provision for a subjective judgement by parents as to what is in the best interests of their children,
(b) makes inadequate provision for parents to use their discretionary powers to act on such judgements.
2. creates the potential for conflict between parent and child (rather than the atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding mentioned as valuable in the preamble).
3. will produce closer monitoring by Government agencies of relationships between parents and children.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in the Parliament assembled, should:
1. By Act, ensure that all international treaties (excluding national security) are debated by the Parliament.
2. Take action to have the Convention amended in order to pay the highest regard to the importance of the family unit, and to the rights and responsibilities of parents.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.

Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill provides for the facilitation of the full privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. I bring this Bill before the Senate because it satisfies three objectives which were notably absent from the Commonwealth Bank's Restructuring Bill presented by the Government last year. That Bill was associated with the partial privatisation of the Bank.
Why are we calling for full privatisation at all?

The purpose of this Bill is consistent with the general aims of the coalition's privatisation policy, which is to increase competition and hence improve the quality and cost of service provision to the community while maximising the range of choices available.

In considering the degree of privatisation which is appropriate for the Commonwealth Bank, the most important threshold question which must be addressed is whether the Government should be directly involved in the provision of bank services.

Given that there is a healthy private sector banking industry, the coalition sees no role for government in the banking industry at all, except in so far as the Reserve Bank is concerned, including its supervisory and regulatory role. Full private ownership will remove the dead hand of government from the Commonwealth Bank's operations and promote greater competition and efficiency.
With the aim of facilitating full privatisation of the Bank, this Bill has three objectives designed to put the Commonwealth Bank on a more even footing with its private sector counterparts.
The first objective of this Bill is to remove the prohibition limiting private shareholding in the Commonwealth Bank to 30 per cent.

The second objective of the Bill is to make the shareholdings of the Bank subject to the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act, as is the case for all other companies.The third objective of the Bill is to make shareholdings of the Bank subject to the Banks (Shareholdings) Act, which applies to all other banks.

Through these objectives, the Bill will facilitate benefits to consumers. The additional competition will increase efficiency and enhance productivity, leading to lower prices and better services. It will provide for employee participation and a wide spread of ownership. There will be flow on benefits, with less government intervention, more effective capital markets and a lowering of debt from the proceeds of sales.

The advantages from private ownership of the Commonwealth Bank can only accrue if the Bank is fully privatised. The Government should be condemned for its half-baked partial privatisation of the Bank which had everything to do with boosting a flagging budgetary position, and nothing to do with the proper role for privatisation-to improve efficiency through increased competition. There is no logic in the option chosen by the Government. The decision is typical of a government that has lost its way.

We should be embarking on a wholesale program of privatisation of government business enterprises and micro-economic reform. Instead, the Government is dabbling at the edges with half measures designed to do no more than attempt to steer a political course through an array of groups with vested interests, including in particular sections of the trade union movement and the left wing of the Labor Party. The Government has lost the capacity to plot a firm course and stick to it.
In stark contrast, the coalition's program of privatisation will provide an important boost to Australia's productivity and commercial efficiency.
As part of that program, the proposals outlined in this Bill will lead to the full privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank, with resultant benefits to bank consumers around Australia.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill provides for a revised system to elect the Legislative Assembly for the Australian Capital Territory, to be known as the `ACT Electoral System'. The system is designed to overcome the inadequacies of the existing heavily modified D'Hondt system which arose out of Parliamentary consideration of the Government's legislative proposals in 1988.

The Government's decision to introduce a new ACT Electoral System arises out of its review of the Recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters in its 1989 Report entitled `Inquiry into the ACT Election and Electoral System'. The Joint Standing Committee's Inquiry was in large part initiated by the controversy surrounding that first election and the system used to decide it.

The Committee's principal recommendation proposes that a referendum be held in the ACT to determine the preferred electoral system to be used at future ACT elections. The Government believes that the inability of the Joint Committee to reach agreement on a preferred system is of key significance and is witness to the disparate but firmly held views which exist. Further any referendum result is unlikely to identify clear electorate support for any single system. Accordingly, the Government rejects the Committee's referendum proposal on the grounds that such a course is not likely to provide a definitive outcome, may not be accepted by the parties concerned and may merely serve to regenerate earlier debates on the merits of self-government. The cost of a referendum is a further, but secondary factor in this decision.

The new ACT Electoral System is in large measure the system which this Government sought to establish when it introduced its electoral legislation in late 1988. The heavily modified D'Hondt system used at the first election in March 1989 including the arbitrary cut off threshold and the complex vote counting procedures, combined with the large number of candidates who chose to stand-many on anti-self government platforms-resulted in an election count that extended for over two months. Quite unfairly it has been the D'Hondt system itself which has drawn the resulting wide criticism rather than the modifications to the system.

The Government's continuing view is that the problems and the criticisms surrounding that first ACT election could have been avoided had the Government's original 1986 proposal for an electoral system based on single member electorates been accepted. To have proposed that the Territory elect its representatives from single member electorates in the same manner as other mainland Australian states should not have been novel or controversial. In fact it is this system-which has been used to elect members to many people's Houses in English speaking democracies-which was not supported.

The opposition parties' objections to a system of single member electorates persist. Accordingly in 1988 and again now, the Government in its commitment to effective self-government for the Territory, has been forced to compromise. Facing the rejection of a system based on single member electorates, as used in other people's Houses, the Government has decided on an ACT Electoral System which embodies some key elements of the D'Hondt system. This system has a high reputation. It is in common use to elect people's Houses in non-English speaking Western democracies including France, the Netherlands and Finland. The D'Hondt system is one of proportional representation, through which the electoral wishes of the people are directly reflected in the composition of their government. The system is highly regarded for its ability to deliver stable government. As I have said it is not the D'Hondt system itself which has resulted in the current unwieldy election process but the amendments which were made to it in the political context of a first self-government election. This Bill largely removes those amendments. Accordingly, there will be no threshold or Droop quota, no provisional election process, and no provision for voters to express preferences for party candidates other than those within the party of their choice. Indeed it is significant that the recommendations of the ACT Legislative Assembly Select Committee on Self-Government make it clear that demodification of the D'Hondt system along the lines of that now proposed would be an improvement.

One of the major shortcomings of the existing system particularly in the context of the first ACT election is the inordinate length of time needed to decide the election count. Even given that the 1989 election involved 117 candidates, the period of nine weeks required to complete the count is unacceptable. Under the new system a staged counting process will be used with the first stage comprising a count of the votes cast for each party and independent candidate. The staged process means that a guide to the state of the parties and independents should in most circumstances be available on election night and the full count completed within two weeks.
To assist the early completion of the election count the cutoff time for the receipt of postal votes is to be set at the close of polling on election day.

The Government has previously responded to the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters Report `Inquiry into the ACT Election and Electoral System'. The Government will give effect to the commitments noted in that response, through provisions contained in this Bill. Specifically, to discourage other than serious candidates the candidate deposit is to be raised to $250. To discourage frivolous parties, all political parties other than parliamentary parties will be required to demonstrate a minimum membership of one hundred eligible ACT electors and individuals will be prevented from being the registered officer of more than one party.

The Government believes the passage of this Bill would discharge the Commonwealth's duty to the people of the ACT by providing them with an efficient and democratic electoral system. The Government believes that following the next ACT election the Assembly will be at a stage where it is able to conduct its own electoral affairs. Accordingly I am pleased to announce the intention of this Government to hand over to the territory the power to control the territory electoral system after the next election, scheduled for February 1992. I intend to bring forward legislation in the Budget sittings later this year to give effect to this commitment. Like other ACT legislation any electoral legislation of the ACT Assembly would be subject to the disallowance power of the Governor-General. No doubt those parties and independents contesting the second ACT election scheduled for 1992 will seek to declare their platform regarding the future territory electoral system.

To use the words of my predecessor in his second reading speech on the original Bill in 1988, this Parliament has a constitutional responsibility to ensure the good and stable government of this, the nation's capital. This Bill achieves this in providing for the people of the Territory a simplified, democratic and efficient ACT Electoral System. In presenting the Bill I note again the Government's intention to extend to the people of the Territory in 1992 the power to control their own electoral system.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: MARINE NAVIGATION (REGULATORY FUNCTIONS) LEVY BILL 1991MARINE NAVIGATION (REGULATORY FUNCTIONS) LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 March, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Parer had moved by way of amendment:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for its failure to reduce the costs which it has imposed through inefficiencies and inadequate reform in the Australian shipping industry, placing a competitive disadvantage on Australian exporters''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Marine Navigation (Regulatory Functions) Levy Bill 1991 and the Marine Navigation (Regulatory Functions) Levy Collection Bill 1991, and the matters mentioned last night by Senator Parer. The levy Bill gives effect to changes announced last August by the Government which provide for the recovery of maritime safety and regulatory costs through the imposition of a levy on seagoing ships. The collection Bill sets out details which will apply to the administration of the levy.

SPEECH.PARA: The maritime safety and regulatory functions were, of course, transferred to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority on 1 January this year, and the changes proposed in the legislation are ones which, as Senator Parer has mentioned, the Liberal and National parties support in line with our policy that, except where community service obligations are concerned, those who benefit from services provided by government business enterprises should contribute to the cost of those services rather than continually hitting taxpayers with the bill.

We commend the Government on its decision to make safety and regulatory functions self-funding by way of a levy. We accept as reasonable the Government's timetable to achieve full cost recovery by 1993-94. The levies are designed on a sliding scale so that larger ships pay less. This is something that the industry at either end acknowledges as quite equitable.

The legislation includes a provision which ensures that there is a ceiling of 15 per cent applied to any annual increase in the levy. Any increase over and above that limit will require this Parliament to amend the Act. By and large, the industry is happy with this safeguard on the cost increases, particularly since, through its representation on the Authority board, it has a say in determining the services and costs.

However, as Senator Kernot mentioned last night, this provision has come to the attention of the Senate through the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, which dealt with this matter at some length. Contemporaneously with the drawing of that matter to our attention, the Opposition considered the matter and foreshadowed the amendment that Senator Parer has moved. Subclause 7(2) of the Marine Navigation (Regulatory Functions) Levy Bill 1991 sets out the various rates per tonne of levy which would apply to ships were the Bill enacted. In each case an amount of levy per tonne is specified, but there is also a proviso which says, `or such other amount as is from time to time prescribed'. Such prescription, of course, must be by regulation.

The regulation making power of the Bill is contained in clause 8, which explicitly empowers the Governor-General to make regulations for the purposes of subclause 7 (2). Subclause 8 (2) limits the extent to which the various rates of levy can be increased, providing that they cannot be increased by more than 15 per cent in any 12 consecutive months. So far that seems to be a reasonable provision. However, the Bill goes on to say that the prohibition does not come into force until after 30 June 1993. This means that up until that time there is no limit on the amount by which the levy can be increased.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has consistently drawn attention to provisions which allow levies to be set in this way without any upper limit or a formula by which the upper limit can be determined. While accepting the view that such levies are often described as being simply a means of recovering costs, they may also be regarded as a form of taxation. Indeed, if the levy were to be increased from, say, 4c a tonne to, say, $4 a tonne-the example Senator Kernot referred to and the one which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee considered-the levy would then appear to be a tax rather than a levy. As such, that is a matter for Parliament to determine rather than being done by regulation.

In making its observation, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee acknowledges that regulations by which such an increase would be made would, of course, be subject to parliamentary scrutiny and ultimately disallowance. However, the regulations would not be amenable to amendment as this option is not open to either House of Parliament when considering a regulation. If it is an impost such as this, it is more properly described as a tax. In the view of the Committee, it should be subject to debate in both Houses of Parliament and amendment by either House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you circulated that amendment?
—I am not sure; Senator Parer is in charge of that.
—I haven't seen it.
—Order! I believe it has been circulated.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is simply to remove from clause 8, page 3, line 4, the words `after 30 June 1993'. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) may have some explanation which he can tell us about during the committee stage. He indicates by nodding that he has, and so we will await that. If there is a good reason, I suspect that we would not proceed with the amendment and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee would be happy. But if there is no good reason, we would want to pursue the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Generally speaking, we have no opposition to the Bill. Furthermore, the amendment indicated by Senator Kernot seems to be reasonable. I doubt that we would have any opposition to that as well. I use this occasion to talk generally about the Australian Maritime Safety Authority and all of the mishmash that has gone on with its placement and the cost of funding it, a mishmash and mismanagement that I think typifies this Government's handling of the economy and certainly this Minister's handling of anything related to waterfront and shipping reform.

I wish to read a press release from Mr Bob Brown, the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, as his portfolio then was, issued on 12 March 1990-exactly one year ago and, coincidentally, just a week or so before last year's Federal election, an election which to all intents and understandings at the time was going to be a very close election. Mr Bob Brown, as well as being the junior Minister in this area, also happens to represent a Newcastle seat. The press release states:

Work to set up the Australian Maritime Safety Authority headquarters in Newcastle is proceeding quickly, the member for Charlton and Federal Land Transport and Shipping Support Minister Bob Brown and the member for Newcastle Allan Morris said today.
Mr Brown and Morris said the selection of building in Newcastle to house AMSA's operations was imminent.
They said AMSA's headquarters would be set up for operations to begin in December this year.
Mr Brown said: ``In Canberra planning work for the move to Newcastle is proceeding quickly.
``Tenders have already been called for a Financial Management Information Package.
``This package will be purchased in time to begin staff training in October so that operations in Newcastle can get underway smoothly and efficiently at the end of the year.''
Mr Morris said: ``Advertisements have been placed in the Newcastle Herald for Marine Surveyors for AMSA.
``While the Surveyors initially worked from Canberra they are being clearly told that from early 1991 their jobs will move to Newcastle.
``From these initial specialist recruitments it can be clearly seen that AMSA will provide a wide range of job opportunities for people in the Newcastle region.
``Under the Hawke Government AMSA is coming to Newcastle and jobs will be created in the region.
The Liberal and National Parties have given no such guarantee and have in fact threatened to cancel the move to Newcastle completely.''

That was just some days before the election: an election in which the Hawke Government was in severe trouble, and an election where it was in danger of losing seats, even in what would have been thought to be some of its safest territory in and around Newcastle. I will read some excerpts from Alan Ramsey in the Sydney Morning Herald relative to the same matter. He says:

AMSA is a story about 200 jobs and $10 million annual payroll that vanished from Newcastle in 10 months. It's also about a government which reneged on its word, local outrage, Labor MPs slagging their own kind unmercifully, and a pig that escaped from a pork barrel. If you believe politicians, it's about ``Yes Minister'', too.

Late last year, after Newcastle lost out to Melbourne for the major slice of the Navy's frigate contract, Newcastle's Labor lord mayor, John McNaughton, flew to Canberra to have a whinge to Bob Hawke. With him went one of the Lower Hunter's four Federal Labor MPs Bob Brown a junior Minister. Bob Brown was Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support.

So, when John McNaughton was telling Bob Hawke that Newcastle was sick and tired of always finishing up the poor cousin whenever Government contracts were being handed out, Brown mentioned the headquarters of the new AMSA as a consolation prize. Newcastle had rated well in the site evaluation . . .

Hawke agreed. A few weeks later Cabinet endorsed the decision to locate the AMSA headquarters in Newcastle. It was announced the next day. It was not, however, announced by Willis, the senior Minister. Neither was it announced in Canberra.
Instead, Bob Brown, the junior minister, flew home to Newcastle from Canberra to make the announcement at a press conference for the local media in his Newcastle electorate office.
When Cabinet first considered AMSA last November, the cost of moving-
this is, of course, November 1989-

the relevant departmental sections from Canberra to Newcastle and establishing the new headquarters there was $7.1 million. The establishment costs of keeping it in Canberra were less than $2 million.

It does not need a genius to work out that the Labor Party was prepared to spend $5.1m to move the Authority from Canberra to Newcastle simply to save a couple of electorates for the Government, simply to prop up some Labor members in that area who looked in danger of being defeated. I know that political parties have trouble raising money for election campaigns, but $5.1m of taxpayers' money to support the Labor campaign to regain government is simply a bit much even for the Australian taxpayer. That is simply what it was-a pork barrel to the ultimate degree. Alan Ramsey says:

The difference in cost alone suggested the Government was pork-barrelling Newcastle and its Labor members, particularly with a Federal election due. So did the curious circumstances of the announcement.

So the election was held and the result is now history and a new Minister was appointed. The current Minister was brought in from the wilderness by Mr Hawke for some reason. The fact that Mr Hawke has been so wrong in his judgments right the way through his prime ministership does not give us a great deal of comfort as to why Mr Hawke was so insistent that the Minister be appointed. Alan Ramsey continues:

The new minister, Bob Collins, ran smack bang into the problem on his first day in office. At his first briefing by departmental officers he was asked to review the AMSA. His first decision the next day was no, he wouldn't. He told his department the move to Newcastle was non-negotiable.

So here is a new Minister coming into the job, right on the ball. He was not going to be pushed around by the public servants. He told them that the decision was non-negotiable; it would go to Newcastle. Of course, the result of the Minister's firm decision making is now well known: the Authority stays in Canberra-where, I might say, it always should have been-but the election was over; the job, the pork barrel, the $5.1m that could have been spent had done its work and the Government was back in power. The people of Newcastle were not delighted; they were very angry. As Alan Ramsey says:

The shrieks from the Lower Hunter have been shrill indeed. Bob Brown, still a junior minister, called the reversal ``outrageous''. Allan Morris said it was ``appalling''. The Newcastle Trades Hall called for Collins to be sacked. So did the Newcastle Council.
Allan Morris is convinced Bob Collins has been ``Yes Ministered'' by ``mutinous'' bureaucrats who ``sabotaged'' the Newcastle move to protect their Canberra lifestyle.
This is the Minister who is in charge of this Bill and in charge of waterfront reform generally. It shows how, according to those experts-Mr Morris and Mr Brown--

TALK.START.PARA: —Alan Ramsey.

—And Alan Ramsey; I will throw him in. Two of the Ministers' colleagues, the ones I was quoting, say that the Minister has been snowed by the public servants. It is interesting that as this matter went on the costs kept increasing. One can almost see Sir Humphrey there. The cost was originally $2m to leave it here; it was $7.1m to move it up to Newcastle-$5.1m to win an election using taxpayers' money is not bad; it could be done. But the public servants thought that this might well happen.

SPEECH.PARA: So the $7.1m increased by increments. All the little extras kept coming in-the cost to remove the dogs and cats from Canberra to Newcastle was thrown in. As time went on, the cost escalated to something like $14m. Sir Humphrey certainly snowed the Minister. He said, in effect, `Throw in a few more figures. Increase the cost, and we'll convince him that it is not worth going on with'. The Minister is certainly embarrassed now. Admittedly, he had only been in office for a couple of days, but they threw him the figures and completely snowed him. That is fair enough. It should have always been left here. I suppose it was good for the taxpayers that he was snowed by the public servants. But the concern is that this Minister, who is so easily snowed by Sir Humphrey and his colleagues, is now in charge of waterfront reform. That causes concern to Australians right across this nation.

The program which the Government wanted to implement with waterfront reform is moving at a snail's pace. At the end of September, the Government determined target was for 500 redundancies to have been processed. In that time, according to the Government's target, its score was a big, fat zero-none by September. Now we are halfway through it, there should have been 1,000 redundancies processed. All the Government can produce, if all the redundancies in the pipeline are realised by the end of March, is 451. That is not even enough to realise one year's target, due six months before. The Government's program, even by its own standards, is moving at half pace.

Those redundancies have occurred, but at the same time there have been another 213 recruits to the industry, and that process has been pursued with greater enthusiasm, compounding the manning problem. There might be some excuse if the targets set were too high. The target set was for a 30 per cent increase in productivity over three years, but it is nothing like the increase that we need if we are to regain our competitive edge in the marketplace. At that rate, the Government's redundancy package, a $300m package, will provide a very handsome $100,000 average payout, which will mean that for every one per cent increase in productivity on the waterfront, taxpayers and industry will pay $10m.
By contrast, the United Kingdom has obtained productivity increases of 65 per cent in one year-the same year that yielded us no productivity gains at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about New Zealand?
—Thank you, Senator Brownhill.
—Put that bit of nonsense in. Let us have all the nonsense in.
—Order! Senator Collins, I suggest you will have an opportunity to follow this speaker.

—New Zealand has achieved productivity gains up to 100 per cent, also in one year, and for a considerably more thrifty average redundancy payout of $27,000. I can understand why the Minister is so sensitive and keeps interjecting because he is embarrassed at being snowed by his public servants. Now he is embarrassed by the slow pace of reform that is not a patch on the nations that we compete with. Australia is being served up very modest gains only by a government and at a price of very generous payments to its mates. While we have been plodding along with unrealised goals of a 30 per cent improvement over three years, the rest of the world has moved ahead at a faster rate. So even if we achieve 30 per cent in that time, the rest of the world will have gone ahead at a much faster rate. In Yokohama, the same cargo is moved at a rate of 30 TEUs per hour--
—What are they?
—Twenty-foot equivalent units. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support shows an enormous ignorance. Every time I speak I have to explain to him things which I think he should know.
—Order! Senator Collins, I would ask you to discontinue the interjections. Senator Macdonald, I suggest you make your remarks through the Chair.

—Can I simply make the point that the Minister confirms his ignorance of these things when, every time someone speaks, he keeps asking them questions. He keeps asking people to explain to him terms and initials that should be well known to him. It simply exemplifies the point I am making that this job is completely beyond the Minister. This is not only my sentiment; the Minister acknowledges his own shortcomings in the question of waterfront reform by having to call on Big Daddy-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and senior Ministers-to help him get through. At least I give him credit for this: he did recognise that he was incapable of doing it by himself and so he brought in the heavies. The heavies have not helped him much either but at least they got something done for the economic statement yesterday. I might say that, for what was announced yesterday, he may as well not have bothered. But at least they had something to announce yesterday which, if the Minister had bumbled on by himself, he would not have had. So the heavies have come in to help him there.

SPEECH.PARA: I continue by reporting that the Victorian Minister for ports has given evidence to a parliamentary committee that at the end of the targeted reform process Melbourne will still perform at only 20 per cent of the rate in Singapore. The Government's policy is fatally flawed when it looks inwards to formulate its standards and its competitors are on the outside. So it is targeting itself against past performances.

The Minister will get up, no doubt, and say, `What did you do in 20 years of government? Where was your reform?' I am not going to argue with that. I will admit that successive governments have not done the right thing. Our party looks to the future and, as a nation, we should be looking to the future, not arguing about what happened before and not comparing ourselves with ourselves and saying that we are 30 per cent better than we used to be. What we have to do is say that we are 30 per cent better than our trading partners and 30 per cent better than our competitors, not 30 per cent better than we were a few years ago. That is where this policy of the Government is fatally flawed.

The standards that will determine the attractiveness of our produce in the international marketplace are those of our competitors. We have to be better than they are if we are to have the competitive edge. The Government has squibbed on this and so industry is having to move outside government to find the mainstream in order to get real benefits. This is exemplified by the Conaust Pty Ltd matter. Conaust responded to this situation by taking its case away from the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority process and into the established arbitration system. In doing so, its chief executive has described the Government as neutral at best in the reform process and, more recently, criticised the lack of purposeful government support which, in his words, left the ship floundering. By its own test the Government is failing in its waterfront reform program and unless this situation is remedied Australia will continue inevitably to languish in this recession that the Government has foisted upon us.

I might say in conclusion that these matters I have been mentioning about waterfront reform are again typified by the Cairns example. The Government is comparing its progress with what happened yesteryear. It is saying that it has reduced the numbers of employees at the Cairns waterfront from 23 to 10 and is patting itself on the back and saying, `We used to have 23 and now we have got 10'. What the Government does not say and what its target should be is that we need four or five. And what have we got? We have 10, which is double that number. That is what is wrong with Australia and that is what is wrong with our port system. This Government compares its progress with an enormously ridiculous base. It cuts the employees by half but this is still double what it should be and that is why Australia is uncompetitive on the market.

All the way through this process has been inadequate. It has been propped up by a Minister who does not understand, who cannot manage it by himself and who has been snowed continually by his public servants. One would imagine that the snowing by the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia is immense; it must think it has been given a gift, dealing with this Minister on this alleged waterfront reform process. The Minister was easily snowed by the public servants in Canberra. The wharfies could teach them a thing or two about snowing Ministers; and this Minister has just fallen for it all the way through.

I think those matters are relevant and the people of Australia should know about them. The reform process is on the wrong basis, with the wrong targets; it is moving too slowly and it has to get better for Australia. We in the Liberal and National parties certainly encourage the Government to be a bit tougher, to get on with the job, to do it properly and not just to languish around with rhetoric as it has been doing. That is my plea. We support this Bill. I encourage senators to consider the amendments proposed by the Opposition and also to look favourably at one of the more sensible amendments to come from my friends on the left.

TALK.START.PARA: —The dynamics are changing in here. This is a surprise.

—They are my friends on the left; I have a great regard for them; it is just their ultra left wing policies that disturb me. If they go long enough, occasionally they will come up with an amendment that is sensible. I guess even the--
—It comes from one of the more sensible members of the Left.
—I would agree with that.

—I take the opportunity to point out in response to Senator Parer's sensible interjection that Senator Kernot comes from Queensland. That is why it is one of the more sensible things from the ultra left wing of the Labor Party.
—It is a wonderful attribute.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I should note your wisdom by indicating that you also come from Queensland--
—And from the Left!

—And from the Left, but not as far Left as my friends in the Australian Democrats. We support the Bill; we support our amendments, of course; and we think the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats is worthy of support as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said a couple of times in Question Time recently, I have been waiting for this debate for 12 months, and it has finally arrived. We have finally had a debate in the Senate on the waterfront. And how pathetic it truly was.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macdonald is quite wrong to say that I had intended to canvass what happened in the past and the failure of the Opposition when it was in government to introduce any reform-and it did not-on the Australian waterfront for the entire 30 years it was in office. I will not do that; I will quote Senator Macdonald's words back to him: we are a party that looks to the future. That is what I was waiting to hear during this debate. There has been an enormous amount of non-stop criticism from the Opposition of the waterfront reform program of the Government over the past 12 months. That criticism started from day one and has not diminished since then.

As well as the Government being criticised during that time, single-mindedly the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia has been singled out for non-stop attention, particularly by Senator Macdonald. According to the Opposition, the companies had nothing to do with this situation, despite the fact that the senior executive of one the major companies publicly acknowledged on national television that they had. As far as the Opposition is concerned, none of the unproductive work practices entrenched in the Australian waterfront over the past 50 years had anything to do with management; those practices were entirely a matter for the union. According to the Opposition, the people currently holding up the process are the unions. That is so far from reality that it is not true.

In the middle of this non-stop criticism, I have been waiting to hear-I am not asking for anything unreasonable-just one tiny detail about how the Opposition would approach this, not in the past, but in the future. I am not the only one waiting for this; the industry is waiting as well.

We finally got it. Two weeks ago we actually had the first public statement that I have heard from a frontbencher in a relevant portfolio as to what the Opposition's policy on waterfront reform is. Ian McLachlan, the shadow Minister for industry and commerce, addressing a shipping industry conference in Sydney a fortnight ago, was asked a question in question time-not unreasonably-by an industry representative, who said, `You have been criticising the Government's waterfront reform program for a year. We also are criticising it. What the industry would like to know is what the Opposition's policy is on the waterfront. If we voted for you instead of the Labor Party what could we expect to see happen on the waterfront with the coalition in government?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read our industrial relations policy.

—I have read it, and there is nothing in there. To that question the shadow Minister replied, `I am not going to tell you because we don't want Bill Kelty to find out'. What a piece of absurd nonsense. That is the official policy of the Opposition on waterfront reform. In fact, it is the first thing the Opposition has said on the matter in a year. Ian McLachlan went on to make the following even more extraordinary statement: `There are one or two senior people in this room'-wink, wink; nudge, nudge-`who know what we will do just before--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. In regard to the words that have been quoted I would ask the Minister to quote them if he can give perfect quotes, but if he is surmising that they are quotes I do not believe that they should be given as quotes.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—For the benefit of the honourable senator who is sensitive about this, I ask someone in my office, who no doubt will be listening, to send down now to the chamber a copy of the actual report of the speech. I can assure the Senate-even though there was no point of order and Senator Brownhill knows it-that the quotes are word for word what Ian McLachlan told the conference.

SPEECH.PARA: An industry representative who was one of the 100-odd industry participants at the conference telephoned me and said, quite rightly, `Of course, not a single person in the room accepted that nonsensical explanation. We all knew perfectly well why he did not answer the question-because he does not know'. That is the real reason. The Opposition does not have a policy for waterfront reform, enunciated publicly, that the electorate can judge it on. It has only a string of cliches-that is all we heard again in the debate in the Senate-one of which has been left out: get tough, take the gloves off. That is the Opposition's policy on waterfront reform. After the gloves are taken off, members of the Opposition do not say who to hit. They also do not say what they will do when he gets up off the canvas and has a go at us. They have no policy on waterfront reform except a string of meaningless cliches.

I say again that I have waited for this debate for a year. Only two speakers for the Opposition have spoken in it-frankly, I expected a cast of thousands on this issue but we have had two-and neither of them gave one single, solitary indication of what the Opposition would do in government. Will it dismantle the industry levies? Will it introduce punitive legislation into the Parliament? Will it break the nexus between the shipping companies and stevedoring companies? There is a whole range of options.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read our industrial relations policy.

—There is nothing in there. I have done it. I am waiting to hear what the Opposition will do. In terms of the nonsense that has been delivered in this debate, both here and in the other place, some of that deserves some response. One of the other problems with the Opposition's performance on this issue is that it keeps on telling lies on the basis of the Dr Goebbels principle: if lies are told over and over again, eventually people will believe them, including no doubt the people who are uttering them but know they are nonsense in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: That happened here again and in the House of Representatives during this debate. We heard comparisons about shipping rates across the Tasman repeated. We heard some extraordinary stuff in the House of Representatives from Mr Sharp about rates on sugar imports to Australia. Prior to 1989, we were not even allowed to import sugar to Australia. The embargo on absolute imports to Australia was lifted only in 1989. I have looked at the figures given and there is no indication as to whether the prices quoted-there is a $2 or $3 a tonne difference between them-are spot rates or long term rates; no indication of the ports where the sugar was going to or coming from; in fact, nothing in any of the statements that would indicate that we could give them any serious analysis.

In fact, Mr Sharp was talking about the comparative freight rates of shipping Queensland sugar around the coast of Australia to Western Australia and importing sugar from Mexico. I am not going to stand or fall on this because I have only had 24 hours to have a look at it. But for the life of me, I cannot find the slightest evidence that we imported enough sugar from Mexico to put in a cup of tea. In fact, my information in relation to the two sources quoted by Mr Sharp is that we imported 700 tonnes of sugar from the Philippines and none at all from Mexico. The Opposition keeps repeating this pretty astonishing nonsense and I have to say that that does not surprise me.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was salt from Mexico.

—Oh no, Senator, have a look at Mr Sharp's speech. Senator Parer interjected and said, `Oh no, it was salt from Mexico'. It was indeed. Now, according to Mr Sharp's speech, it was sugar as well. I was about to say, before Senator Parer's helpful interjection, that we have not imported enough sugar from Mexico to put in a cup of tea and we have not imported enough salt from Mexico to sprinkle on a tomato. But it is perfectly okay for Senator Parer to run it in here again. We have been given all these figures about the thousands of tonnes of salt that we are importing from Mexico, and now the thousands of tonnes of sugar which, according to Mr Sharp, we are importing from Mexico. We are told how much cheaper it is. The Mexicans do not seem to know anything about it and I cannot find anybody in Australia who does either.

SPEECH.PARA: All I am saying is that there are plenty of examples around that the Opposition can use. Why does it not use the real ones? There is plenty of good material that it can use to criticise the waterfront and the shipping industry. If they did not need to be criticised, we would not be engaged in the process of reform. The fact is that we acknowledge that there are reforms and improvements needed. Why does the Opposition keep running nonsense, instead of fact? The reason is-and it annoys me-that it is not even interested in making the slightest effort to concentrate its mind on how it would actually reform the waterfront. The Australian electorate deserves better than that.

I tell the Senate-and there is 15 years of Hansards to prove it-that I am not a person who has ever believed that all of the consolidated wisdom rests on one side of the Parliament. I am open to suggestions from the Australian Democrats, from the Opposition and from my own parliamentary colleagues, which is why I initiated the formation of that working group. If somebody can think of a better way of doing it than I have been able to do, let us hear it. But we are waiting in vain for suggestions from the Opposition. We still have not heard it yet. In the great waterfront debate in the Senate, we have had two speakers from the Opposition and neither of them said anything. I am still waiting. Perhaps they will have another run at it during Question Time today or will stick the debate on again in another three weeks. But I am open to suggestions.

I know what all the hard options are. I know what the alternative options to a negotiated settlement on the waterfront are. Instead of hearing these meaningless cliches about getting tough and taking the gloves off, I would like to know, and the industry would also like to know, which one of those options-any of them or all of them-the Opposition would implement in government. We are still waiting.

In terms of the breathtaking nonsense that continues to be delivered on this matter by the shadow Minister, John Sharp-I say this again, and I am happy to demonstrate it-he has not yet put out a single public statement on shipping and waterfront reform that has not been factually wrong. The canards have been delivered again in here today and repeated by Senator Macdonald-the same nonsense.

I will quote a whopper. We were told that the Conaust agreement was negotiated in principle outside the waterfront reform process. What a piece of arrant factual nonsense. The Opposition has no excuse for continuing to run this lie because I nailed it down in Question Time earlier in this sitting. In fact, I produced the document and quoted the section from it. The Opposition has no excuse because the role that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission plays within the process is contained on page 1 of the agreement. If members of the Opposition are too lazy to read the first page of the agreement, I refer them to the transcript of the Commission in which Commissioner Sweeney laid out very clearly in the Cairns decision, and indeed in the Conaust matter-in fact, I will send it to Senator Macdonald's office-the specific role that is required of both the Commission and the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority within the process of waterfront reform.

It was always acknowledged that there could come a time, amazingly enough, when there would be issues where an umpire was needed. Of course, the appropriate place to go is the Commission, the very organisation that the Opposition has a policy of dismantling and destroying and going outside of, so that the devil will take the hindmost and we will be back to the good old days of 30 per cent leaps in wages. The Commission is absolutely part of the process. I might also add-and the Opposition has ignored it-that it was the conciliation processes of the Commission that achieved the result-not arbitration. It was done by agreement between the parties, both Conaust and the unions.

I have said this before, in terms of industrial dynamics, and I point it out to Senator Macdonald-but because of his non-stop, 100 per cent union bashing attitude he is not interested in listening to it-it is a hell of a lot easier for the company to negotiate these reforms than it is for the union. Whether you agree or disagree with the work practices-and I disagree with many of them, and think that they should be removed-the fact is that they have been in place for a very long time; in respect of the rosters and work practices, at least 20 years or more. Whether or not we disagree with them, in the case of the union it has been a process of constantly giving up conditions that it has got. It is a lot easier for the company under those circumstances.

I believe there is a very strong, long term benefit for the workers engaged in this process, and so does the union leadership. I want to take this opportunity to pay tribute publicly to the work that has been done over the last 12 months by the leadership of the Waterside Workers Federation, in particular, Tas Bull and John Coombs. Over the last 12 months I have had enormous respect and admiration for Tas Bull because, for a union official--

TALK.START.PARA: —Join the club.

—It is not a question of a club at all. It is something that Senator Parer and the Opposition refuse to acknowledge. It is a hell of a lot more difficult for the union officials to negotiate this process because on every occasion they are having to make concessions. As Tas Bull said to me, quite correctly, late last year, every time he goes into a port to negotiate-and he has done it-it costs him another 100 members who have not got jobs.
—He might be a better Minister; put him in your place!

—All I am saying is that the one thing I have refused to do in terms of advancing this process-and Senator Macdonald should have regard to it-is flatly refuse to criticise company actions on this. It has been criticised trenchantly by some people, particularly Conaust, and I have not engaged in that debate; nor have I taken this crazy position of singling out the unions for special attention. That would be a wonderful attitude to bring down to the waterside in terms of getting reform!

SPEECH.PARA: As I have pointed out before, getting the agreements is only half the battle, the real reform is delivered when those agreements are actually implemented in the workplace. That is why a negotiated process, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you will be well aware, is a far more effective way of actually getting reforms delivered than the process of provoking maximum resistance in forcing changes on people when they have the opportunity, scattered around the ports of Australia, to be as slow or as quick as they like about putting them into practice.

The coercive role that the Opposition has wanted to take from day one of taking off the gloves and getting tough-as it has said again in this debate, without specifying how to do it-would be guaranteed to produce industrial chaos in Australia and ensure that the real reform and the real results would not be produced for years.

I will tell the Senate what is the trouble with this country, and one of the problems, using a classic example from recent times. A certain organisation was making some radical changes. I was rung up by a journalist who said, `Would you like to be interviewed on this?'. I said, `Yes, I would, because the changes that are being brought in are significant for the country, for the national economy and for the national good; they involve a lot of money and some radical moves that are going to be very positive. I would be very happy to take the opportunity to be available'.

The same journalist rang me back on the same day-this is only a week ago-and said, `Look, we don't want to do that interview now'. I said, `Why not? What's the problem?'. The journalist said, `Our Sydney office contacted the unions, and the unions aren't going to put on a blue so we are not going to run the story'. That is a fact. That happened a week ago.

I point out one thing about this country that really irritates me in respect of this and, in fact, all other debates. Shipping reform achievements have been considerable. On an almost daily basis I get feedback from senior executives of the companies involved-and it happened again last night-telling me what direct and real benefits, in terms of the gypsum industry, their companies are achieving from the drastic reductions in crewing levels on their ships over the last three years, without one day lost in industrial disputation.

I will tell the Senate what the problem is. If one goes into a negotiation without a stoush, without any publicity, fuss or fanfare, but just with a bit of commitment and achieves a 40 per cent increase in production, everyone says that is a failure, it is not enough. But if one goes into it and has a brawl-a big punch up with the unions-and gets hairy chested and says, `We are going to take on the unions', one gets the same 40 per cent productivity and that is claimed as a victory. It is a bit of a problem.
Some of the angst that I get from rank and file trade unionists-these are the guys down on the docks actually doing the work--

TALK.START.PARA: —What work?

—It is obvious that Senator Parer has not been to the port of Melbourne to have a look at the work that is being done down there. There are some container terminals down there that he might like to have a look at. He did not get past 1950 in his speech yesterday, and I had a listen. He was still in the 1950s. Things have happened since then. He might like to go down and have a look because, with some justification, these guys down on the docks are saying, `Listen, why should we have any incentive or any motivation to produce an A-grade result when we are going to get bucketed whatever we do?'. There are grounds for saying that. They are saying, `We are being attacked every day'.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a piece of correspondence from a user group saying, in respect of the reductions of 80 per cent in manning in grain terminals which we achieved, that that was inadequate. I have to tell the Senate that there is a view in the union movement that even if the WWF replaced every single wharfie in Australia with a robot, it would still be attacked, and it is right, because it would be by some.

Where is the motivation for the union movement to have any real desire to implement an A-grade result and say, `Let's go for the top'? Tas Bull is doing that, but it is very frustrating from a union point of view because the rank and file is saying, `It does not matter what we deliver, the Opposition will get into us and say it is not good enough, so why should we bother delivering anything at all?'. There are some grounds for that, and in the real world one has to have regard to that.

I will finish with Mr Sharp's nonsense and what he said about the Opposition's performance in government. Senator Macdonald and Senator Parer said that that is not relevant any more, and I agree. We should be looking to the future. I am still waiting to hear the future from the Opposition. Mr Sharp talked about the past. He delivered a whopper in the House of Representatives. He referred to when the coalition government was in office in the late 1960s and early 1970s during the introduction of containerisation. He said:

A coalition government in control of the country at the time was able to negotiate and to reduce the numbers of waterside workers from 30,000-odd down to around 10,000-a cut of two-thirds in the number of waterside workers during the last years of the coalition Government prior to Whitlam coming to power.

Let us have a look at what really happened. When the coalition Government lost the 1972 election there were 14,600 waterside workers representing a reduction of 4,400 over a four-year period. This reduction had nothing whatever to do with the coalition Government. Quite the reverse. In fact, it was the heavy-handed approach of the coalition-the same one it wants to adopt now-in government in 1971 to reducing surplus labour which is still having an ongoing and damaging effect on the industry. It is all contained in the report of the Inter-State Commission (ISC).

At that time the Federal Government had direct regulatory control through the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority, or ASIA, as it was known. It was a party to the national stevedoring industry conference agreement which covered the overall employment arrangements in the industry. In other words, the government was right in there, hands on.
I quote from page 42 of the Inter-State Commission report, the report commended by the Opposition and on which our program is based:
In 1971, the Government through Asia-
that is, this mob-
attempted to remove 500 surplus workers from the industry-
not 3,000 but 500-

if necessary through the compulsory retrenchment provisions of the National Stevedoring Industry Conference Agreement. The employers again resisted (apparently fearing industrial confrontation) and instead provided in their 1972 memorandum of agreement with the union that redundancy in future years would be on a voluntary basis only. Reductions were agreed at that time with the union, after additional incentives were provided for early retirement (particularly for workers aged 60 years and over).
I quote the final sentence:
In subsequent years reductions in registrations (of waterside workers) were negotiated solely by the AEWL and the WWF.

In other words, the Government was out of it completely. Consequently, it was the coalition Government's heavy-handed interference with the industry in 1971 that helped to bring about the non-compulsory redundancy agreement which it now so aggressively criticises. The Opposition gave it to us the last time it was in Government by taking the gloves off on the waterfront. The Government did not negotiate these labour reductions, as claimed in the House by Mr Sharp. In fact, the reductions were achieved by the industry through improved redundancy incentives as outlined in the ISC report. As the report said quite clearly the Government, because of its heavy-handed attitude, was cut out of it and the redundancies were negotiated entirely through the Association of Employers of Waterfront Labour (AEWL) and the WWF. The legacy of that heavy-handed nonsense-the coalition has not learned a thing in 30 years and wants to visit it on us again now-is that we now have in place the voluntary redundancy provisions-thanks to the Opposition-and that is what it is now complaining about.

I would like to take the opportunity, before I finish, to talk about the Bill that is before the Senate. I do, of course, have to respond to the nonsense that was delivered by the Opposition during this debate, but I have to give some credit to Senator Macdonald because he at least did talk about the Bill, and I thank him for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —So did I.
—He did for five minutes. I am talking about the Opposition. I have to give some credit where credit is due. Senator Kernot did, of course, as well.
—Are you going to tell us about the Newcastle decision?

—I will have to leave that for another debate, unfortunately. I have only five minutes. I will do it in the adjournment debate. I will not be full of spirit when I deliver it either. It will be a very statesmanlike address.
—I'll bet you will.

—I would like to talk briefly about the Bill because I would like to give to Senator Macdonald something I have been able to give Senator Kernot in respect of the amendments. The Government will not be accepting either of the amendments, but I am encouraged by Senator Macdonald's comments on how firmly committed the Opposition is to the cost recovery principle and the support it is giving the Bills. He indicated that, if he can be persuaded that there is a good reason for not proceeding with these amendments, the Opposition will consider not proceeding with them, and there is good reason.

SPEECH.PARA: I have, of course, read the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's report on the legislation and can understand the recommendations it has made and can therefore understand why these amendments are before the Senate. There are a couple of matters that the Committee probably was not in a position to take account of at the time it came down with these recommendations, which indicates that it would not be useful to proceed with the amendments. I will deal with them one at a time.

On the first one, the Committee determined, quite reasonably on the face of it, that the 15 per cent cap was quite reasonable in terms of being posted from 1993 on. As Senator Macdonald has correctly said, the industry has agreed with it. Senator Parer did, too, but Senator Macdonald said this morning that the industry has agreed to it and thinks it is reasonable. I point out that it is not an economic cap. It is not suggesting for a minute it will be 15 per cent. It is a legislative cap that has been put on and the industry is satisfied that that figure is reasonable to put on as a legislative cap. The reason we oppose the amendment to remove the starting date for the cap is very simple. We were faced with the situation where the $7m-and it is not a huge amount of money-that is currently spent in this area by the Government, which the industry is now going to pay, had to be cost recovered and there needed to be a cap and a mechanism put in.

We did not want to put the industry in a difficult situation. We could have, because it is only $7m, and that is not a huge amount from the whole industry. The Government still did not want to introduce it in one hit and say, `We will collect $7m'. I might add that, if we had, we would have had no problems with the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. We could have said, `We will immediately begin to collect this at its full rate to recover the $7m'. Can I say, for the benefit of the Opposition and the Senate, that it is only proposed-and I state this quite clearly here-that the rates will be levied to collect that sum of $7m that is actually expended in providing these services. They are in fact all laid out and I am happy to enunciate them in the committee stages, if the Opposition wants me to.

The industry is well aware of where the money goes and it is not arguing with that either, but it does cost $7m to provide the services. That is all we are going to collect. I said, `No, we cannot do that. We have to phase it in over three years'. That is why there was not a cap put on. The Government has provided for a three-year phase-in and, at the end of that three years, that is the only money that will be collected. The difficulty for the Government in removing these words-and this is why we cannot accept the amendment-is that if a 15 per cent cap is put on the phase-in period, it will take eight years, not three, to move to full cost recovery. That is the problem.

I understand why the Opposition has moved the amendment because I have read the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's report and it is based entirely on the Opposition's recommendations. I am quite happy to explain to the Committee, at the first opportunity I get, why this has happened. The Government would have had no problem with the Committee if it had said, `We are going to collect $7m right now from day one and then put the 15 per cent cap on'. That would not have infringed the Committee's principles.

In respect of the second amendment, the same thing applies and that is why I have provided the Opposition with a copy of the regulations. I have pointed out to Senator Kernot that paying refunds back is not discretionary. There simply is no avenue to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), nor should there be.

What would happen if the amendment was accepted is that people would be going to the AAT saying, `I insist that I want to appeal about people giving me this cheque because I do not want it'. There is no discretion allowed to the Collector of Customs. He collects it in the first place and he knows when it has to be paid back, and the regulations quite clearly state that it must be refunded if the ship in fact is laid up or out of service or all of these other conditions. Can I say that my information is that it has never happened, so there never has been a problem with it. The problem would lie, of course, if there was an oversight or it was left out. When it was drawn to the attention of Customs, it would go to the small claims court or the magistrates court and get immediate judgment in their favour. It is not a discretionary payment. It must be paid to the shipper if the ship is out of service. The amendment, therefore, is simply not necessary.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Parer's) be agreed to.
