The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to comment briefly on the proposed amendments and the explanation by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) as to why they should not proceed. Before doing so-and I believe I have some latitude in this area-I should like to comment on some of the remarks made by the Minister in his second reading speech on the lead-up to his explanation as to why some of those amendments should not be put. The Minister indicated that at no time had he heard from the Opposition on how it would handle the problems on the waterfront that he referred to. He then proceeded to give us a litany of arguments-that all we had referred to was the past.
—I am giving you a little latitude, but you really cannot have another second reading speech. I would like you to try to tie your comments into the amendment that you propose.
—Speak to the third reading. You shouldn't do this in committee.
—Order! Senator Collins!
—I am getting lots of advice.

—On a point of order: I have no objections to Senator Parer saying what he has said, but it really is not appropriate to reply to a second reading speech during the committee stage on the clauses of the Bill. I am simply suggesting to Senator Parer that he might like to take the opportunity to deliver his rebuttal during the third reading debate.
—On the point of order, Mr Chairman: I understand that during the committee stage of the Bill one can talk on the name of the Bill, which is the Marine Navigation (Regulatory Functions) Levy Bill.
—You can but you cannot have a second reading speech. Could you try to tie your comments into the proposed amendment?

—Certainly, Mr Chairman. The proposed amendments relate to the levy increases and the percentage of increases prior to June 1993 in respect of various aids for shipping which uses Australian ports. For that reason I was reflecting on the waterfront reform which is so critical to those vessels which come into this country and which in fact will pay the levy. On that basis I would like to mention a few points. If more ships are going to use those ports and if those ships are going to pay the levy on a tonnage basis, we will need to improve the efficiency of the waterfront.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Minister did was come in and act as an apologist for probably the most militant and destructive union that this country has ever seen. It has destroyed industry within Australia, it has destroyed much of our export potential and it has increased the cost of our imports. The Minister should reflect on this, because one of the things that he did was give great praise to Mr Tas Bull. I have no objections to Mr Tas Bull representing as best he can the interests of those people who work on the waterfront. That is his job. But I would remind the Minister, if he would listen, that about a year ago I attended a luncheon where Mr Tas Bull quite categorically stated that he had been through umpteen numbers of these reforms. They had been subject to the same sort of pressure in the past as they would over this waterfront reform process and he could assure those on the waterfront that they would come out of it in much the same way as they had every other time in the past. All I can say is that, if the Minister has been sucked in by the comments of Mr Tas Bull, who is a very articulate person, he is just showing the naivety which reflects the comments made by users who tend to refer to this Minister on micro-economic reform-and I carefully choose these words; the only regret I have is that I did not say it-as the `phantom of the offerer'--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order.

—I accept your point of order before you make it, Senator Collins. Senator Parer, you have been given some latitude. I ask you to come back to the purpose for which we are in committee; that is, to look at the amendments before the chamber.

—Yes, Mr Chairman. I think I was referring to it, because I indicated that a levy was being charged and we were putting forward an amendment because of our concern about there being no ceiling on that levy until 1993, and the necessity for the waterfront reform to be gone through and done properly to enable a $7.1m figure, which was the cost of operating the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) to be paid for by the vessels visiting our ports. I indicated that one of the most important things is to increase the throughput of those ports; in other words, increase our exports and improve our current account deficit. To achieve that, we need proper waterfront reform-not phoney stuff. We need proper enterprise-based unions, not phoney enterprise-based unions. As I indicated when the Minister got up to make his point of order, he should go out and listen to the users and not just the user-friendly Tas Bull, which shows that the old bull is conquering the young bull. It shows a naivety that the reference being made to the Minister by users is the `phantom of the offerer'. I wish that I had dreamt up that term myself. It is a wonderful term. That is the view of users to micro-economic reform.
—What does it mean?

—It means that what the Minister is offering is of a phantom nature. Here we have the Minister again interjecting. He keeps interjecting on Senator Macdonald because he does not know what he is doing on the waterfront and I have to explain to him some simple English.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. This is an absurd committee stage. The honourable senator has the right to speak, and I have pointed that out to him. I am not trying to cut him off; I just want the procedures followed. He has an opportunity for delivering this kind of speech in the third reading stage of the Bill. Let us get the amendments dealt with; that is what committees are for.
—I thought that at that stage Senator Parer was--
—He's had a lot of latitude.

—I will determine how much latitude there is in this Committee, Minister. I thought that Senator Parer was getting on to the request in front of the Committee. If there were fewer interjections on my right it would certainly help the procedures of the Committee.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. The Minister is obviously concerned about his lack of progress in achieving a result that the rest of Australia is demanding. I will move on to the amendment that I have foreshadowed. However, in view of the Minister's explanation in the second reading debate in respect of the date June 1993-as I understood it, that the ceiling of 15 per cent was to apply only after that date because it enabled the levy to be progressively increased over a three-year period up to the amount of the cost of operation of AMSA- and in view of the Minister's assurances, we will not proceed with that amendment. But one of the questions that relate to it, which I did ask the Minister and which he tended to gloss over in the second reading debate is this: what was the basis of the 15 per cent in the first place?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did in fact make a reference to that question when I concluded. In response to the comment that had been made on it by Senator Macdonald, the basis of the 15 per cent is--
—Arbitrary.

—Quite right; it is a legislative cap, as it must be. It is not an economic cap. The Department simply looked at the annual rate of inflation. If I could just explain, there is a very strong mechanism for determining that these charges will be made only in line with the actual cost of delivering the services. AMSA has a board which has to set this cost. The board is obliged to have consultative mechanisms with the industry. That is one of the benefits, in my view, of doing this not just in the maritime area but also in the aviation area. Those in the industry are paying for it now; they have an absolute right-and that right is enshrined-to be consulted about the justification of the increased costs. They have simply said, `If you have an average inflation rate of 10 per cent, stick a bit on top of that so that there is some flexibility in case of a bad year so we don't have to bring it back to parliament every time there is a fluctuation--
—Do you think inflation might be 10 per cent?

—Not at all. It is simply a procedural matter. As I explained-and I am right up front about it-it does not have any economic basis. It is a reasonable legislative cap. It has been accepted as being a reasonable legislative cap by the industry. The industry has indicated that it is a reasonable figure to put in. My own view is that it is highly unlikely that after 1993 that figure would ever need to be charged.

SPEECH.PARA: The basis on which the increases will be made is purely and simply-and it has to be justified to the industry-the actual cost of delivering the services. I do not want to delay the Committee any longer, but if the honourable senators want me to I can read out the long list of areas where these charges are made. Of course, the industry has these. I say again that it is not an economic cap; it is simply a legislative cap. That is the basis of it. I have to come clean with Senator Parer. The reason I was being such a nuisance in the committee stage and was trying to get it finished was that, as he may have noticed, my colleague Senator Richardson, whose duty was to start now, has taken the opportunity, because I am still stuck here, to clear off. I have to stay here now until 12 o'clock. I was hoping the debate could be finished.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my remarks by wishing aloud that as a result of the economic statement yesterday the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) is not prejudging that the inflation rate will get to 15 per cent in any one year. It is probably worth noting, the Minister having raised the question of inflation, that we have seen inflation gallop under this Government, but hopefully it will not get to 15 per cent in any one year.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the amendment that Senator Parer foreshadowed. I accept the Minister's explanation, and Senator Parer has also explained it to me, but I want to clarify the Bill in my own mind. I am talking about the levy Bill, which says at subclause 8 (2):
After 30 June 1993, an amount applicable under paragraph 7 . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —What document are you reading from?
—I am referring to the Marine Navigation (Regulatory Functions) Levy Bill 1991: page 3, clause 8, line 3. Subclause 8 (2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: After 30 June 1993, an amount applicable under paragraph 7 (2) (a), (b), (c) or (d) must not be increased by more than 15% in any 12 consecutive months.

Could the Minister explain the words `an amount applicable under paragraph 7 (2) (a), (b), (c) or (d)'. What is the amount applicable under paragraph 7 (2) (a), (b), (c) or (d)? For example, clause 7 (2) (a) states:
4 cents, or such other amount as is from time to time prescribed, for each of the first 5,000 tons of the ship's tonnage.

It is 4c, or such other amount as is prescribed. The Minister indicated to me during the break that that could increase to 30 per cent. I do not know what that means in dollars and cents, but if there is an amount in that up to June 1993-let us say it is $40 per tonne-does the 15 per cent then apply to the $40 per tonne or does it apply to the 4c? I hope I am making myself clear. Is the amount applicable the 4c, and can it be increased by 15 per cent, or is the amount whatever might be prescribed in those first three years, and then increased by 15 per cent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did explain that to Senator Macdonald during the break. He is quite correct, I do understand the question; it was clear. The reason why we want the legislative flexibility to increase the charges is the very reason for which Senator Macdonald has raised his question. These figures contained in the existing legislation-just to put a rough figure on it; it would not be exact-will collect about a third of the total levy that will be charged in the final year.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, if the date were taken out, it would take eight years to collect the full amount. That will collect the equivalent amount in the first year that is required.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, that is not the point. I accept the point that the Minister has made. Is the amount applicable, referred to in subclause 8(2), the 4c, which can then be increased by 15 per cent by year four, or is it whatever the 4c may have been increased to by regulation?
—It is the second.
—So if it is increased by 4c to 40c in the first three years, or $40 in the first three years, then the 15 per cent is on the $40, not on the 4c?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The easiest way to explain it would be to use the total amount. The total amount of money being collected by this levy is around $7m a year for the whole industry. No doubt that amount will increase in line with the inflation rate over the next three years up to 1993. The 15 per cent cap that will then be levied will be on the final figure in that third year, so it will be on the $7m plus whatever the increases are. It will not be 15 per cent on year one; it will be 15 per cent on year three.

—What is the point of putting 4c, 3c, 3c, and 2c in the Bill? Is 4c an estimate of what will be needed to run it after June 1993? Is that the Minister's current estimate of what will be required after June 1993?

—As I explained during the break, in the negotiations with the industry we wanted to inject some certainty into the matter so the industry knew where it was. To avoid any difficulties at all with the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills or anyone else we could have taken the decision, considering that the total amount is $7m a year industry wide, simply to impose that immediately from year one. We could have said, `We will collect the full $7m in year one and have a 15 per cent cap after that'. But we decided not to do that, and I think that is reasonable, even though the amount is only $7m. It is a new charge and it should be phased in.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry wanted some degree of certainty. The reason those figures have been put into the Bill, so that they are in the Act, is to provide an absolute starting point for the industry so that it knows right now what the initial charges will be, and I think that is reasonable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister another question. He may not be prepared for it, but I notice that he does have his advisers with him. If my recollection is correct-I might not have the right terminology-regarding things such as lighthouses, navigational aids and so on, I understood that a charge had already been made on shipping and I think it was called light dues. Is it the intent that this will replace light dues? Will light dues continue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not. The navigational aids are very significant expenditure. My advisers can correct me on the exact figure, and I will ask them in a minute, but, from memory, the total amount of money required to service all the navigational aids is in the vicinity of $42m a year. By comparison, the regulatory side of it-that is, the safety regulation side of it-which is designed to collect, is quite a small figure by comparison. To operate the massive lighthouses and navigational aids around Australia is around $42m a year, and that will still remain to be collected.
—Is it the intent down the track-this is more an interest type question-to incorporate light dues and so on within this sort of legislation under the AMSA?

—I would not think so. For convenience, I guess there would be no real problem in doing it, but there is no real need to do so. The legislation exists separately that provides for that. It is a very distinct service and a very distinct charge and the industry is well aware of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The specific answer to the honourable senator's question would be no. There is no intention to do so by this Government because it is well understood in the industry to incorporate both navigational and light dues charges in this kind of legislation which currently exists and is operating quite well, so we will leave it alone.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to keep on about this matter, but I just want to be perfectly clear in my own mind. Is the 4c, 3c, 3c, and 2c the Minister's estimate-it may not be quite correct, it may have to be increased a little-of what will be needed in the first three years to recover $7m or what is expected would be needed, having made the initial recovery, plus inflation, to keep the thing going after 30 June 1993?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I do apologise if I am not explaining it, but I thought I was very specific. The charges are so that the industry knows right now, at the beginning of the process, what will be charged in the next 12 months. I will give the honourable senator the figures, which are not a guesstimate. The figures that are being levied are designed to raise on the 4c, et cetera, approximately $2 1/2m in the first year; it is split into three bits.
—I thank the Minister. That is all I want to know. Are those the figures that will apply in the first year, as best the Minister can estimate?
—That is correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did enjoy the rare opportunity to bask in the praise of Senator Macdonald. I would even like to prolong the moment. However, I have to concede that the Minister's explanation was totally acceptable to me. I accept that under the regulations, which I now have a copy of, there is no discretion and the levy must be refunded. It is not appropriate, by my amendment, to put in a mechanism by which we can appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I only foreshadowed my amendment; I will not be proceeding to move it. I still think it was important to raise the principle of inappropriate delegation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond briefly to something Senator Collins raised. I make it clear that these opinions are entirely my own and I have not discussed them with members of my Party. Senator Collins has made quite a lot of the fact that I have only attacked the unions. My investigations and my discussions, particularly in the part of the world where I come from, suggest to me it is not only the unions. It is principally the unions because of the practices that have established themselves over the years, but those practices have been acquiesced in by certain employers.

SPEECH.PARA: There would be many excuses why employers did cave in and did acquiesce. When one has a shotgun held at one's temple, one does not have much alternative but to acquiesce. But I do say there is some division amongst the employers on the attitudes that should have been adopted on the waterfront over the years. There are certain employers who do not agree with the way their peak bodies have handled the matter over the years. I am pleased that there are some employers who have gone outside what might be called a closed shop approach and taken different views and different attitudes because they realise at times that they, as a group of employers, have exacerbated the situation by agreeing to unreasonable demands and work practices that were not just scandalous but were fraudulent-fraudulent on the Australian public.

I am pleased to say that there are employers now who are prepared to stand up and to take the consequences. Hopefully, in doing that, they will achieve something for Australia as a whole. But I want to make Senator Collins aware that I do not say-and I never have said-that the fault is entirely with the unions. It starts with the unions because they want these practices implemented, but the employers have been equally as guilty over the years by acquiescing in them. I want to put that on record as my thoughts; it is a two-way street. The solution is for the employers to stand up and for the unions to be reasonable about it. If that can be achieved in the future then Australia will have been done a great service. My regret is that I do not think that has been achieved.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am grateful for the clarification Senator Macdonald has provided because, frankly, I agree with it. The difficulty has been caused by what he outlined, but we cannot blame the unions for that. Senator Macdonald is quite right: it initiated with the unions. Of course, if they are in a position-as any other person would in the same bargaining situation-such as entering into a contract with someone else, having to bargain with someone where one thinks the other party is going to cave in, fold and give up--
—It is pretty uneven.

—I agree. I just rose to say I appreciate Senator Macdonald's clarification. He is quite right. I was interested to see that Richard Setchell-who has been one of the severest critics of the Government's reform program until recent times-in the final paragraph of his most recent statement commended the Government on its resolve and hoped we would continue it, and we will. He has been one of its severest critics and he acknowledged on national television-I think in April last year-precisely what Senator Macdonald has said, that the companies and management have to bear a lot of responsibility where, when they had the opportunities in the past on some work practices to stand up and be counted, they failed to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I generally support the remarks of both Senator Macdonald and Senator Collins on this matter because I think we are talking about something terribly important to this country and we should treat it that way. Cheap point scoring should not be the order of the day. However, I point out that there are a lot of people to blame for our present position. Having already had our burst on the unions, about which generally one could not refer to a level playing field by any stretch of the imagination, we must also consider the stevedores in the middle and, of course, the shippers, whom very few mention.

SPEECH.PARA: But most of us recall the sorts of things that went on: a ship partly loaded, then probably a phoney dispute pulled-whether it be on safety or some political issue-and the shipper going to the stevedore and saying, `What do you have to pay these people? If it is $100,000, give them the cash and let's get the ship out of the port'. They were the sorts of things that went on. They became additive and cumulative because once a union has established that it has achieved an end, from that particular point of time it becomes entrenched.

One of the greatest difficulties I have when I talk to union people-I think Senator Collins and these people recognise that these things are ridiculous-about giving up these things is that they talk about these `hard won gains'. I think that is the most common phrase I hear within the trade union movement: `We are not about to give up hard won gains'. I think the only way to go down this track is to have more competition between ports. We must get genuine enterprise agreements. If we have an enterprise agreement which is the same for every port we do not have enterprise agreements; we still have the old pooling system with centralised control.

I make those points because Senator Collins indicated earlier in his second reading speech that he was not hearing anything from the Opposition about where we want to go. If he reads, as Senator Macdonald said, our industrial relations policy, he will see quite clearly that it deals with enterprise based unions, in getting rid of closed shops and introducing competition not only within the employer groups but also within the labour market itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 contains minor administrative amendments to: the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985 and consequential amendments; the Dairy Produce Act 1986; the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act 1986; and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the legislation is to change the names of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation to the Meat Research and Development Corporation and the Australian Dairy Industry Conference Inc. to the Australian Dairy Industry Council. This Bill also introduces equal opportunity amendments for the Australian Dairy Corporation in the same manner as were approved for the Australian Wheat Board. Other amendments in the Bill allow the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation to develop a more commercial role in research.

With regard to the Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985, the amendments will change the name of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation to the Meat Research Corporation. The decision to change the name has come from the Corporation to prevent confusion with the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation. Owing to the fact that the name occurs in 15 other Acts there are consequential amendments. Other amendments will permit the Government to match industry funding to 0.5 per cent of gross value of production.

The amendments to the Dairy Produce Act 1986 will insert government equal opportunity clauses. This amendment falls into line with legislation relating to other statutory authorities. I take this opportunity to reflect on the debate in this chamber last week, initiated by Senator Newman and Senator Brownhill, with regard to the plight in the rural community of Australia at the moment and, in particular, for the 2 1/2 million women living in rural Australia where the current economic situation is very dire. Inflation, unemployment and high interest rates have hit hard. Pain and anguish stalk our farms and country towns.

It is well recognised that the hours worked by farm people, especially farm women, are considerably more than the national average and the return for effort in monetary terms is increasingly inadequate. Of a total Australian farm work force in 1989 of some 390,000, approximately 100,000 or 25 per cent were women. Of course, in many instances that probably does not recognise the considerable voluntary contribution by many owner workers, who are women, in this particular industry.

I was interested to note in a report tabled for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet a survey of rural women in Australia that goes under the title of Life has never been easy. There are a number of issues that have been identified as problems in this area but the factors that stand out as the biggest problems for rural women today are the financial and economic issues. Of course many other issues have to be addressed and it was interesting to note, in that report, issues such as income assistance for farmers in times of rural decline.

From the perspective of northern Australia, it is interesting to note that the taxation zone rebates for people in zone allowance areas have not been altered by the Labor Government since 1984. Whilst there have been a number of reviews by the country task force set up by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in recent years, the Government has not alluded to any changes in this area. It was not addressed yesterday in the industry statement. We need to really look very carefully at those zone rebates which have been described as `sufficient to pay the freight on a newspaper, a carton of milk and a loaf of bread'. Certainly the original aims were that the zone rebate particularly in northern Australia would compensate in so many of the other areas.

When we look at the other issues that arise, whether they relate to the family allowance supplement, to Austudy or to other areas, we need to recognise that in rural Australia there are problems particularly in areas of entertainment and culture in the non-urban centres, such as access to libraries, arts, crafts, theatre and dance, which are often made on the farm and generated internally. Many people in rural areas have inadequate counselling services. They certainly do not get access to the more urbanely provided child-care facilities. There are just so many areas in which we do have to admire the changes. Therefore, we should note carefully the Government amendments with regard to equal opportunity in this particular Bill and the fact that they relate to a very important principle of merit.

Amendments also change the name of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference to the Australian Dairy Industry Council and its executive council to be known as its executive. The changes require consequential amendments to the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act 1986.

The amendments to the Horticultural Research and Development Act 1987 provide for changes to the commercial role, administrative control and accountability of the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation, and are consistent with those contained within the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 which sets the framework for all rural research. These amendments will allow the Corporation power to commercialise research and development and to join in the formation of a company to acquire, hold and dispose of real and personal property. Other amendments allow for meetings to be held by electronic means rather than by having face to face meetings.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to join in this debate because I feel that any discussion about primary industries is now of vital importance to Australia's entire economic and social fabric. The Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, which we are now debating, is an omnibus Bill which seeks to make a number of minor amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, it changes the name of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation to the Meat Research Corporation, and the Australian Dairy Industry Conference Inc. to the Australian Dairy Industry Council. It also introduces equal opportunity amendments for the Australian Dairy Corporation in the same manner as was approved for the Australian Wheat Board in past legislation. Other amendments in the Bill allow horticultural research and development to develop a more commercial role in research. These are minor matters as far as the Opposition is concerned, but they are important. Hidden behind these changes is the economic situation which confronts Australia today and the fact that our primary industries are the important industries which can get our economy back on track.

In its impact, this legislation is not of major significance. However, the circumstances in which it is being debated-the tragic social and economic implications of the rural depression-must be of great concern to this Parliament. Whilst the debate in recent weeks has focused on free and fair trade issues and on the question of protection and tariffs, the horrendous impact of domestic costs has not received the attention it warrants. Already some 60 per cent of the cause of reduced incomes to rural industries today relates directly to our internal structures on interest rates, inflation, outdated work practices and the sustained and continuing attack on the productive sector and its assets.

Part of the Bill before the House refers to equal opportunity for females within these corporate bodies. I do not think anyone would oppose that in any way. It falls into line with legislation relating to other statutory authorities, but I take this opportunity to pay tribute to those women who work within the primary industries. I am speaking about the family farm, which is basically the backbone of agriculture today in Australia, as I trust it will be over the many years ahead. If one goes on the farm today, one finds that the wife of the farmer and even his children share the responsibility for running and working the property. There are certain radical groups who see the current phenomenon of an increasing number of women in the work force as important. I would like to put a slightly different view. In agriculture this is not a success story but the indication of the failure of our social and economic system. Women who have been a partner in farming activities and who have formed a very valuable part of agricultural pursuits are working not to achieve some new career aim but because the chosen career they took up with their partners is regrettably being destroyed.

The amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act change the name of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation to the Meat Research Corporation. The decision to change the name came from the Corporation, to prevent its being confused with the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation. Other amendments will confine the Government's commitment to match industry research funding to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production. As a result of the name changes, 15 other Acts will need to have consequential amendments made to them.

Last year I had the opportunity to speak in the Senate on the tabling of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation annual report and I congratulated the Corporation on the research work it has done into major areas affecting the industry both in the on-farm and off-farm sectors. I noted that the Corporation commissioned a number of research programs to service urgent industry needs. A number of them were designed to maximise the benefits for Australian producers and processors from the expanding Asian beef markets, to increase the volume of land going into the higher value domestic and export market, to increase the demand and price for Australian sheepskins and to increase the productivity of cattle and sheep by genetic engineering or rumen microbes.

However fine and commendable these objectives are, I doubt there has been much success with them in the past year because, as all honourable senators know, there has been a dramatic turnaround in the fortunes of anyone associated with the Australian rural sector. Already honourable senators would know that the nation's greatest single export earner-the wool industry-has had its confidence shattered, and the wheat industry is in similar shape. It does not matter whether we produce the goods; factors outside the farm such as disastrous Government decisions on rural issues, in addition to the Government's economic policies, mean that being on the land is just not profitable. I certainly speak from experience as one who lives on the land and knows of the bills which have to be paid.

I reiterate: primary industry is not fully recognised as it should be in this country. It is no use sending a delegation of Ministers or even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the United States or the European Economic Community when these countries have no intention in the long term of reducing support for their producers and consumers. I believe this is an important fact to remember. We know that we are efficient upon the farm, but if there is a problem, as there is in the wheat and wool industries, the Government has to come to their support.

Let us look at the other support that the Government gives to primary industry in this country. We get a rebate on diesel fuel, certainly, and there are other little forms of assistance. I hope that the wheat industry will receive a large form of assistance. But we should compare what is given in Australia with what is given in other countries against which our farmers have to compete. This is the important fact. Our farmer is working his family farm and has his money tied up in the capital of that property, in his stock and plant, and he has to compete with other countries. We ought to be a little more open-minded than we are with regard to the needs of our farmer and the important role that he plays so far as our national economy is concerned.

I know that the leading farm organisations within Australia say that farmers want to stand upon their own feet. But can farmers stand upon their own feet when we find that overseas other countries are dumping and are supporting their farmers so much financially? The farmer does not want a handout, but he wants to know that he has friends in government and opposition who are prepared to come to his aid if needs be.

If we are to compete fairly, assistance has to be there for farmers. The Chairman of the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation said last year that the decade we have just entered will be a testing one for our sheepmeat and beef industries. He is certainly right about that. He also stated that our markets and consumers' needs are changing significantly and that both sectors must change with them. Producers will have to produce to market specifications which best suit their enterprise, and processors will have to reduce the cost of processing and lower the two to three times difference in costs which exist between Australia and its competitors. Failure to do so will relegate the Australian meat industry to producers of manufacturing meat only and will force us to forgo the premiums associated with quality.

In order to lower this difference in costs between Australia and its competitors, we should also be looking at the imposts placed on small rural businesses and farming families by bureaucracy and big business. An estimated 30,000 farmers are currently suffering a cost price squeeze which will force many from the industry in the 1990s to join the 30,000 farmers who have already left the industry over the past 30 years. That statistic will surely add weight to the Chairman's predictions for the 1990s.

A recent report in my local newspaper, the Courier-Mail, stated that farm incomes are expected to crash by more than 50 per cent in most categories this financial year and continue to decline in 1991-92. The statistics show that wool farms will be hardest hit, as well as mixed farms and wheat farms. The article also reported that even beef farmers, who will fare the best in the next few years, will not do very well. They are still expected to sustain a loss in their cash operating surplus of 14 per cent this financial year from $30,000 last year to $25,700 this year and up to $26,500 next year. The situation for family farmers is even gloomier when depreciation of farm land and equipment is taken into account, with just over 50 per cent of farms expected to have positive incomes.

The problem is that many Australians do not realise how bad the rural downturn has become. They do not understand the critical problems facing farmers and graziers. Most Australians live in urban communities where they expect, or these days hope, to receive a weekly wage packet, where all manner of services are readily available and where governments provide an infrastructure that for the most part is adequate to meet demands. Urban Australians are shielded from the most obvious effects of depressed commodity markets. They pay less for basic goods because they live within the reach of transport systems in which costs are moderated by the economies of scale. Droughts reduce them only to rationing the water with which they sprinkle their lawns. Other quirks of nature are largely insurable disasters.

Contrast this comfortable lifestyle with that of the people in the bush, whose efforts, ever since we became a nation and from well before that time, have produced the export income which underpins Australian society. Their products are subject to the fickleness of world commodity markets. Their hard-won and finely honed skills are rendered redundant by technology. They pay vastly more for petrol and all kinds of services and equipment because the national transport system cannot deliver goods to remote areas cost effectively. Droughts lead not to parched lawns but to ruination. Hailstorms and floods wipe out crops and stock.

Against all this, the very price of living and working in the bush keeps rising far beyond the cosily metropolitan confines of the consumer price index. The family farm is being driven out of business and the country is being flayed raw. Meanwhile, governments have decided to make the user pay. That is fine. There is no problem with that. But I want to remind senators that there are fewer and fewer people in the bush who can pay and who are there to pay.

Australia has a golden opportunity to become the world's greatest agricultural exporter with its pollution free food. We are on the doorstep of rapidly emerging Asian markets, the demand from which is expected to lift commodity prices in real terms for the first time this century. However, we must work to ensure that government policies do not prevent us from servicing those markets.

It is not much use to so rationalise our rural sector that we eventually see the demise of the family farm. If in the process of achieving cost efficient industries we push the family farmer off the land, in the long run we are certainly serving no really good purpose for Australia. We should ever be vigilant that we do not allow ideology on economic issues and crass politics to misplace the needs of people. This is what is happening in many industries today, I regret to say, and it is at the expense of one of the most important sections of our community-the small family farmer, whose economic survival is at risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Loan Bill 1991 seeks to give the Government authority to borrow funds to meet the shortfall that is occurring between the moneys appropriated by the Parliament in the Budget last year and, subsequently, the funds that are available through the Consolidated Revenue Fund to meet those appropriations. To some extent, this Bill is a standard technical Bill to authorise the financing in situations such as this. To that extent, it is essentially identical with Loan Bills that have been required for similar purposes in the past. This is the first Loan Bill that we have had since 1987. In the years since then there has been a sufficient surplus in the Government's accounts to meet the requirements through the appropriations.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, the Bill is a Bill that we were not going to have. It is a little like the recession of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that he was not going to let happen-the recession that a few months later he then said we had to have. We were not going to have a loan Bill in this financial year, 1990-91. It was not going to be required because the Government had budgeted for an $8.1 billion surplus only last August when the 1990-91 Budget was brought down. But because of the major unravelling of the whole of the Government's fiscal policy and, as a result of that, the massive deterioration in the budgetary situation, the Government is now going to be forced to go to the market for considerable funds to finance the gap that now exists between the funds in the Consolidated Revenue Fund and the appropriations that have been made. As I say, this is a bit like the recession that we were not going to have and then that we had to have. This is a Bill that we were not going to have but that we now have to have.

Had the Bill been programmed and planned properly at the start of the year, and had the Government read the political wind, it would surely have recognised that a loan Bill would have been required, because there was no way that the Government was ever going to reach its estimated surplus figures for this year. We said so on the very day the Budget was brought down, and everything that has happened since then has confirmed the accuracy of the coalition's predictions on that front. Had the Government planned for a loan Bill, as it should have done, this Bill would have been, along with normal practice, introduced into the Parliament shortly after the Appropriation Bills had been passed last year. So the normal time for the introduction of a loan Bill is somewhere around October each year.

The Loan Bill, which I say at the outset the coalition, of course, is not opposing, is needed simply because of quite massive financial mismanagement on the part of the Government and quite massive financial budgetary irresponsibility. It is those things that have led to the unravelling of the Budget; the deterioration in the Budget situation; and, therefore, the need for this Bill. It is for that reason that, whilst not opposing this Bill, on behalf of the coalition I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but that the Senate condemns the Government for its economic mismanagement and fiscal irresponsibility, which has resulted in a severe and protracted recession and lead to:
(a) a substantial shortfall in Commonwealth revenues for the year ending 30 June 1991;
(b) a major increase in Commonwealth expenditure for the year ending 30 June 1991;
(c) a reduction in the Budget forecast of an $8.1 billion surplus to a possible deficit for 1990-91;
(d) an increase in the public sector's call on national savings of up to 3% of Gross Domestic Product in 1990-91, compared with the Budget forecast of a zero requirement; and
(e) an expected deficit starting point for the 1991-92 Budget based on existing forward estimates.''

Looking briefly at each of those points in the amendment, there has been a major erosion in Commonwealth revenues to date this financial year that will continue for the remainder of this financial year. That is essentially due to the recession-a recession which, according to Senator Button in his reply to me during debate last week, the Government apparently did not forecast at the time of bringing down the Budget last August. Yet it was only three months after that that the Treasurer admitted that we were in recession. He could not do anything else because the national accounts figures showed indisputably that this was the case. It was a recession that, in any case, everyone in Australia knew we were in the middle of but it took three months after the Budget for the Treasurer to admit that.

Despite the fact that the Treasurer said, when admitting the recession, that it was a recession that we had to have, that it had been deliberately engineered and that he, the Treasurer, and the Government had actually pulled the levers to engineer it, Senator Button advised me last week in this place that none of that had been forecast at the time the Budget was brought down on 21 August and, therefore, there was no expectation on the Government's part that the revenue shortfall and the expenditure overrun, which I will come to in a second, was likely to occur. I find that absolutely amazing; it is quite extraordinary.

It is also extraordinary that that issue was not addressed at all yesterday in the industry statement. There was no recognition or acknowledgment at all of any weakening of fiscal policy. Indeed, whilst announcements made yesterday in the industry statement will not have much fiscal impact in this current financial year, I believe that a time bomb has been built into the Budget in that over the next two or three years, commencing in 1991-92, the budgetary position is going to be made that much more difficult by yesterday's decisions. In 1993-94 the impact of yesterday's budgetary decisions through the industry statement will be no less than $1.2 billion and in 1992-93 it will not be much short of that figure either. It is extraordinary, though, that none of that was acknowledged in yesterday's industry statement.

There has been a major shortfall in Commonwealth revenues in this current financial year because of the recession. Company tax payments are down enormously, pay as you earn payments are down very significantly and sales tax receipts and indirect tax receipts are down right across the board. Just a couple of weeks ago the Treasurer admitted to the Economic Planning Advisory Council that the shortfall in terms of some of those revenues was going to be of the order of $2.8 billion. On a realistic assessment, it is not difficult to get that figure up to $4 billion.

This year the Government has had this major shortfall in revenues at the same time as it has had major increases in Commonwealth expenditure. The point that the Treasurer is trying to delude the Australian community into believing is that this massive increase in government spending has all been due just to the automatic impact of the recession on such things, in particular, as the payment of unemployment benefit. It is simply not true that the major part, or by any means all, of the expenditure blow-out has been due to that at all.

There have been major discretionary decisions taken by the Government since the Budget was brought down last August which have added to that increase in Commonwealth spending. Even if we had not had a recession and even if we had not had the additional spending decisions that have been taken since the Budget, we still would have had a major increase in the Commonwealth's own purpose spending during 1990-91.

Last August when the Government was talking about fiscal responsibility and the need for us all to pull in our belts and so on, the Treasurer was budgeting for an increase in the Government's own purpose spending of about 12 per cent-5 1/2 per cent in real terms and roughly 6 1/2 per cent for inflation. So, while the Treasurer was reading the Australian people a lecture about the need for financial discipline in their own households and businesses, in his own household and business he was going for a massive 12 per cent increase in Commonwealth Government spending. The Treasurer tried to dress that up by making it look not as bad as that by squeezing the Commonwealth payments to the States so that the increase in State spending was much less and therefore, the overall budgetary look from the Commonwealth was that much less. But let no-one be in any doubt that there was a major increase in Government spending planned at the time of the last Budget. That has been executed and executed plus because of all the other things that have happened since then, only one of which actually is the impact of the recession.

Taking that shortfall in revenues and the overrun in expenditures into account, the Government now has a totally discredited Budget surplus figure that was quoted at the time of the Budget. The Treasurer was so certain of it that he quoted it to three decimal points. The Treasurer said that the Budget for 1990-91 would come in at $8.107 billion. That figure now, even on the Treasurer's own admission, is down to $1.7 billion, at best. Indeed, in a television interview only 10 days ago the Treasurer said that the Budget for the year could go into deficit.

What makes that even more extraordinary, apart from the unbelievably bad economic management and financial planning to get such a turnaround-I think the largest turnaround that has occurred in postwar history-between what was planned at the time of the Budget and what the actual Budget outturn was, is the admission the other day by the Treasurer that the Budget could finish up with a deficit. He said, `But that would not be any great calamity; there would be no calamity in that'. This is despite the fact that one of the key planks of his Budget Speech in August was that the maintenance of fiscal discipline, which he described as the $8.1 billion surplus plan, was the principal weapon that the Government was going to use against the current account deficit, against the debt situation and, therefore, by implication, against inflation and all the other problems besetting the economy.

That principal weapon of the Government has gone absolutely out of the window. The Government has not put anything at all in its place; indeed, it is not even admitting now that it has lost the principal weapon, so one could not get a starker example of the lack of understanding by this Treasurer about the economy and the requirements of economic policy. I will come back in a moment to the implications of that, because that is what this Loan Bill is very much about.

As a result of this massive deterioration in the Budget, there will be an increase in the public sector's call on national savings. I estimate-various commentators have estimated different figures-that the call on national savings by the public sector in this financial year, that is, 1990-91, will be up to 3 per cent of gross domestic product. That is a figure of $10 to $12 billion, and that compares with the Treasurer's statement in the Budget last August that the public sector as a whole, as a result of his so-called fiscal responsibility and fiscal discipline, would be in balance for the year as a whole. That obviously is wildly out. Far from the Commonwealth and the public sector's accounts contributing to the national savings pool, what in fact is going to happen this year is that the public sector generally-the Commonwealth Government particularly, but also State and local government-has got its hands right in the cookie jar of the national savings, and that is going to be of great detriment to the private sector and is going to have some very significant implications for financial management and interest rate policy over the next couple of years. I will come back to that shortly.

That is the fourth point in the coalition's condemnatory amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill. The last one, and it follows automatically from the four I have just mentioned, is that, because of all those things that have happened this financial year-and when one looks at the Government's own Forward Estimates for the next financial year, 1991-92-it appears that there would be no way in which the Government, in starting the framing of next year's Budget, would be starting other than from a position of deficit, and quite a potentially significant deficit.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. It stems from some confusion in the wider community and obvious confusion in the ranks of the Opposition about the flexibility provisions resulting from the award restructuring process. Can the Minister advise honourable senators how the flexibility clauses in restructured awards operate? Will the Minister also advise what provisions exist in the flexibility clauses to protect the interests of workers, particularly those with weak bargaining power?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Sherry for his continuing keen and intelligent interest in industrial relations. Doubtless this question arises because in some of the post-industry statement comments that have been made there has been reference to the so-called inflexibility of the Australian labour market, which is really meant to be the inflexibility of the wage fixing system. I am struck on the one hand that spokespersons for the Opposition refer to the SPC dispute as an example of their ideal in flexibility. I remind the Senate that the SPC outcome occurred through the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and demonstrated, therefore, the very flexibility that Opposition spokespeople pretend does not exist.

ANSWER.PARA: The award restructuring processes that have been referred to have resulted in many changes in reforms to the way workers and managers organise their work in the workplace. A particularly positive feature of award restructuring has been the incorporation into awards of some very important flexibility clauses.

Nearly all major awards now include enterprise flexibility clauses and/or facilitative clauses. Facilitative clauses enable managers and employees to reach agreement at the workplace level on specified conditions or issues consistent with the general less prescriptive award provision. For example, the ordinary hours of work as specified in an award may be extended from, say, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. Monday to Friday, to 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. Monday to Saturday, and within this expanded range managers and employees can negotiate the range of hours which best suits their needs without having to go back to the Commission to do so. Most facilitative clauses state that the union must be consulted and/or a sizeable proportion of the workers, around 60 per cent, must agree with the changes that are being proposed.

Enterprise flexibility clauses are different clauses which incorporate negotiating frameworks into awards allowing agreements to be reached that enable award provisions to be altered at the enterprise level. The range of issues on which agreement can be reached is generally much wider than that available under facilitative clauses. These issues include: the provision for time off in lieu of overtime; the introduction of 12-hour shifts; increased flexibility in the taking of annual leave; expansion of the span of hours in which penalty rates do not apply; and the reduction of the minimum payment for weekend overtime. Enterprise flexibility clauses typically contain provisions to protect the interests of workers such as the requirement for consultation with unions and ratification of award variations by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

This Government has introduced even further scope for enterprise flexibility through the facility for employers to register section 115 certified agreements. This facility allows employers and unions, by agreement, to opt out of a formal award structure and register with the Industrial Relations Commission a set of arrangements tailored to the particular enterprise. However, such agreements must be judged by the Industrial Relations Commission to be in the interests of the parties involved and not against the public interest. At November last year, 45 certified agreements had been registered.

I conclude by saying that, in the current national wage case, the hearing of which has been completed and we now await judgment, the Government has submitted that there should be greater flexibility devolved to the enterprise and to allow particular negotiation for achieved productivity and profitability gains. I note that last Saturday Mr Ian Spicer, the chief executive of the Confederation of Australian Industry, said of the flexibility in the current system, `The system is able to deliver extraordinary flexibility if that is what employers really want'.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the disturbing reports of unrest in Yugoslavia, including major demonstrations in the capital, Belgrade, in which two people are reported to have been killed and dozens wounded, and which has led to the presence of troops in the streets. What is the Australian Government's assessment of the current situation and prospects for the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As all honourable senators will appreciate, the situation throughout Yugoslavia is indeed tense at the moment. The events in recent days are the latest manifestation of the very considerable uncertainty which exists there about the country's future. As Senator Loosley said, a large demonstration was held in Belgrade just a few days ago, on 9 March, in which over 50,000 people protested against the policies of the Government of the Republic of Serbia and in particular government control over television. The Serbian authorities had not given permission for the demonstration to be held. They called on police, supported by the army, to disperse the crowd and two people were killed and some 70 injured in the ensuing violence.

ANSWER.PARA: Tension remains high in Belgrade, where demonstrations for and against the Serbian Government of President Milosevic are continuing to take place. It is the case that the Serbian Assembly has now agreed to set up a commission of inquiry into the violence, and reports this morning indicate that the Serbian authorities have now dismissed a number of senior officials in the broadcasting organisation.

The Australian Government certainly welcomes these decisions as first steps. We hope that as a result of the inquiry the violent scenes of the weekend will not be repeated. The circumstances of these disturbances are only part of a larger pattern of difficulty throughout Yugoslavia, where the non-communist governments of the republics of Croatia and Slovenia are calling for the creation of a loose confederation where sovereignty would reside in the individual republics, whereas the traditionalist communist Government of Serbia is wishing to maintain the present federal structure and centralised government. There have been several incidents in Croatia recently where confrontation between Croats and Serbs has occurred. Fortunately, they have not triggered wider ethnic unrest.

As I said in a statement on behalf of the Government on 1 February, the Australian Government urges all political forces in Yugoslavia to work together to find a peaceful solution to that country's problems. May I also take this opportunity to reassure the many thousands of Australians with relations in Yugoslavia that the Government is very conscious of their concerns. We will do what we can to encourage a peaceful solution to the problems in that country that respects the wishes of the people. We especially urge the Serbian authorities to exercise maximum restraint in dealing with protesters. We take the view and have communicated the view that mass protest of the kind currently under way in Belgrade should be met with dialogue, not strongarm tactics.

Finally, what are the procedures for information exchange between the Australian National Central Bureau of Interpol and the police forces of other Interpol member states and for the inspection by Australian citizens of any files which Interpol may have on them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an extraordinary question, which has been prompted by a front organisation of the Church of Scientology, which has published a tremendous amount of material which I know has raised misgivings in the community about the role of Interpol. I am very proud of the fact that the South Pacific island states have requested the Australian Federal Police (AFP) in Canberra to provide a regional communications network for their Interpol communications. That will be set up in Canberra under the auspices of the Australian Federal Police.

ANSWER.PARA: As for Interpol, it is true that 154 countries are members; so it embraces a wide range of regimes, including several of the great democracies such as the United States, the United Kingdom and, of course, Australia. Indeed, the Secretary-General of Interpol, whom I had the pleasure of meeting a couple of weeks ago, is a distinguished law enforcement officer from Scotland Yard and he has a very high reputation in United Kingdom policing. He is now based in Lyons in France, which is the headquarters of Interpol.

The second question which Senator Spindler asked was about Manuel Noriega. Various assertions have been made about Manuel Noriega, including by this Church of Scientology front organisation, that he once headed Interpol's drug division, which is a ludicrous and absurd suggestion. All that the honourable senator asked in his question was whether Manuel Noriega had been given an Interpol award for his anti-drug activities. The answer is no. At a regional conference held in Panama, I think in 1987, Manuel Noriega was given a memento of the fact that the conference was held, as often happens when a visiting head of government or head of state attends the opening of a conference. It was no more than that.

The honourable senator asked whether I am aware of claims by Nazi war criminal hunter, Simon Wiesenthal, that Interpol files were used by known Nazis before, during and after the war. The supposed Nazi past of Interpol has been thrown up from time to time. The facts are these: prior to the Second World War, the headquarters of Interpol were in Vienna and, of course, came under German control when Austria was annexed by Germany in 1938. In 1940, Interpol headquarters were moved to Berlin. The presidents of Interpol during that time were Nazi appointed senior officers of the Gestapo.

With the collapse of Germany in 1945, this Nazi dominated body ceased to exist; indeed, it had ceased to function normally during the war years when many members of Interpol were, of course, at war with Germany. In 1946, at an international conference in Brussels, it was decided to create a new Interpol based in France. Whilst, as I say, there was that unfortunate interregnum, if you like, during the war years, that is understandable. But the Nazi taint certainly did not affect the subsequent operations of Interpol.

As to the honourable senator's question about the procedures for information exchange between the Australian National Central Bureau of Interpol and the police forces of other Interpol members, they are fairly straightforward. If the United States, under some jurisdiction there, wishes to make an inquiry as to whether an alleged fugitive offender, for example on a murder charge, has fled the jurisdiction in the United States and is thought to be somewhere in Australia, that request for identification of the whereabouts of the person would be passed on to the AFP in Canberra, to its Interpol section, and the Victorian and New South Wales police forces would be asked to assist and, if they wished to, they would.

As for inspections by Australian citizens of any files Interpol may have on them, the operations of Interpol in Australia, conducted by the AFP, are strictly under the control of the Commissioner of the AFP and are subjected to all the normal safeguards of freedom of information. The Ombudsman has his normal role in relation to the handling of complaints about Interpol in so far as they have effect in Australia.

In short, the operations of Interpol, certainly in Australia, are conducted according to the laws of this country and are the responsibility of the Federal Police Commissioner. Everything that occurs here in Australia is subject, in particular, I emphasise, to the supervision of the Ombudsman's office, and the usual process for dealing with complaints is supervised by him.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ABORIGINAL DEATHS IN CUSTODY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of the Inquiry into the death of Walter James Barney

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This is the report of the inquiry into the death of Walter James Barney. I want to highlight some of the findings of this report because I think they are fairly significant. This report has been written by Commissioner Johnston.

Walter James Barney was 39 years old when he died in Townsville prison on 22 February 1981. The cause of death was haemorrhaging in the lungs precipitated by chronic lung disease from which Barney had suffered for many years. Barney was into the third day of a default sentence of seven days imprisonment after being convicted for drunkenness in a public place. Walter Barney lived with his friends as a homeless park dweller, a way of life, according to one of his sisters, which he preferred. As far back as 1964 Barney had been convicted of vagrancy.

To ascribe total blame to Barney for his inability to change his lifestyle in the intervening years is to misunderstand the significance of the historical and social realities that conditioned his life and the life of his parents and to underestimate the continuing effects of a history of paternalism and authoritarianism to which very many Aboriginal people in Queensland have been subjected. The life and death of Walter Barney stands as grim testimony to the inadequacy of the remedies utilised by the Queensland criminal justice system in dealing with homeless Aboriginal people addicted to alcohol.

On 20 February 1981, Barney appeared before Mr John Winmill, SM, in the Townsville Magistrates Court charged with drunkenness. He was convicted and fined $10, and in default seven days imprisonment. No time was allowed for him to pay the fine and Barney was taken to serve in Townsville prison his fifty-fourth sentence for public drunkenness. He was received at Townsville Prison at 3.35 p.m. on 20 February 1981. I think this is where we need to look at the sequence of events from then on.

In accordance with the usual practice on arrival at the prison in the absence of a visiting medical officer, Barney was examined by the prisoner who acted as a medical orderly. The prisoner medical or derly had been sentenced to life imprisonment in 1973 and shortly thereafter had been made medical orderly. His only qualification for the position was a first aid certificate he obtained when working on the Snowy Mountains scheme many years previously. Following the prisoner medical orderly's examination of Barney, he recorded the following on Barney's prison medical record:
Drunk
Reception
Shake from grog
Melerill . . .
seen by P.M.O.

No specific instruction or direction existed in 1981 as to the inspection of the inmates in the observation cells. The frequency of such inspections was, it seems, a matter for the discretion of the individual prison officers, who themselves had no medical training which would enable them to determine the necessary frequency of such inspections.

On 22 February 1981, the day Barney died, prison officer William Keith Lakos was rostered on duty from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. in A Wing. At 11.15 a.m. on 22 February 1981, Lakos and prison officer Gary William McClintock locked up the A Wing prisoners and went to lunch. In a statement made to the superintendent the same day, Lakos said that `the four OBS prisoners were all okay'.

Lakos has since left the prison service and cannot now be located. McClintock told the Commission that he now had `only a vague recollection of the events surrounding' Barney's death. No log of duty or occurrence record was kept by the prison in relation to A Wing and no witnesses can now recall the presence or activities of prison officers or prisoners in the vicinity of A Wing that day.

The report concluded that, whilst Barney's death was not preventable, his care and management whilst in Townsville Prison can be described only as deplorable. That the facilities were inadequate is now recognised and, following the Commission of Review into Corrective Services in Queensland by Commissioner Jim Kennedy, it is planned to make significant changes in the provision of health services to all correctional services in Queensland. What those changes will be and when they will be implemented remains to be seen.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

This report of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training relates to strengthening careers education in schools. At the present time there is something like 26 per cent youth unemployment in Australia and about 25.8 per cent of young Australians seeking full time jobs cannot find them. This is getting back to the levels of the early 1980s. I think the peak was in 1985 or so-of course, under the Labor Government. I think we all recognise that there is a great need for anything that can assist young people in getting jobs. The report says:

Careers education in schools should, in the Board's view, involve a K-12 approach which begins in primary schools with the development of general skills, attitudes and awareness about the world of work. Throughout junior secondary school, students should develop a gradual understanding of the place of work in Australian culture and a general awareness of the various occupations and careers available to them. The Board envisages that this process culminates in Years 9 to 12 with the acquisition of more specific knowledge about the world of work, including an understanding of further education and training options and their relationship to occupations and careers, and the development and awareness of the generic knowledge, skills and competencies required to participate in the workforce and to contribute to and participate in society generally.

Naturally, I think all honourable senators would say amen to all that. At the moment there is a special need for it because we have in the Australian education system at the moment an enormous number of people in the years 10, 11 and 12 segment who are, in fact, still at school because they cannot get jobs. In other words, there is a massive disappearance of young people off the dole queues, out of the unemployment figures, into the schools and one can ask the reasons for that.

The statistics are dramatic. I think that in the last 10 years there has been something like a doubling in the retention rates in secondary schools of people staying on at least into year 12. The Government may well claim that one of the reasons for this is that it spends something like $300m a year on extending Austudy to secondary school students. I think that covers about 150,000 young people under the age of 20.

If that enormous expenditure is increasing the capacity of some students to be able to get skills training, to get the benefit of careers education, then there is a net benefit, but I regret to say that there is the greater prospect that a large amount of that money is being spent simply to get young people out of the Government's unemployment figures which are already enormous and up round the levels at which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had said in 1984 no government should be forgiven for generating.

This Prime Minister should be reminded of the fact that under his deliberate policies, under the recession we had to have, we are now apparently getting the youth unemployment we had to have, and we are having, if you like, Austudy at secondary school level being used to an extent to hide the real impact of the inability of so many young people to get jobs.

As I said, this puts an added burden on the need for careers education in schools. That burden, I believe, having been put on the State systems by the Federal Government, should be at least partly met by the resources of the Federal Government which has created the problem in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the final report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on aspects of the proposal for a very fast train (VFT), together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Committee was directed to inquire into certain aspects of the proposal for a very fast train in August 1989. Since then, several major studies and decisions relevant to the project have been released. While the Committee received nearly 400 submissions, it is unfortunate that virtually all of the contributors provided their evidence before that material was available and before the preferred route option for the train was announced in October 1990.

In its report the Committee has incorporated what data was available at the point at which the report was finalised. It is important to recognise that at this stage more studies are being undertaken by the proponents of the VFT, the joint venturers. They also have proposals before the four governments through whose jurisdictions the route of the train would pass, and those governments have yet to give their formal approval for the project. There is, of course, the most important consideration, namely, a decision by the joint venturers on the feasibility of the project. The target date currently set for this decision is December 1992.

Although the Committee was not asked to examine the financial viability of the VFT proposal, it recognises that the project's proponents emphasise that the VFT is to be a private enterprise undertaking. In its report the Committee supports the project in general terms, but confines its assessment and recommendations to the matters specified in its terms of reference. In doing so, the Committee directs its recommendations to Government involvement with the project, matters such as environmental impact statements, implications for the Commonwealth at the VFT's construction stage, the possibilities for fast rail freight and safety and noise standards for the VFT.

Although the VFT proposal is a private enterprise initiative, the four governments it involves have vital and continuing roles in evaluating and approving aspects of it as it evolves, and if the decisions are made that it should proceed. The Committee endorses the role of governments in the proposal to date and encourages them to continue their assessments of it with a positive approach, on a basis of cooperation.

In concluding my remarks, I thank the present and past Committee members and all the other individuals and organisations, including the secretariat of the Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee, for their input and assistance during the whole inquiry.
