TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, which conducted this inquiry into the very fast train, I welcome the publication and presentation today of our report by the Chairman, Senator Foreman.

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry was somewhat limited in scope and it is perhaps worth repeating the particular limitations on the inquiry. The particular questions that were investigated by the Committee in its inquiry on the very fast train were: firstly, the effects which such a project could have on existing and future land use patterns and transport and communications infrastructure in south-eastern Australia; secondly, other possible environmental impacts of such a project, including possible noise and atmospheric effects; thirdly, transit time, route and technology options; fourthly, safety aspects both in terms of protection of passengers and effect on road toll; and, finally, the effect on energy usage.

Within those terms of reference, after very lengthy and detailed investigation and a number of hearings and consideration of a number of detailed submissions, the Committee generally adopted a favourable attitude towards the project. The Committee, as honourable senators would be aware from the terms of reference to which I referred, was not asked to assess the overall costs and benefits to Australia of the project. Nor was it asked to investigate the financial viability of the project. So those matters remain for further consideration by others.

But certainly we did investigate in great detail those aspects relating to the terms of reference. In relation to what Senator Vallentine said, we looked in particular in some detail at the environmental impact of this project. All of the evidence that we could garner led us to the conclusion that there were no detrimental environmental consequences sufficient for us to conclude that the project should not go ahead.

Senator Vallentine referred to the conservation movement's opposition to the project. The evidence that was put to us by the conservation movement, in particular the Australian Conservation Foundation, was grossly inadequate in supporting any arguments against the development of this project. As one of the members of the Committee said at the time, they were an embarrassment to the conservation movement in what they had to say to the Committee.

The arguments that it put to us were simply unconvincing against the very fast train going ahead. So there can be no serious opposition to this project on environmental grounds.

Generally, within the terms of reference, we reached a favourable conclusion on the project. Of course, the question mark remains with regard to its financial viability. It is a private enterprise project and, therefore, the funds raised for it must come from the private sector, which in turn must initially provide investors with the incentive to invest in the project.

The difficulties of the financial viability of the project obviously weigh heavily on the minds of its proponents because initially they proposed the concept of land value capture as a means of supplementing the financing of the project. In simple terms, that meant they were seeking government intervention to ensure that any increase in the value of land along the route of the very fast train would be garnered for the joint venture project proponents through a government grant of the right to capture the increased value of that land. This is generally known as a betterment tax proposal, with that betterment tax going to the proponents of the project rather than, as it does in some situations of local government and so on, to government revenue itself. That was the basis on which they sought to close the gap between the avenue required for financial viability of the project and passenger numbers and revenue that it might generate. That was rejected after consideration in particular by the New South Wales Government. It was also rejected by this Committee as a valid means of financing the project.

More recently, the joint venturers have proposed that certain tax concessions be given to the joint venture as a means of ensuring the financial viability of the project. In general, these tax concessions which are sought relate to deferring tax for which the project might be liable, rather than it not being liable for tax at all, by changing the nature of taxation applicable to such a project whereby investors in the project would be given tax deductibility for the funds which they put into the project as equity. In return, the project would forgo the tax benefits it would obtain from depreciation and other measures later in the life of the project. In other words, there would be no net loss of revenue for the Government overall but simply a deferral of certain tax liabilities on the part of the project.

I believe that that concept is worthy of further consideration. I was disappointed, therefore, to see a report in yesterday's newspaper that the Federal Government had rejected that proposition from the joint venturers. I believe that the project has sufficient merit that some tax concessions could be considered favourably by the Federal Government to encourage it to get off the ground, if that would make the difference between its being viable or not viable financially. Therefore, I would encourage the present Government to reconsider its attitude to those proposals from the joint venturers. I hope that the coalition parties, if the Government has not reconsidered by the time of the next election, as they develop transport policy in the lead-up to the next election, will consider reactivating those proposals and give them favourable consideration. There is a real question hanging over the project as regards its viability in terms of our present population.

One point which Senator Vallentine made which in the present circumstances certainly has some validity is that there is a real doubt as to whether Australia has sufficient population at present to generate sufficient passenger traffic to provide sufficient revenue to make the project profitable for investors. I have no doubt that in the future, as our population grows, particularly in the south-eastern corner of Australia, we will have sufficient population to make this project profitable. Therefore, in terms of national infrastructure, it may well be worth getting the project off the ground now so that it is in place as that population develops. As I said, that may require some initial up-front tax concessions. I believe that certainly is an area that ought to be given consideration favourably by the Government: to have the project under way now, even though the population does not exist now, so that it is in place as the population develops and can take advantage of the service.

One area of concern which the Committee had, given the issues of financial viability which I have raised, was the dangers of the project failing in the construction phase; in other words, the project getting under way, construction commencing and the joint venturers then finding that they do not have adequate capital to finish the project-to get it up and running. The Committee and, obviously, I as a member of that Committee strongly share the view that it should be made patently clear to the joint venturers that, in the event of the project failing, the Government would not come in and pick up the tab-would not take over the project and complete its development or be liable in any other way for the costs of the project.

We investigated various ways in which that could be made definite. There were certain recommendations from the Department of Transport and Communications and from other parties, but there is certainly no definite way in which one can set in concrete the fact that a government would not in the future pick up the cost of completing the project if the joint venturers were unable to finish the building of it. Simply, as the Committee recommends, there must be strong statements made by Government and Opposition that no present or future government would pick up the costs of that project should it fail. We believe that that is a very important factor. Those statements ought to be clear-cut so that the joint venturers are left in no doubt that this project would not become the responsibility of government.

That is a different issue from making some assessment of the financial viability of the project at the outset and providing, as I have urged, some further consideration of specific tax concessions to encourage equity investment in the project. I make a clear distinction between the issue of the government being required to come in and pick up the whole completion of the project, should it fail in its construction phase, and a very specific tax concession which might be offered to the joint venturers and equity investors in an effort to get the project off the ground.

In conclusion, I support the project. I believe that it has the potential to provide an exciting alternative means of transport in south-eastern Australia-a means of transport which will be viable in the longer term in this country. Therefore, if there are means of getting the project off the ground sooner rather than later, then I believe they ought to be explored, provided that they do not provide a cost to revenue as such but, rather, simply a deferral of revenue on the part of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When my comments were terminated before the suspension of the sitting for lunch, I was about to refer, in relation to the Loan Bill 1991 which we are now debating, to the financial implications of the situation which has now developed as a result of the massive deterioration in the Government's Budget this year, and to look also at the extremely worrying financial outlook for next year even if the Government were able-which seems unlikely-advantageously to turn around its Budget prospects.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, because of the deterioration that has occurred in its budgetary position, has now announced that it will conduct two bond tenders in the remaining months of this financial year. These will be the first normal-type bond tenders for this financial year. There was no requirement for one at all last financial year. The first of the two bond tenders will be on 16 April; the second one will probably be in May on a date yet to be announced.

The financial institutions in the marketplace are estimating that each tender will bring in some $800m to $1 billion; a combined total of close to $2 billion. How much does the Government need? To work that out we need to go back to the Budget figures and work forward from there. The Government budgeted for a surplus of $8.1 billion, but of that it spent $1 billion on making payments to Commonwealth superannuation funds. Prima facie, that left $7.1 billion as a contribution to domestic savings. That figure also is too high because it includes an amount close to $2 billion as a result of the proceeds of asset sales which, of course, are simply a switch of debt between the public and the private sectors and do nothing in net terms to the domestic situation. We also had the switch of responsibility for State debt from the Commonwealth back to the States. That totalled almost $1 billion in asset sales. So almost $2 billion has to come off the $7.1 billion to give the figure that was going to constitute the Government's contribution to domestic savings in the financial year 1990-91. Therefore, that brings the figure down to, say, $5 billion.

As I said, that was on the basis of an $8 billion Budget surplus, but it now appears that that surplus will all but disappear and could, according to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), even finish up as a deficit. Let us say for the purposes of this analysis that the 1990-91 Budget outturn will be balanced; that is, there will be no surplus or deficit. That is probably a reasonable assumption. On that basis, the $5 billion of Commonwealth contributions to domestic savings estimated at Budget time will turn out to be a $3 billion call on domestic savings. The question then is: how will the Commonwealth fund this $3 billion call on savings? It is not just $3 billion that it has to find. The Government has, or will have this year, redeemed a total of about $2 billion in foreign currency debt and some $300m through negative borrowing via the redemption of Australian savings bonds.

If we bring all that together, it means that on the basis of a balanced Budget outturn the Government this financial year-that is 1990-91-will be required to go to the market for a total amount of some $4.7 billion. This is a little complicated, so let me just spell it out again in a slightly different form: the Government this year had to raise $1 billion for the superannuation fund payments, $2 billion to repay maturing overseas debt-that makes a figure of $3 billion-another $300m through the negative borrowing as a result of the redemption of Australian saving bonds, which gives $3.3 billion, plus, because of the massive deterioration in the Government's budgetary position, another $3.4 billion for scheduled redemptions of maturing treasury bonds.

On the basis of a balanced Budget, the Government has to find $6.7 billion this year-1991. It has announced that there will be two treasury bond tenders. As I mentioned before, those two bond tenders are expected to raise up to $2 billion by the market. That leaves $4.7 billion to be raised by other means. The practicalities are that if it is not raised by further treasury bond tenders, then the full $4.7 billion would be required to be raised by the issue of treasury notes. That is a very large treasury note amount. It would significantly reduce the average maturity age of government debt and, therefore, increase the Government's risk exposure to interest rate fluctuations in the financial markets.

Depending on movements in interest rates next financial year-and I will come back later to why I think those movements will be upwards rather than downwards-the public debt interest bill could rise steeply and would rise steeply if rates rose. It would be more prudent, therefore, for the Government not to look to treasury notes for all its financing requirements this year over and above the already announced treasury bond tenders. I think that the Government should be giving consideration to at least a third bond tender.

My understanding from speaking with various financial institutions is that the market will be able to absorb these bond issues without difficulty this year-that is, 1990-91-but the problem for the market, and this stems directly from the Government's financial mismanagement and budgetary looseness, will come next year in 1991-92.

Let us just have a look at the years 1991 and 1992. There are $5 1/2 billion of domestic bond maturities in 1991-92 and there are $1 billion of offshore redemptions, which will be financed domestically as I understand it because of the Treasurer's obsession about overseas borrowing. He is concerned with his Moody's Investor Services rating because Moody's rates on the basis of the level of offshore debt, not domestic debt. So that gives $6.5 billion to be financed in 1991-92, plus another $1 billion in further payments into Commonwealth superannuation funds, plus another $2 billion to offload some of the treasury note financing built up this year, 1991. That gives a total of $9.5 billion to be found, and that is on the basis of a balanced Budget next year-no surplus, no deficit.

As I said earlier, it now seems almost certain that on the basis of the existing Hawke Government policies, the 1991-92 Budget will be heavily in deficit and, therefore, make an even greater call on our domestic monetary markets; that is, on our national savings.

Even if we discount this Budget deficit probability completely, there will still be a heavy Commonwealth Government call on the longer end of the market next year. The $5 1/2 billion bonds maturing this year are now one year or less stock, whereas the new issues to replace this maturing debt will have three year or longer maturity dates. Therefore, it is clear that the Government will be competing fiercely with the private sector for funds and, in turn, there will be government induced upward pressure on bond rates and, therefore, the whole interest rates structure next financial year.

Continuing lax fiscal policy resulting in the re-emergence of Commonwealth Budget deficits will simply compound this problem. We have seen in the Loan Bill today the result of the massive deterioration in the Government's Budget. If there had not been this deterioration, then there would have been no need for the Government to be seeking the authority to borrow, which this Bill authorises. Until recent weeks it did not foresee the need to do such a borrowing.

It is absolutely essential that the Government gets the wheels back on to its Budget cart; all four wheels have fallen off at this stage. If it does not get those wheels back on to the Budget cart, then the pressures of inflation, renewed interest rates, undesirable exchange rate movements, and all the things that flow from that, will sweep away completely even the very limited advances made in yesterday's industry statement. There was no reference at all to macro-economic policy in yesterday's industry statement. I believe that it was a major deficiency in that statement. Unless the Government gets its macro-economic policy back into shape, nothing it will do in other areas will count one iota.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate today is discussing the Loan Bill 1991. This is the first Loan Bill to be debated since the 1987-88 financial year. The absence of a loan Bill during the intervening years reflects the fact that the Commonwealth has been running substantial surpluses. However, the technical necessity for this Bill is not strictly related to whether the Budget is in surplus or deficit, rather it is necessary to balance a projected deficit in the Commonwealth Consolidated Revenue Fund. That fund is created by the Australian Constitution under section 81 and all revenues raised or received by the Government must be deposited in that account, which is part of the public account.

SPEECH.PARA: The other funds in the public account are the Loan Fund, to which this Bill is addressed, and the Trust Fund. In any one year, it is possible that the Consolidated Revenue Fund can be in deficit at the end of a particular year even though a Budget surplus is forecast. Such is the case this year due to the recession, but since this is not allowed to occur as the fund must always balance at the end of the financial year, this Bill provides for certain payments, which would have been made from the Consolidated Revenue Fund, to be made instead from the Loan Fund.

Clause 5 of the Bill specifies that the expenditure to be made from the Loan Fund is defence expenditure; that is, any defence expenditure otherwise authorised by parliament which is incurred after the Bill receives royal assent may be made from the Loan Fund rather than the Consolidated Revenue Fund thereby reducing or eliminating any deficit which may otherwise occur in that account.

The reason defence expenditure is used to effect the appropriation is twofold: firstly, the defence budget is always large-the Australian Democrats believe that it is too large-and, secondly, and most importantly, clause 4, which grants the Treasurer the right to borrow money necessary to finance the expenditure authorised by clause 5, avoids the necessity for obtaining the approval of the Loan Council for the borrowings for defence purposes, which could be politically embarrassing. It should be noted that the expense of borrowing is also authorised to be defrayed by the funds so raised. This is a standard provision and not opposed.

Part 3 of the Bill-clauses 6 and 7- authorises the Treasurer to borrow money to supplement any deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund which may arise. It is not yet certain whether this authority will be necessary. All such moneys are to be applied to the Consolidated Revenue Fund except for that amount relating to the expense of borrowing.

As with the borrowing for defence purposes, the borrowings may be raised either by the issuing of securities to the public or to the Reserve Bank or by the investment of trust fund balances in such securities. The Minister may be in a position to tell the Senate which of these options is to be used-if this has been determined. Any borrowings under part 3 must be authorised by the Loan Council. I now turn to the reason for the Bill's presence before the Senate; it is simple. The Government's fiscal position has been eroded because of the recession it has engineered. The Opposition's second reading amendment addresses this issue, and I will deal with our response to it later.

The surplus was estimated by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) at Budget time last year at $8.1 billion. The Democrats policy was that the surplus should have been at least 1 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) higher, that is, an additional $3 billion to allow an immediate 3 per cent cut in interest rates in an attempt to avoid our current recession. The Democrats have certainly constantly opposed the use of monetary policy to curb demand because of the obvious disadvantages and inequity of targeting borrowers, which does not involve any capacity to pay; the destructive effects on business, which we have all witnessed in the past year or so; and the resulting appreciation of the currency, which tends to favour imports relative to exports. Unfortunately we were right.

On 22 February, the Treasurer announced that the projected surplus for 1990-91 would be only $1.7 billion. This is far below the prior rough estimates by the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) of a surplus of about $4 billion. The $6.4 billion erosion is made up of an estimated $3,870m decrease in projected receipts and increased spending of $2,535m. The details are as follows: amongst the revenue losses are $2,800m less taxes and other receipts which will be collected because of declining employment and reduced spending; $640m because of higher than expected tax refunds, emanating from lower incomes and financial losses; and $430m from the November wage tax trade-off, which all members of this Parliament supported. Clearly, paragraph (a) of the Opposition's second reading amendment is correct. The second paragraph identifies the extra spending which will be undertaken this year as a result of the Government's economic mismanagement.

The extra spending or deficit not budgeted for is, firstly, $750m because the Senate would not accept the Government's proposals to privatise the Moomba-Sydney gas pipeline, and rightly so; secondly, the Senate's refusal to allow the Government to push through its legislation on the assets test on family allowances, and again rightly so; $400m in extra unemployment benefits; $280m caused by the Gulf war in defence expenditure increases and wheat industry compensation payments; and $275m which relates to the wool industry assistance. Farmers have been abandoned by both the Government and the Opposition, but that much at least is due to them.

An amount of $750m relates to expenditure for natural disaster relief-for example, the Newcastle earthquake, the disastrous floods in eastern Australia, and the large number of bushfires-and pensions. Clearly, the expenditure items as such could not justifiably be opposed, but in the strategic overall sense the need for most of these was indeed created by the Government's mistaken economic strategy and, as a result, the Australian Democrats will be supporting the Opposition's second reading amendment.

The Democrats propose that the Government should increase outlays now to alleviate some of the unemployment it has caused. Australia is in desperate need of improved public infrastructure in such areas as water, sewerage, railways, ports, public transport and public housing. We also need a much greater retraining program to avoid large increases and long term unemployment--

TALK.START.PARA: —More taxes.

—These are matters that we have put on record in our response to the industry statement and in our alternative Budget, Senator Kemp. We have identified the additional taxes that could be raised if this Government had the political will and if the Opposition were in support of them-taxes which would raise, for instance, some $600m from incomes above $100,000 per annum. But unfortunately neither the Government nor the Opposition has the political will or the guts to attack their wealthy friends. There is little point in continuing this debate. It is quite clear that the Hawke Government has mismanaged our economy and has engineered a recession under which we are now suffering and for which taxpayers are footing the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Loan Bill 1991 which is before the chamber. I was pleased to hear the comments from Senator Spindler of the Australian Democrats; they are proposing to support the amendment that Senator Short has moved to this Bill and which, amongst other things, condemns the gross financial mismanagement of this Government. I was sorry to hear Senator Spindler say that the Australian Democrats will be continuing to pursue the policies they have put forward before this chamber which, frankly, is basically more government spending and more government taxes. I would have to say, given the financial disaster which this country is now facing, the last thing we need, Senator Spindler, is billions of dollars more in spending. Given the struggles of individual families and people who are running the business enterprises of this country, and the struggles that our farmers are having --
—You like to speculate.

—The last thing they need is more of the Democrats taxes. I think it is bold of Senator Spindler to come out and say he would like to have wealth taxes; that he wants to have capital gains taxes; that he believes the marginal rates of taxes are too low. It is a bold policy, one I would have to say which would be accepted by a minuscule number of people in this country. I think when he talks in general terms about the sorts of taxes he wants to raise in this community, the Australian Democrats should be very specific and inform people that what they are talking about is significantly higher taxes on Australian families and businesses.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a great pity, given the concerns that Senator Spindler raised about tax avoidance, that the one proposal which we would have hoped the Australian Democrats would have supported is the proposal of Dr Hewson for a goods and services tax which would have the effect of picking up the `black' economy in this country and cutting down on the very high levels of tax avoidance which can occur.

The fiscal policy of this Government has collapsed. There is no greater evidence of it than the Bill we currently have before the chamber. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) are now forced to borrow funds to cover the Budget shortfall which is now emerging at a frightening level.

We can recall in this chamber that the Budget surplus for 1990-91 was forecast by Mr Keating at $8.1 billion. Just seven months later, his surplus has virtually disappeared. The latest estimate we have from the Government is that over $6 billion has been lost from the surplus and that the current surplus is now forecast at only $1.7 billion. Mr Keating, in a rare display of frankness and honesty, has said that the Budget may even go into deficit.

The reason we have this Bill before us is that the Government's collapse in Budget revenues has forced the Government to return to the money markets to seek further borrowings. It has to be said that this Government, under Mr Keating's management of the economy, has a notorious record for failing to meet key Budget targets. Time and time again we have seen in the Budgets that Mr Keating has brought down failures to meet his targets on inflation, failures to meet targets on productivity and failures to meet targets on balance of payments. I am afraid that it has to be said that despite this incredible record of budgetary failure under Mr Keating, the 1990-91 Budget is really the mother of all Budget failures.

Just look at the statements which were made by Mr Keating just seven months ago when he brought down his eighth and hopefully last Budget. Senator McMullan is at the table and it is quite possible that he is trying to block out of his memory the truly incredible Budget Speech that Mr Keating brought down just seven months ago. It makes very bad reading today. I will just refresh the memory of the chamber about some of the statements that Mr Keating made in August last year about his Budget. This is what he said last August:
The faith the Australian people exhibited in the Government at the election is now being repaid as the economy adjusts to a sustainable rate of growth without a catastrophic collapse.
This year inflation will fall further, the current account deficit will markedly improve and employment will pick up.
In short, the kind of outcome the Government was seeking, delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.

Does Senator McMullan remember those comments that were made just seven short months ago? Now we have this statement before us and the previous comments by the Treasurer that we are in the midst of probably the heaviest and most savage recession since the 1930s. There is no comment in this Budget statement about the planned recession that we had to have. Remember that statement that Mr Keating then told us? There was no hint to the Australian public just seven months ago. Mr Keating went on to say in his Budget Speech last year that this Budget:
. . . builds on the fiscal achievements secured to date and maintains fiscal policy as the Government's principal weapon in the fight against the current account deficit and our overseas debt.

What happened to the principal fight against the mounting foreign debt in this country, because the fiscal policy outlined in this Budget has collapsed catastrophically? Then Mr Keating went on to say:
With a surplus of over $8 billion-
what a vain boast that appears to be today-
the fourth successive Budget surplus-it provides Australia with a period of sustained budgetary discipline unprecedented in its history.
It adds this further $8 billion to national savings to cut the call on overseas savings and hence overseas debt.
If that gross overstatement was not sufficient, Mr Keating then continued:
But not only does its rectitude provide an advantageous bottom line,-
that was the $8 billion which has now gone west-
it also underpins the fairest array of Commonwealth spending policies in the history of the Federation.

This is the Budget brought down in August last year which has now totally collapsed. The sad thing is that the Australian people-at least a sufficient number of them-believed Mr Keating, Mr Hawke, maybe Senator McMullan and maybe the Ministers in this chamber when they went around in the last election assuring people that there would be no recession. How many Labor people went around and gave assurances in their electorates? We certainly heard Mr Hawke and Mr Keating almost day by day during the election period assuring people that Dr Hewson was wrong in saying that the Australian economy was facing a severe recession. They said Dr Hewson was wrong in saying that the fundamental issues in the economy were not being addressed. So our Labor colleagues remember all that?

Well, what happened was that the Labor Government squeaked back into office on the basis of that big lie. It was a big lie because there was enough evidence around at that time-certainly available to the Liberal Party and there was no reason to believe that it would not have been available to the Australian Labor Party-that Australia was heading rapidly downhill.

I have read the bold boasts by Mr Keating in the last Budget about the financial rectitude of the Budget and being the fairest Budget since Federation, but there was not a hint about engineering a recession or the recession that we had to have. One would have to say on reflection, and I think Senator McMullan at the table would probably agree with this: how foolish and arrogant Mr Keating's Budget Speech now seems.

Just last night, Mr Hawke decided to eat some humble pie. One can remember, and perhaps this is a fair analogy, that it took Mr Hawke some years to admit that his promise that no Australian child would live in poverty was not kept. That was the big lie of the 1987 election. The big lie of the 1990 election was that there would be no recession. Mr Hawke maintained that position until it was no longer sustainable even for a man with a hide as thick as our Prime Minister has. So last night Mr Hawke-I quote from his statement-said:
. . . the recession has hurt many people and cost many jobs, and that is something I regret deeply.
He went on:
The Australian economy is currently at or near the bottom of a downturn that has been sharper, deeper and more prolonged than we anticipated.

I do not know whether it should be `we anticipated' or `we were not prepared to admit'. I suspect that the real truth of the matter is that the Government was well aware of the catastrophe which was befalling Australia, but it simply was not prepared to admit it.

The apology of Mr Hawke last night is probably but little consolation to those Australians who are now losing their businesses, losing their homes and losing their jobs as a result of Mr Hawke's and Mr Keating's gross misjudgments on the economy. It was these people who undoubtedly remember more clearly than most the central promise of Mr Hawke in the last election that there would be no recession.

Dr Hewson, in his reply to the Budget Speech given last August by Mr Keating, said that the Prime Minister and his Treasurer were clearly out of touch with the state of the Australian economy. Dr Hewson said this:
The Hawke-Keating Government has no idea of the extent of the recession in the private sector in Australia nor of the hardship being experienced by the great bulk of Australians.

Dr Hewson warned that the high interest rate policy of the Government was pushing the private sector into recession. Seven months down the track Mr Keating, Mr Hawke and Senator Button have all had to admit that Dr Hewson was correct and that they were wrong.

Mr President, you may recall that on Monday in this chamber Senator Button conceded that interest rates had been kept too high for too long. It was a great pity that Mr Hawke and Mr Keating did not listen to the advice given by Dr Hewson and Peter Reith many months ago. It would have saved many Australians great pain and suffering. The main reason this Budget has collapsed and the Government now has to return to the money market for funds is the recession-the recession, I remind my colleagues, which Mr Keating initially said that we would not have, then said that we had to have it; and then he said that it was unfortunate this disaster had occurred.

Senator Button has conceded, as has Mr Hawke, that the recession was a dreadful mistake. Had Mr Keating a thread of decency, he would accept responsibility for the disaster which has befallen the Australian economy-the most savage recession since the 1930s-and he would resign. We know, as we have seen from the behaviour of Mr Keating over a long period of time, that he does not seem to possess that sense of responsibility and decency that marks a strong leader. He does not seem to feel any remorse at all for the untruths he has told the Australian public. In my mind, he is devoid of the principles which should guide our leadership.

In the circumstances, Mr Hawke really has no option but to sack Mr Keating. I think we can recall the visit of Mr Keating to the Ford factory in Geelong before Christmas. Mr Keating spoke to some workers there who were not very pleased with him. One of these workers had the temerity to come up to our Treasurer and complain about the effects his policies were having on his home and his job prospects. What did Mr Keating say? Do honourable senators remember that famous statement? He said, `Disappear, pal.' That is what Mr Keating said to the Ford worker-`Disappear, pal.'

TALK.START.PARA: —And he is going to.

—Yes, regrettably, as a result of this Government's policies and as a result of Mr Keating's mismanagement of the Australian economy, many Ford workers and indeed many workers in many factories around the country will see their jobs go. To pick up that theme, the Australian public want Mr Hawke to say to Mr Keating, `Disappear, pal'. That is what they want but, Mr President, you know, I know and Senator McMullan and all the other senators over there know that that will not happen. Senator Walsh occasionally gives us great insight into the workings of the Labor Party, and he described the Prime Minister as-remember this?-Old Jellyback. Old Jellyback will not have the guts to stand up for proper principles and to sack the man whose economic mismanagement of this country is causing such suffering and distress. I have to say, and I think many Australians would agree with me, that Mr Hawke's apology for the recession last night would have sounded more sincere had Mr Keating, the man who has caused the loss of so many jobs of other people, finally lost his job.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to conclude by making this prediction: if the Government does not change its Treasurer and does not change its economic policies, we will have many Bills brought before this chamber, as we have today the Loan Bill 1991, requiring further borrowings. I urge the Government to reflect again on the collapse of its fiscal policy, admit responsibility for the economic failure which has so devastated this country, and start to take the fundamental decisions which will address the real issues in this economy, which the Government so notably failed to address last night.

One of Senator Peter Baume's most enduring achievements was his contribution to the development and articulation of Liberal philosophy. In the book Australian Liberalism: The Continuing Vision, which sets out the evolution of liberalism in this country from Alfred Deakin at the time of federalism through to the present, Peter Baume reaffirms the importance of the individual when he writes:

Our problems are best solved by a redistribution of power-``away from the Government and back to individuals, and this can only be achieved by stating and restating our fundamental liberal commitment to the maximum liberty of each person''.
This philosophy is very much in line with that of Sir Robert Menzies, who, at the founding of the Liberal Party in 1944, said:
I see the individual and his encouragement and recognition as the prime motivating force for building of a better world.

It was such a speech that first attracted me to the Liberal Party. Turning on the radio one evening in 1958, I heard Robert Menzies deliver a speech at the opening of a poultry farmers' conference. The occasion was very ordinary, but the speech was extraordinary. This eloquent man outlined with such grace his vision for Australia and there was I, a boy with a bad stutter recovering from the effects of polio, totally intrigued, listening and drawn to the Liberal vision of an Australia built on a deep respect for the dignity and the freedom of the individual, of an Australia where one could be rewarded for effort and where enterprise would be encouraged, and of an Australia where there is real equality of opportunity and choice.

If one were to try to encapsulate this philosophy in one phrase it would be that the success of the community depends upon the success of the individual. The Australia in which I grew up in the 1950s and 1960s seemed to be the manifestation of this philosophy. When I look back, these seem to have been the golden years of Australia. Then we had the third highest standard of living in the world. Australia Felix was the slogan; Australia unlimited. And why not? Then, unemployment stood at between one and 2 per cent; inflation fluctuated between 3 and 4 per cent; and interest rates were at 6 1/2 per cent. Do honourable senators remember those figures? As for overseas debt, we tended to have a surplus.

I cannot recall any Liberal Treasurer in Australia's golden age claiming to be the world's greatest, although the Liberals' records stand high in stark contrast to what has happened to our economy during the past eight years. Australia in the 1980s and 1990s has become enmeshed in a deadly thicket of high overseas debt, inflation, interest rates, unemployment and now recession-the one that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) claims to have masterminded but which he really generated because of a completely inappropriate economic policy mix.

Over the past eight years the Hawke Government has made a number of fundamental errors in the direction of economic policy. What it should have been doing was getting the economic policy settings right to solve our underlying economic problem, which is our failure to produce sufficient goods and services. The top priority of the Hawke Government should have been to boost productivity. Instead, we have been focusing mainly on demand management and discouraging expenditure through a regime of high interest rates.

We have seen the effects of that. Last week Senator Button in one of his refreshing bursts of candour admitted that we were heading towards our third quarter of negative growth. Australia is going backwards, and out in the suburbs and down on the farm people are suffering. Living standards in this country are about to decline dramatically. The ones who will be most affected are the most defenceless: the young and the unskilled.

The December unemployment figures reveal that 25 per cent, one-quarter, of our youth are without jobs. In my home city of Newcastle this figure is 30 per cent-one in three. Apart from the human misery that this creates, it is also a waste of a resource that is vital to the recovery of this country. Perhaps the Treasurer should come to Newcastle and explain to the scores of families without breadwinners and the legion of unemployed youth why we had to have this recession. Of course, he will not, because he realises that he has made a major policy error: interest rates were too high for too long.

In its fourth term, the Hawke Government has finally stumbled upon the correct economic path-micro-economic reform. At last it is starting to focus upon the supply side of the economic equation and is belatedly trying to boost productivity. This begs the question: why did the Government not do this during its first term? The so-called micro-economic reform agenda is a half-hearted attempt to get the country back on the right economic track. The tragedy for Australia is that here we have a country rich in resources but without a proper economic structure to take care of it.

On Australia Day we sing, `This land abounds in nature's gifts of beauty rich and rare'. One would be forgiven for wondering how a nation which started out with such hope and with so much natural wealth and, at the time of Federation, had the highest per capita income in the world could reach a point in the last quarter of the twentieth century where it could no longer pay its way in the world. We cannot allow our national debt to continue to climb at $1 billion to $2 billion a month. The Labor Government now breathes a sigh of relief if the debt goes up by only $1 billion a month. Our total net foreign debt at the end of 1990 stood at $130 billion; that is, $7,500 for each man, woman and child. This cannot be sustained.

To understand how we got ourselves in this economic mire, I want to look closely at a region in my State of New South Wales which in a concrete way is indicative of what is wrong with the Australian economy. Like Australia as a whole, the Hunter Valley is rich in resources. In fact, it is the richest valley in Australia. I know it well because I have lived there for the past 19 years. I am very proud to be the first Liberal senator from that region.

To put the magnitude of the wealth of the area in some sort of perspective, let me provide the Senate with some relative comparisons between the Hunter region and the nation as a whole. The economic resource base of the Hunter is massive. With only 3 per cent of the population, the Hunter produces almost 5 per cent of the gross domestic product of this nation. It produces one-third of the nation's coal and half of that is exported; one-third of the aluminium; one-third of the electricity; and one-quarter of the crude steel production. The Hunter's port handles more cargo than any other in Australia.

In addition to the Hunter's massive contribution to rural and secondary industry, over 70 per cent of the population is employed in the tertiary sector. The area serves as the northern administrative headquarters for private and public sector organisations. The Hunter has one of the finest universities in the nation, with over 12,000 students in a very wide range of faculties. I had the privilege of serving on its faculty of education.

I first moved to the Hunter region 19 years ago, and with my family I have explored this wonderfully diverse region. We have hiked through the subtropical rainforest below Barrington Tops. We have gone white-water rafting on the Chichester River. We have camped on the beautiful broadwater at Mungo Brush. We have fished-somewhat unsuccessfully-at Fishing Point on beautiful Lake Macquarie, the third largest salt water lake in Australia. We have strolled along the redeveloped foreshores of Newcastle Harbour listening to the jazz bands with the local people on a Sunday afternoon.

Over half a million people live in the Hunter. It is an area rich in human resources as well as natural resources. The strength and character of its people were demonstrated 15 months ago when it was hit by the worst natural disaster in our history: an earthquake measuring 5.5 on the Richter scale ripped through the city-our sixth largest-killing 14 people and creating billions of dollars worth of damage. The destruction cost was greater than that wrought by Cyclone Tracy in 1974 when it flattened Darwin.

In my own home the building whipped around; the children screamed and were flung to the floor. In the city, the huge Newcastle Workers Club collapsed, killing people; in the suburb of Hamilton the shop facades crashed to the ground, creating more loss of life. Historic buildings were fractured and later had to be torn down. Within five seconds that morning, lives were lost and billions of dollars worth of damage occurred. The response of the people of Newcastle was magnificent. In the true spirit of Aussie mateship people really helped each other to put their lives and their properties back together. Fifteen months after the quake, the work still goes on as the city is rebuilt.

The Hunter is a magnificent region with magnificent people and, more than any other, it pulls its economic weight in this country. We generate 50 per cent more gross domestic product per capita and 90 per cent more exports per capita than the Australian average. But just as the 1980s and 1990s have seen a slide from the golden era for Australia, so too in the Hunter. Like Australia, the Hunter could have done far better, especially if governments over the past 90 years had not neglected the area.

A report released three weeks ago by the Hunter Economic Development Council outlined the New South Wales Liberal Government's economic strategy for the region over the next 20 years. This excellent document targets 30 key industries in the Hunter where there are private business opportunities, including defence and aerospace, bio-related technology, energy related enterprises, education exports, leisure and sports, recycling, the wine industry and tourism.

The document also highlights what the Government needs to do in terms of upgrading infrastructure to provide the base on which industry can build. What is greatly hampering the enormous economic potential of the Hunter is that these facilities are not in place now. Government neglect here is really an analogy of what is wrong with Australia as a whole and why we are constantly struggling as we produce less than we consume.

The strategy document highlights the need to develop the Williamtown air base as a proper international tourist destination, with upgraded access to places such as the vineyards and Port Stephens. But, instead of going forward with vision over the last 10 years in terms of services, the area has gone backwards. Ten years ago one could fly from Newcastle to Canberra by jet. Now, when I fly from here on Friday, I leave on a small propeller-driven plane in the middle of the day-most senators will know the flight-and when I get into Sydney I wait for an hour and a half at the airport. I then catch an even smaller plane, with even smaller propellers, to fly to Newcastle. This neglect is not confined to Newcastle. The airport facilities around Australia need enormous extra expenditure to upgrade them. Sydney is waiting on the third runway. The annual cost of that in lost tourism and economic potential is $2 billion.

Even if we upgraded the facilities of Williamtown, there would still be major problems because of the lack of adequate road links. The main highway that runs north of Newcastle, the so-called Newcastle-Sydney expressway, ends 15 kilometres west of the city at the moment in a confused tangle of substandard roads. This main road was started 30 years ago and it was to be the link to Newcastle, the Hunter, northern New South Wales and Queensland. But we are still waiting for it to be finished. It is still 15 kilometres short of linking up with the rest of the road system. It would be a very game overseas tourist who would try to find his way to the airport, Port Stephens or the vineyards through this road maze. It has been like this for three years; it will be like it for at least another three.

Despite the fact that the Government takes half of our money at the petrol pump in the form of taxes, it really has not spent the money on roads. We really have a Third World road system in this country. Four years ago I drove on the roads in the United States-what a contrast! One American actually abused me about the state of our roads. He had actually tried to drive around Australia. He was an extremely brave man. The poor state of our roads, apart from killing thousands of Australians each year, adds between 10 to 20 per cent to the costs of our transport, making us even less competitive in the world marketplace.

When a driver with a semitrailer load of exports eventually reaches port, after tackling the substandard roads, to unload it on to ships, he faces a whole new range of problems on our waterfront. Australian ports are considered by the rest of the world to be a joke-the epitome of inefficiency. Reform is moving at a snail's pace. Overseas, our major trading partners are reforming their waterfronts at a much faster pace. We continue to slip further behind. Of course, when our semitrailer driver arrives at the port of Newcastle, which in terms of tonnage of cargo is the largest in Australia, he probably will not be able to send his load anywhere because of the lack of general cargo handling facilities. The Hunter region economic development strategy has targeted the upgrading of the port to enable it to handle container terminals for the Asia-Pacific trade as the second highest priority after upgrading Williamtown.

I have outlined only three of the many ways in which a region of proven economic performance, and even greater economic potential, has been stunted in its growth by government neglect over many years. Even when the Government has had an opportunity to direct resources to the city, it has not done so, taking its very traditional Australian Labor Party vote for granted. Until 1988 and the advent of the Greiner Government in New South Wales, the people of the Hunter sent to Canberra and to Sydney, Labor members of parliament for most of the century. This bred political complacency and the results were disastrous for the Hunter. The Royal Australian Navy submarine contract, worth $4.6 billion, went to Adelaide, not to Newcastle. Perth pinched a $99m offshore gas platform from Newcastle. The frigate contract worth $4.3 billion went to Melbourne, not to Newcastle, despite a promise to the Hunter yards that they would get a quarter of the work; as yet, not one dollar has actually come into the region. One of our most productive and innovative shipyards, Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd, has just gone into receivership because of a lack of work. This is a matter I intend to pursue in this Parliament.

Not giving the region its fair share of contracts is one thing, but deliberately denying contracts to the Hunter is quite another. Having missed the opportunity for decentralisation by not sending the lucrative submarine and frigate projects to a regional city, the Hawke Government generated outrage in the city and in its own Labor Party when it decided to keep the Australian Maritime Safety Authority in Canberra, instead of doing what it promised before the election-to send it to Newcastle. It was Labor's own Minister for Land Transport, Bob Brown, who said:
I emphasise that the decision to locate the Authority in Newcastle was based on objective reasons. Newcastle was the best location.

However, the decision was reversed by a new and inexperienced Minister who was hoodwinked by the people in his department. The snow job blew out the costs of the move from Canberra to Newcastle, originally estimated at $6.7m, to $14.7m, which included a four-day visit to Newcastle for all 211 staff and their families, whether they intended to move to Newcastle or not, and an item of $19,200 for moving family pets. It was an episode worthy of Yes, Prime Minister. In fact, I think the Department based its stratagem on the `Man Overboard' series in which Jim Hacker PM tries to relocate some of the armed forces to the north of England. Do honourable senators remember the story? The field marshal made it very clear that one could not ask senior officers to live permanently in the north. When Jim Hacker asked why, he was given the following reasons: `Their wives would not stand for it', `Wimbledon is not in the north; nor is Harrods, nor is Ascot, not to mention the Army and Navy Club'. In the end, the inexperienced Minister lost, Jim Hacker lost and the armed forces stayed in the south of England-and England hypothetically, lost economic gain.

Likewise, our Australian Maritime Safety Authority stayed in Canberra-on Lake Burley Griffin, 200 kilometres from the sea. Imagine how well the Hunter region might be doing now if it had received its fair share of government expenditure and contracts. The billions of dollars that might have been ours would have created a major boom. I am sure that they would have been ours if we had had more political vision in this nation, or if we had been fortunate enough to have been an island like Tasmania.

I hasten to assure all Tasmanians that I am in no way denigrating Tasmania. I simply want to illustrate to this chamber, especially the 12 honourable senators from Tasmania, how location and government neglect stretching back over 90 years has stunted the economic development of the Hunter and, because of its economic importance to Australia, stunted the development of the whole nation.

Imagine, if you will, that the Hunter valley was an offshore island, approximately 240 kilometres off the coast-the same distance as Tasmania is from the mainland. If we now consider a comparison between `Hunterland', as we might call the island, and Tasmania, we would find that Hunterland has a population of over half a million compared to Tasmania's 450,000. The Hunterland capital of Newcastle is twice the size of Tasmania's capital of Hobart. In addition, Hunterland's gross domestic product and its contribution to export income in Australia are greater than those of Tasmania. Yet Tasmania is a State in control of its own affairs, with a State Parliament and Tasmania is fully represented in this chamber with 12 senators. The Hunter now has one.

During my term in this Parliament I pledge myself to fight for the Hunter, a region which, if treated properly, could reach its full potential as an economic powerhouse for New South Wales and for the whole of Australia. With its vast wealth and contribution to export income, it could play a major role in leading our nation out of its economic morass.

Although I represent all of the people of New South Wales, I will be focussing much of my work in the north, in its largest population centre where half a million people have been under-represented in this Parliament. In doing so, I am following in a great tradition established before my arrival by my two New South Wales colleagues: Senator Bronwyn Bishop, who has set up her office in the west of Sydney which has a population bigger than the city of Adelaide, and Senator Michael Baume, who has set up his office in the twin steel city of Wollongong. Together we will help redress the balance of representation in this Parliament and provide a fair go for three major regions which, over the years, have been victims of Government neglect.
Honourable senators -Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Returning to the second reading debate on the Loan Bill 1991, any intelligent person, assuming the integrity of the August Budget, could never have envisaged the speed at which the economy would deteriorate and, at the same time, the speed at which the surplus would evaporate. The speed at which the surplus is evaporating is the reason we have this Loan Bill before us today.

SPEECH.PARA: In that Budget we had a projected surplus of $8.1 billion. The Bill before us today seeks to give the Government funds to meet the present budgetary shortfall, and perhaps a lot more. This shortfall is occurring between the moneys appropriated by Parliament in the Budget and the funds available through the Consolidated Revenue Fund to meet those appropriations.

Usually, a Bill of this nature would be introduced into Parliament shortly after the Budget Appropriations Bills, if it was anticipated in the Budget that the Consolidated Revenue Fund would be in deficit. As we all know, the Government did not expect the Consolidated Revenue Fund to go into deficit this year. The hype at the time was about a soft landing. How wrong that hype was. We now have a very severe recession. As I mentioned, the only reason for having this Bill before us today is that the Budget in August failed to address our economically disastrous situation.

Today, we have before us a situation where in August last year the Government had a surplus of $8.1 billion. A few weeks ago the Treasurer (Mr Keating) estimated a surplus of $1.7 billion. Furthermore, since then, the Treasurer has indicated that there may be a deficit. As my colleague Senator Short said earlier, this decrease in the expected surplus has made a mockery of one of the central achievements forecast in the Budget-a Commonwealth surplus which the Treasurer said would ensure that Australia's public sector as a whole would be in balance.

I know that there are many reasons for this decrease in the surplus, the Gulf war being but one. The Government's outlays have increased beyond expectations. On the other hand, receipts have come in well below Budget forecasts. For example, in the months from July to December there is now an estimated gross shortfall of $2.4 billion. The worrying part of this shortfall is the large proportion of it which is due, or expected, from pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayers.

There is also a $93m decrease in sales tax. It is quite obvious that the strategy of the luxury car tax, which was a Budget gimmick-an accord, arrangement or carrot-was successful at the time for getting votes, but in the long term, as we predicted, was disastrously wrong. We do not want to say it, but at the time we told you so. If only this Government would listen a little more closely to what the Opposition has to say!

The Australian people have been deceived time and time again. I remind honourable senators of a statement made by the Hon. John Howard in the other place. He reminded that House of Ministers in the Australian Labor Party who have distorted and lied about the past, misrepresented the present and given false hopes about the future. That Budget document was widely acclaimed across Australia. How falsely that portrayed the real situation.

There are a number of questions that I think really need answering. That $2.4 billion deficit to date allegedly nets down, because of a number of factors, to perhaps $1,100m, about which there can be absolutely no dispute. Will this be recovered in subsequent months of the year? I think it is unfortunate that we do not have a Minister representing the Treasurer or his Parliamentary Secretary to answer these questions. I hope that they will be taken on board and answered later.

I remind the Senate of a question that I asked yesterday, and the response from Senator Button was that he would endeavour to get the answer as quickly as possible. We are still awaiting that reply. On 20 August we asked similar questions on taxation. We have been promised replies. They are still not forthcoming. What has the Government to hide in relation to taxation and its tax collections? Will this $1.1 billion adjusted shortfall wipe out the remaining vestiges of the proclaimed surplus? The Australian people need to know. What will be the estimated impact on the projected Budget surplus for 1990-91? It is indeed worrying.
The collection performances against the Budget goals have been so uneven in taxation offices across Australia. In fact, only three of the 16 offices have exceeded their Budget goals.

One of my hobbyhorses in this place has been the treatment of taxpayers by the Australian Taxation Office in what I have referred to as the slow gradation of their rights in the past five years. I have advocated, and still advocate, the need for a taxpayers' Bill of rights, and statements that continually come out of the Taxation Office reinforce, certainly on a regular basis, the need for that taxpayers' Bill of rights.

The uneven collection performance against Budget goals causes me to ask the Government a further question. Given the differences in approach-and the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) does not even have the decency to listen when I am posing these questions; he is talking on the telephone-can this Minister assure the Senate that all taxpayers are being treated with the same degree of fairness in implementing the laws? The minutes coming from the Taxation Office indicate that there is a wide variety in terms of implementation strategy and policy.

Could the Minister also outline the procedures that are being followed by the Australian Taxation Office to collect this shortfall from individual taxpayers who are indebted to the Australian Taxation Office? There needs to be a consistent policy from State to State and from office to office and that is not the case at the moment.

Why should taxpayers facing prosecution be treated differently in Sydney than in Melbourne? It is a Commonwealth-wide office. There are further questions that I think need to be asked. Is it correct that instructions have been given to the Australian Taxation Office to place even further pressure on PAYE collections? The uneven treatment is, indeed, worrying.

After the Government's Budget last August, Paddy McGuinness made the comment, `The Commonwealth Budget was the product of a treasurer and a government that have run out of ideas and no longer have the courage of their convictions'. The statement before us today reflects that run-down. In August, Mr Keating announced to Australians a Budget that would improve our balance of payments and result in an export driven economic recovery. In the press two weeks ago we were informed that the Treasurer's emphasis had now shifted from balance of payments to inflation. According to the Treasurer:

the extent (to which) we achieve and maintain a low inflation path we can diminish . . . our concern with the current account deficit because we will have more confidence that investments and savings decisions are rational and efficient.

In itself, that statement is quite okay. But it is interesting to note the change of emphasis and the change of trend to meet the problems that Mr Keating is meeting, changes for the purposes of expediency and convenience. The run-down of the original Budget surplus forecast of $8.1 billion to this announced $1.7 billion is again, according to Mr Keating, the key lever in his inflation first and then balance of payments strategy. Who is going to accept that as a sop, given the problems that we are facing at present? The only problem is that the probable run-down of the Budget surplus also has the possibility of becoming a Budget deficit, in which case the Commonwealth will return to the bond markets as a borrower for the first time since July 1989. It is interesting that the Government is of the opinion that this course of action is what is now needed to provide the stimulus to get investment and, subsequently, the economy growing again.

It is also interesting to note because previously one of the Hawke Government's economic objectives was to remove the Government as a competitor in the financial markets. The Government's logic then was that if it ran a surplus there would be more domestic money available for domestic investors so that they would not have to borrow funds from overseas. This action would not add to the current account deficit. If the Government now diminishes the surplus through this `recession we had to have' and becomes a borrower, the Government will have to go back to competing with industry for funds, thereby pushing up the price of those funds.

The Government's previous policy also included keeping wages down to get profit share growing so that companies could invest in and expand their businesses. Both policies were geared toward increased investment, which was supposed to lead to a higher standard of living. The Government actually did achieve its investment objective. It was a bit later than first predicted, but there was a boom. The labour market experienced strong employment growth, with the number of people in the work force at record levels. This positive economic situation, which the Government fostered with its policies, resulted in a surge in aggregate demand and often the demand could not be met by domestically produced goods, so the quantity of imports increased.

This increased demand for foreign funds to cover the investment plus the increase in imports led to a sharp rise in the current account deficit. The demand for products being as high as it was increased the inflation rate. The increased current account deficit, combined with the inflation increase, led the Government to slam on the brakes and the brakes were applied unilaterally in the form of monetary policy. The Government increased the interest rate rapidly over a short period as a disincentive to spending and investing.

I do not want to lecture the Government on its policies because I think the Senate is pretty familiar with the outcome. I think it is important to understand where we have come from in order to realise the mess into which this Government has now got the economy and that is reflected in the need to go out into the market and borrow and introduce today's Loan Bill. The Government's economic thinking has somehow come to the situation of a loan fund Bill to try and finance our economic ills. A further concern is whether we are in a recession at all or rather whether we are in a long term decline, as Geoffrey Lehmann recently pointed out in the Australian Business Magazine. That is perhaps of even greater concern. In Mr Lehmann's words, the:
word recession . . . implies that our problems are just the result of a cyclic downturn.

That is the notion that has been perpetrated by the Treasurer. We have heard all this before. Years ago it was called the J curve scenario. I remind this Senate that there is nothing cyclic about Australia's worsening current account deficit; there is nothing cyclic about this deterioration in the Budget surplus; and there is nothing cyclic in the deterioration that is occurring right across Australia in terms of lower standards of living, in terms of lost jobs and in terms of failed policies that this 12 March statement made such a pathetic attempt to rectify. Therefore, the Government really does need to address much more significantly our long term relative decline and not merely the current recession.

The Government's policies have led us to a situation where we need this Loan Bill before us now. The extent of the borrowing is the sixty-four dollar question that this Government has to answer. The Government has mismanaged the economy. Our Government Ministers and their advisers need to think much more clearly about measures to reverse the trends started in last year's Budget and giving rise to situations that demand a further borrowing, a borrowing that is manifest and needed through this loan fund. I ask the Government to reconsider its policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to the Loan Bill, I too seek to use it to further condemn the Government, as my colleagues have done. A loan Bill has been in the past a normal mechanism to allow for the balancing of the consolidated fund and it has been something which has been used in an ordinary and regular fashion as part of the bureaucracy. On this occasion, it is somewhat different. Since 1987, the Government has crowed from the top of its favourite hill that it has been a superb manager producing surpluses, which has meant that it has not needed the mechanism of a loan Bill in order to go out and raise further funds to keep that consolidated fund in balance.

SPEECH.PARA: When we had the Budget last year and we had the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tell us how we were looking forward to a wonderful anticipated surplus of $8.1 billion, many of us thought that it was an illusory figure and many of the people in the business community and the ordinary Australian population thought it was an illusory figure, but the Government proceeded to continue to skite that it was a real figure and that it, the Government, was in charge of the economy and the economy was in good shape. Already we had had the invasion of Kuwait, already we had had people starting to lose their jobs and already we had started to see small businesses go into bankruptcy and individuals go into bankruptcy. The signs were there that what the Treasurer finally came to acknowledge as an engineered recession, with all the levers pulled by him, was to fall upon us. We had already seen a decline in that surplus-indeed not a decline but ultimately almost its disappearance.

So we come to the Loan Bill, which is perhaps best described as yet another contrivance to be used by the Treasurer to get his hands on a bit more of the taxpayers' money. In this case he is going to go out and borrow money or get the authority to borrow money to enable the Commonwealth to be run in accordance with the law.

In the last couple of months we have seen the use of another mechanism, the Advance to the Minister for Finance; and we have seen in the last two months large applications for drawings against that fund, particularly with regard to payments to United Nations organisations, where, in the figures for January, there was a blow-out of some $3.3m of fees that were due and payable, due to currency fluctuations. But more particularly we had the large figure of some $45m concerning the blow-out in the Export Finance Insurance Corporation (EFIC) and that advance was sought pending the passage of Appropriation Bill (No. 3).

Appropriation Bill (No. 3) was brought forward in this place on the basis that the war had incurred additional expenditure and that it was necessary to deal with that Bill in the month of February. However, in the February applications for an advance from the Minister for Finance we saw yet another application for a further $22m worth for EFIC relating to wheat default payments, not subsequent or contingent upon being met from Appropriation Bill (No. 3) but simply a further drawing. In other words, when the Government put together the figures for Appropriation Bill (No. 3), it made a further error or omission or was simply incompetent in working out the necessary figures.

In 1988, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts was particularly concerned at the way in which the Advance to the Minister for Finance fund was used. Just to remind senators, this is an amount of money appropriated under the Appropriation Bills to enable provisions to be made for contingency amounts to be paid which in the parlance of the day were `urgent and unforeseen', and it was necessary that they meet both criteria.

The Public Accounts Committee was concerned that the way in which the fund was used was simply illegal because there were good examples of applications being made where somebody had simply made an error and left out of the estimates and out of the provision for appropriation certain sums of money which were obviously going to be necessary.

So the Public Accounts Committee made three recommendations, which were subsequently accepted by the Department of Finance, to make the fund be used in a more seen way and in accordance with the law. What happened was that there was virtually a new category created which dealt with erroneous or understated figures from the appropriation funds.

When one looks at the way in which the supporting documentation for a drawing on the Advance to the Minister for Finance is used-and, indeed, another recommendation of the Public Accounts Committee was that the supporting applications be made public so that the Senate can see exactly the grounds upon which the additional moneys are sought-one will find that the excuse or the reason still most often given, if not universally given, is `urgent and unforeseen'.

As one goes through, looking at the sorts of amounts required, in no way could one really say that they are perhaps truly meeting the Finance guidelines. I would suggest that the Department of Finance and indeed the Secretary and the Minister need to look more earnestly at the way some of those applications are coming forward.

The Loan Bill is simply a mechanism for allowing the law to be met. In normal times when proper administration of the economy takes place, it is of no particular moment and normally would not have any particular attention drawn to it. But it is particularly important in the context of the Budget that came down last August, which simply gave us a promise to impose substantial and sustained hardship for millions of Australians and their families. In the Budget we saw that there was an illusion of fiscal restraint but that in fact the expenditure cuts that were made were only about one-tenth of the expenditure cuts outlined in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan, which was the economic document that the Opposition used prior to the last election and which in fact would have been the basis of its first Budget, and we saw that we have a prognosis where the touted $8.1 billion surplus will undoubtedly fall as the private sector economy continues to slide and the revenue base is further eroded and activity related expenditure increases. The Opposition was able to see that the Budget was an illusory document, and in my own contribution to the debate on that Budget which I made on 8 November, I would perhaps remind the Senate, I used these words:

The Budget has already been totally discredited by unrealistic Budget assumptions. Saddam Hussein may have blown the Treasurer's prediction on oil prices out of the water, but he can blame no-one when his own figures on growth, unemployment and inflation have been inaccurate. The Treasurer's failure on the assumption has torn apart the Government's strategy on wages, interest rates and foreign debt.

Yet at that time the Government was still saying that the economy had not gone into a recession. The Treasurer was still claiming that he had got all the sums right. We had to progress further along until we finally got the admission that not only had the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) got it wrong but that the Treasurer had got it wrong; that the dole queues were lengthening at a frightening rate; that businesses were closing like never before; that ordinary Australian families were hurting badly; and that statistics were starting to reveal the true damage that the mismanagement of this Government had foisted upon the economy.

Over the last year we have seen the following: capital expenditure down 3.4 per cent; motor vehicle registrations down 10.6 per cent; dwelling approvals down 12.1 per cent; commercial finance commitments down 12.1 per cent; and job vacancies down 28 per cent. And it hits very hard in the west of Sydney, where ordinary Australian families are forced to struggle with the reality and the fallout of mismanagement.

But still we were hearing the ridiculous denials, and only the continued expressions of pain finally seemed to permeate the circle or the wall which the Prime Minister and the Treasurer had built around themselves. But when they finally admitted that they had got it wrong, did they apologise? Did they explain? Did they show remorse? No. There was simply an acknowledgment that they had failed.

Frankly, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) highlighted the plight they were facing. It was intended to appropriate funds significantly exceeding the resources appropriated by the Advance to the Minister for Finance which I mentioned previously-$234m, including $52m for equipment and stores on expenditure associated with deployment of the forces in the Gulf and $181m to meet the claims by the Australian Wheat Board associated with Iraqi defaults on credit sales. But the overwhelming bulk of the expenditure should have been considered and included at the time of the Budget.
My colleague in the other place Mr Alexander Downer, the shadow Minister for trade, in his response to the Budget said:

No provision was made in the Budget under the national export insurance scheme to cover this considerable debt, which could be claimed by the Australian Wheat Board if Iraq fails to meet its payments on time.

In other words, the Opposition was quite able to detect and to publish the fact that there were matters that simply had not been considered and ought to have been considered and included in the Budget and that the Budget itself was a farcical document and indeed in no way showed an accurate or indeed even an honest attempt to portray the economic reality of this nation. But the Government, of course, has not listened to the Opposition on this issue.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes:
(i) with gravest concern the contents of the so-called Westpac documents now before the Senate and incorporated into Hansard,
