(ii) the fact that these documents suggest that Westpac, Australia's largest private bank, through its subsidiary, Partnership Pacific Ltd. (PPL), in relation to its handling of foreign currency loans:
(a) abandoned its fiduciary obligation to its clients,
(b) took points and switched accounts to advantage the bank at the expense of clients,
(c) passed on withholding tax to clients which should rightfully have been paid by the bank or banks, and
(d) breached its obligation to the Reserve Bank by exceeding its limited entitlements to foreign currency holdings,
(iii) that the law firm, Allen Allen &Hemsley, conspired with PPL to obstruct just outcomes to clients disadvantaged by the above actions,
(iv) that on legal advice strong prima facie cases exist that Westpac through its subsidiary PPL:

(a) obtained financial advantage by deception as contained in Section 82 of the Victorian Crimes Act 1958, as amended, and which has been duplicated in the NSW Crimes Act 1990, as amended, and other relevant Acts, and
(b) committed related offences dealing with false accounting,

(v) further, in this regard, that a strong prima facie case exists that the author of the Allen Allen &Hemsley letters has committed a transgression of the criminal law relating to aiding and abetting a criminal offence and/or being an accessory after the fact of a criminal offence and being guilty of a conspiracy relating to these activities, and
(b) believes that these and other allegations concerning bank malpractice are of such gravity as to warrant a full judicial inquiry.

In moving this motion I draw attention to the fact that this is the first opportunity that the Parliament has had to discuss the infamous Westpac letters, which have attracted such widespread attention throughout the nation. I expect that the nation at large will be waiting to see how the Parliament reacts to this opportunity. I describe them as the infamous Westpac letters because I believe that the wording of my motion, which I will turn to in detail shortly, aptly describes them as exactly that.

I did a radio interview with Don Chipp not long ago. I said that I had a very large bone to pick with him because at the time that I came into this place as an Australian Democrats senator he told me what my role was-to keep the bastards honest-but he did not tell me how many there were. They are everywhere. Indeed, I found out not long after arriving in here as a Democrat senator, in joining my other colleagues, that we have a duty not to resile from the hard issues. This banking issue has proven to be a hard issue. We have not resiled from it. We do not do so now. We have put before the Senate in this motion the realities of what the Westpac letters actually mean, and we are calling upon the Senate to take its position in relation to those realities.

From the very beginning when these letters surfaced, Westpac went into panic mode in the extreme. There were a series of efforts made to deprive the public of knowledge of the contents of the documents. That involved claiming legal privilege. I have argued in this place that the documents do not attract legal privilege. I am not detracting from the importance of legal privilege as a process-namely, the right of individuals to present themselves to lawyers, to declare all and then to get confidential advice back-but if the lawyers go beyond the step of giving confidential advice about whether the law has or has not been broken and extend to the stage of actually saying how to avoid the outcomes of that breach of law, legal privilege, we would argue, does not apply.

There were widespread injunctions in an attempt to contain the publishing of these documents and even comment about the documents in the press. I have said at public gatherings recently that, if somebody had asked me five weeks ago to name a country where there was widespread corruption in the most powerful financial institutions in the land, where key witnesses before parliamentary inquiries found themselves intimidated before appearing before those inquiries, where the press was muzzled by processes of injunctions before the court and the threat of litigation emanating from those injunctions, and where the parliaments of the land were not able to or reluctant to debate significant documents revealing that corruption, I think that I would have said Chile or Nicaragua. Sadly, the answer today, on 13 March 1991, is Australia.

It is difficult to overestimate the significance of these documents. For that reason, they have rightly attracted enormous public attention. I believe that it has emerged that subsequent to the discovery and disclosure of these documents, in a variety of ways, there are two dimensions to the issue before the Senate today. The first is the obvious one of the disclosure and revelation of corruption in our most powerful financial institutions. That in itself should be sufficient to arrest the attention of the nation; in fact, it has done so. The second, and in some respects the most important, dimension to emerge is the one which relates to questions of the privacy of the Parliament: the very foundations and nature of our Constitution and the rights of individuals, and elected representatives especially, to come into parliaments with privilege, and the rights of those people to use those privileges in the public interest.

The editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald three or four days ago got it right when it said that we must not let the parliamentary dimension of this issue rest; that in fact there have been profound implications to flow from the revelations contained in these documents and how our parliaments and our courts have reacted to those revelations. But in the final analysis the Westpac documents are not about Mr Stuart Fowler, Managing Director of Westpac, on his salary package in excess of $2m per annum. They are not about senators like McLean, who have been pursuing the bank issue for 2 1/2 years-and the coincidental arrival of these documents which have allowed that issue to emerge in the true light of day is one which should attract the attention of the nation. They are not about those things; they are about the plight of ordinary, everyday Australians in the hands of the most powerful financial institutions in the land. They are about the plight of those people trying to take their circumstances into the courts of the land and get justice. It is those dimensions of these documents which make them of such primary importance and make it so vital that the Australian Parliament address them for what they are.

But there has been an extraordinary reluctance on the part of the Parliament to undertake that responsibility. We reluctantly have here tonight the opportunity of 1 1/2 hours of debate; half an hour of that is mine. I am wondering what the Government and the Opposition will do with their opportunity to debate these documents in the remaining hour.

I have been advised today that the documents have not yet been tabled in the other place. I have been advised today that as yet there will have been no opportunity for representatives elected to the other place to discuss those documents. I hope that this will not be the final outcome after all of the trauma that the nation has gone through, the courts have gone through and, indeed, this chamber has gone through. With those documents now before us, I hope that the final outcome will not be that the Federal Parliament of this land gives them an hour and a half of debate. That would be to lie down in front of the banks. That would be to confirm the statement made by Ansely Rothschild in 1801 when he said:
Allow me to control the credit of the land and I care not who makes the laws.

Ansely Rothschild in 1801 got the relative powers right. He acknowledged the fact that the banks are the most powerful institutions in the land; he acknowledged the relative powers between the banks and the law makers. It will be interesting to see what happens in our Parliament in response to what is revealed in these documents tonight.

I do not resile from the fact that I have brought before this chamber what I consider to be an extremely important motion. The motion is essentially in three parts. It is about abuse and corruption of a privileged position by Australia's most powerful private bank; it is about collusion, aiding and abetting of that process by Australia's most powerful law firm; and it is about what the Australian community should do in relation to those matters. I would like to take each aspect of the motion in turn. It states:
That the Senate-
(a) notes:
(i) with gravest concern the contents of the so-called Westpac documents now before the Senate and incorporated into Hansard,

(ii) the fact that these documents suggest that Westpac, Australia's largest private bank, through its subsidiary, Partnership Pacific Ltd (PPL), in relation to its handling of foreign currency loans:
(a) abandoned its fiduciary obligation to its clients,
(b) took points and switched accounts to advantage the bank at the expense of clients,
(c) passed on withholding tax to clients which should rightfully have been paid by the bank or banks, and
(d) breached its obligation to the Reserve Bank by exceeding its limited entitlements to foreign currency holdings,

I would like to address some comments to that aspect of the motion. These documents were suppressed for as long as they were because they are, in their own words, devastating in their condemnation of the behaviour of Australia's largest private bank-Westpac. `The bank you can bank on', is its slogan. These documents are incredible in their condemnation of the behaviour of that bank.

I will take the concept of the fiduciary obligation. The fiduciary obligation is not a difficult concept; it is simple. It says that the bank has the obligation of considering the interests of its clients equal to those of itself. That is its obligation in law. In the processes which are known as the so-called managed foreign currency loans, Westpac-and I would venture to suggest other major banks too; and I will suggest this to the bank inquiry on Friday-threw that to one side and ruthlessly, aggressively and effectively pursued profit-massive profit.

Do honourable senators know that one person, with one phone, in one day made $0.76m profit for Westpac? I will put the documents to verify that before the bank inquiry on Friday. One person, with one phone, in one day, made $750,000 which went into the coffers of Westpac. Do honourable senators know what money was used to make that profit-the money of people who innocently walked in the door and wanted to borrow from `The bank that you can bank on'. They just wanted to borrow money to buy a header to take wheat, to expand their business, or to do ordinary, normal things, and they were convinced by this bank that they should enter along a path which fundamentally is revealed in the documents known as the Westpac letters, the Belgium letters and subsequently the French letters. Subsequently, in hundreds of other documents that I will table before the bank inquiry on Friday, it was revealed that Westpac went about its own selfish business, exploited opportunity and en route actually did other things, but avoided paying taxes that it should have paid. It passed those taxes on to the poor, innocent victims who walked through the door. It deliberately exceeded its obligations to the Reserve Bank. It did all of these things in the pursuit of what has been described by another banker as super profits.

That bank and those who managed it in that stage should stand condemned for this behaviour which I argue, prima facie, on legal advice, was illegal, criminal behaviour. There are obligations upon the Treasurer and the Attorney-General to acknowledge the nature of that behaviour and to take the appropriate steps.

With the aid of the law firm Allen Allen and Hemsley, Westpac went further to devise ways and means of ensuring that those who had been victimised, if they could get into the courts and when they got into the courts, would not get justice. Westpac put in place a strategy, and that is the heading that is used in these letters to describe the steps that `The bank that you could bank on' would take to ensure that justice would not eventually be done. And justice has not been done. That is why these documents are devastating. They not only condemn the bank involved, but also condemn the law firm involved. I would like to move on to the second part of my motion. It states:
(iii) that the law firm, Allen Allen &Hemsley, conspired with PPL-
which I have earlier said was a subsidiary of Westpac-
to obstruct just outcomes to clients disadvantaged by the above actions,
(iv) that on legal advice strong prima facie cases exist that Westpac through its subsidiary PPL:

(a) obtained financial advantage by deception as contained in Section 82 of the Victorian Crimes Act 1958, as amended, and which has been duplicated in the NSW Crimes Act 1990, as amended, and other relevant Acts, and
(b) committed related offences dealing with false accounting,

(v) further, in this regard, that a strong prima facie case exists that the author of the Allen Allen &Hemsley letters has committed a transgression of the criminal law relating to aiding and abetting a criminal offence and/or being an accessory after the fact of a criminal offence and being guilty of a conspiracy relating to these activities, and
(b) believes that these and other allegations concerning bank malpractice are of such gravity as to warrant a full judicial inquiry.

I will come to the question of a royal commission in a moment. Let us look at the behaviour of the law firm. There are two Westpac letters: the first one essentially describes the management debacle or the mismanagement debacle that was known as the foreign loans or Swiss loans fiasco. It describes its magnitude in detail, but it then goes on to acknowledge the fact that the people who were victims of this process-it almost boasts that the victims of this process-will not be able to get just outcomes because they will not know, first of all, what a treasure-trove of information is available to them if they can get their hands on them; that is what they will not know. The second letter actually acknowledges that they will be so devastated by the outcomes of this experience, so destroyed financially, emotionally, maritally and domestically, that it is highly unlikely that many of them will respond anyway and, if they do, the costs of responding will be so massive that it is unlikely they will push right through to the High Court-the final court of appeal. They will not have the strength to do it. These documents actually say that.

They say to Westpac, `Don't panic. All will be well. These poor, weakened individuals will not be able to pursue a course of justice'. But they go further than that and say, `If they do, or if they show signs of doing so, or before they do, let's do certain things to them. Let's call them in and sweeten them with concessions'-that is what they are called; I would use the term `bribes' but in the letters they are referred to as concessions-`and in exchange for these concessions, let's extract from them exemptions from legal action, releases from legal action'. In some cases they actually extracted from them non-disclosure clauses-in other words, `We won't tell people what is happening. If we do, we will be breaking our agreement or our contract not to disclose what has happened to us'. This is actually suggested as a strategy by the law firm Allen Allen and Hemsley. That is aiding and abetting; that is being an accessory after the fact; that is a crime in this country.

If this Senate is not prepared to acknowledge it as a crime, if this Parliament is not prepared to accept it as a crime, if the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is not prepared to accept it as a crime and if the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) is not prepared to acknowledge it for what it is, we have got problems. Not only have we got a sick banking system but also we have a gutless parliament, and that means problems of enormous dimensions. I am waiting to hear what the Government and the Opposition in this place have to say about these problems. I would anticipate that they are likely to say that there is a bank inquiry in progress and to leave it in the hands of the bank inquiry. It has taken us 2 1/2 years to get a bank inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we had had one earlier--

—As Senator Powell says, if we had had one earlier perhaps we may have averted this immoral, incredibly arrogant behaviour on behalf of Australia's leading banks and lawyers. But we have one now. I would argue that that bank inquiry is under-resourced; it has the wrong terms of reference; and it does not have the expertise to render adequate analysis of the problem that is all of a sudden before it.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not doubt the efficacy of the inquiry at all; that is not the point. But only a royal commission will put before the Australian people in a non-politicised way the realities of this mess. The inquiry will eventually deliver to the Parliament a report which will be politicised in the same way as the evidence that I have brought into this chamber for 2 1/2 years has been politicised. Now it cannot be politicised any more because I do not believe the Australian people will allow that to happen. I think they will demand that this Parliament react to it objectively. I think they will be absolutely staggered if this Parliament does not give it any more than an hour and a half's debate. Frankly, I believe that they should be disgusted, they should be frightened, if this Parliament does not give it more than an hour and a half's debate eventually, but I might be premature in judging that. The words of Ansely Rothschild ring in my ears, `Give me the power to create credit and I care not who makes the laws of the land'. That should be ringing in the ears of every Australian.

I would like to spend a couple of moments on Mr Fowler's response to all this. He responded in two ways. He went before the bank inquiry in a special sitting last Thursday, withdrew all the injunctions and declared that Westpac was in a mood of cooperation, and that it had always been. He actually put together a statement which essentially was directed at me and said certain things that suggested that people like me were involved in a campaign timed to correspond with the commencement of the inquiry. What a stupid comment to make! Of course it was timed to correspond with the inquiry. He said that it had been conducted by certain journalists. Thank heavens for them-the brave journalists like the Ann Lampes of this world who were prepared to confront injunctions week after week, and who believe in a free press. Those people came together in the best interests of Australia.

Mr Fowler talked about interest groups. Do honourable senators know the interest group he is describing? It is the Foreign Borrowers Association, the people who were decimated by this process of greed. Of course they are an interest group. It would be impossible to imagine anybody who should have a more profound interest.

He said that others were prepared to traffic in stolen documents. `Traffic in stolen documents'-what an emotive phrase. I say to Mr Fowler: I do not know whether the documents are stolen or not. I could not care less whether they are stolen or not. I know they are authentic because the authenticity has never been challenged. I know what they say. They say what is in the motion before this chamber today.

I believe that I have an obligation to bring those documents into this place. What am I supposed to do-shred them, eat them? What are elected representatives supposed to do with documents like this? Trafficking in stolen documents! Do honourable senators know what these documents are about? They are about stolen money; moneys stolen from ordinary Australians and trafficked in foreign currencies in the most sophisticated and effective way. What hypocrisy!

Mr Fowler goes on to make equally empty observations but the gem is at the end. I do not know whether honourable senators saw him on the television and heard his closing line when he said, `The figures speak for themselves'. He highlighted the fact that there had been no bankruptcy notices issued and only 10 matters where action had been taken in respect of security, only three of which have resulted in the sale of secure properties. All he was citing there was the effectiveness of the strategy put together by Allen Allen and Hemsley, conspiring with Australia's bank which we are supposed to be able to bank on-Westpac-to destroy the interests of ordinary Australians. He argues that it was less than 100. I could not give a damn, Mr Fowler, if it was one or a hundred or a thousand; it is irrelevant.

The realities are that he was citing there the effectiveness of this conspiracy against ordinary Australians; he was citing there the impotence of ordinary Australians to get justice before the courts; he was citing there the fact that their sweeteners, their concessions, their exemptions from legal action and their non-disclosure clauses had worked.

Last Sunday, he had the most unmitigated gall, when being interviewed about all this on the Business Sunday program to quote me as a referee. He said, `If you want to see how clean Westpac is, you hear what McLean had to say about Westpac'. He said that in the last two years, in all the material I have tabled in this place, Westpac is the cleanest bank. He quoted me as his referee. How about that for hypocrisy!

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you applied for a loan lately?
—I have got an account with Westpac. It has got $64 in it. My other account is with the Commonwealth Bank and I will give it a pretty good serve on Friday, too. It is not about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that any more serious motion could be brought before this Senate. I sit down with interest to hear what the Government and the Opposition in this place are going to say about this motion, which actually cites the fact that the biggest bank and the biggest law firm have colluded to destroy ordinary Australians and to pervert the course of justice after having done so. I now welcome the comment of the Government of this country and the alternative government, the Opposition, on this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the motion that Senator McLean gave notice of two days ago. I indicate that I will not be supporting the motion because of paragraph (b) which calls for a full judicial inquiry. I believe it is the Government's view that such an inquiry at this stage is unnecessary, because we do have a full inquiry into the banking industry being conducted by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. We also have, in view of some of the matters arising from the Westpac documents dealing with the cost of justice, an inquiry being conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. So in the inquiries of two committees of this Parliament there is plenty of scope with the evidence before us for those matters to be dealt with. At this stage I am not willing to support the resolution because of paragraph (b).

SPEECH.PARA: I concede that if people are dissatisfied with the recommendations that come from those two inquiries they can then quite legitimately come back into this place-and I am sure Senator McLean would-and ask for a full judicial or some other sort of inquiry if they believe that the material relating to the Westpac documents has not been properly dealt with.

I want to spend some time on the aspect that I am most interested in, which is the cost of justice. I believe these documents, the Westpac documents, give irrefutable evidence. As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I must say that we have been very keen on our inquiry into the cost of justice. This is the first time that we have had before us irrefutable evidence from a senior legal source stating that one way in which one can defeat people in this country in their proper rights for justice is to use the high cost of the legal system.

In all the evidence that we have had so far there have been assertions and speculation that that is the case. But here it is in these documents; that one of the defence mechanisms that Westpac has been advised to use by its legal advisers-from one of the most senior firms in the land-is to rely on the high cost of justice, the high cost of court proceedings, to scare people out of their proper rights.

I must say that when the Senate Committee inquiry started, I had a suspicion-a gut feeling-that the legal system in this country was being perverted by a high cost; that people were being denied justice. But now we have got before us clear evidence that this is a tactic of the system. I hope that our Committee in its deliberations and final conclusions can bring forward recommendations that deal with this problem.

I have already raised with the Chairman of our Committee and other members of the Committee that I believe it would be very proper for our Committee to ask Mr Jones, who wrote the Westpac documents, to come before the Committee and give evidence to the content of them. The Committee would also ask representatives of the various law societies, the Law Council of Australia and the Bar Council to come before us and give evidence about the lack of ethics contained in these documents.

In the Westpac documents that have now been incorporated in the Hansard after some debate for some days and are now publicly available I want to draw attention to the evidence that I am most interested in at the moment. On pages 6 and 7 Mr Jones prepares conclusions, which I just quote to give the flavour:
1. According to PPL's own documents, PPL:
told clients it would do a professional management job;
told clients that it would adopt a conservative, `when in doubt, hedge' approach to risk management.
2. PPL's own documents acknowledge that:
PPL did neither of these things; and
this failure caused loss which would not otherwise have been incurred.
And so it goes on with clear-cut evidence and admission by Mr Jones, on behalf of Westpac, that PPL did not carry out its responsibilities, as it said it would. It then says on page 7:
9. Clients will be slow to commence action because of:
The breadth of the exclusion clause in the Power of Attorney will deter clients (who don't know of the deal switching and point taking and the damaging PPL documents) from commencing action;
their lack of knowledge of how damaging PPL's documents are; the lack of success of OCL actions to date;-
and the final point-
the high costs involved.

10. Given 9 and given full-time hands-on management by a suitable executive having total responsibility, suitably supported by state managers, it should be possible to keep liability at a manageable level.

Just to emphasise the point in these documents, on page 12 in conclusions 9 and 10, Mr Jones again goes through in more detail the defence mechanisms and the defence strategy that should be adopted. In conclusion 9 the fourth point titled `The High Costs Involved' reads:
Many borrowers (particularly in these troubled times) are not flush with cash and they would doubtlessly perceive that PPL would defend proceedings grimly.

Well, no doubt that is correct; that the borrowers, the ordinary citizens of Australia-and some of them may be quite wealthy-would realise that with their experience or understanding of the law that a Westpac-run organisation, with its unlimited resources compared to theirs, would be able to take them to every form of court and legal action to defend the position and wear them down because of the costs.

That is justice denied. It means that our system where everybody is supposed to be equal before the law does not apply. If one is rich in this country, one gets away with it; but if one is poor then one either goes broke or goes to gaol. I believe that these documents expose the legal profession in this country, because this is not some grubby little country solicitor at the back of Oonagallaby; this is a document written by a senior member of one of Australia's leading legal firms. This is the practice that we all have had an assumption on but now we have the evidence.

Today when I was asked to speak in this debate I decided that I would try to find out just what are the ethics of the legal profession. I asked my office in Adelaide to contact the Law Society of South Australia to give us the details of what are the ethics for solicitors to act on in Australia or in South Australia. My secretary reports that the conversation went something like this:
Can you tell me whether the Law Society has a codified set of ethics for lawyers?
The Law Society has copies of rules of conduct for the profession-they cost $5. What exactly are you wanting to know about?
We are just interested in seeing a copy, how can we get one?
I can't sell you one because they're only for qualified solicitors.
Why is that?
I can't answer that, I'll have to put you through to someone else.
So my research officer went through to somebody else and the conversation went something like this:
I'm wondering how we can obtain a copy of the Law Society's rules of conduct?
We sell them for $5 but they are only available to members of the profession.
Why is that?
I can't tell you that.
Why not?
It's just the way it's always been.
Do you know why?
No. I'll have to get someone else to call you back.

At the last count there had not been a call back. I find it astonishing that the profession which claims to be one of the pre-eminent professions in this country, which claims that in every sense it is the custodian of justice for people, refuses to give a copy of its own ethics to members of the public, even if they are willing to pay $5. If there is a case to end so-called self-regulation of the legal profession in this country, that little snippet proves it beyond doubt.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is black and brown and looks great on a lawyer? A Doberman Pinscher.

—I think that if we get into jokes about lawyers we will be here all night because those jokes are endless and reflect the cynicism of the Australian public about the way this profession has acted in a high-handed manner without any feeling that it was responsible to the community. I suppose the other side of it is that it is often said that doctors bury their mistakes and lawyers gaol theirs. We have all heard those sorts of comments. They are jokes within the community; they may be unfair but they reflect the feelings of ordinary citizens that they do not get a fair go in the way the law is structured and operated in this country. That was the reaction of the Law Society of South Australia to a query about the ethics of lawyers so that I could check whether Mr Jones, the lawyer who wrote the Westpac documents, was acting ethically.

SPEECH.PARA: Through the Department of The Parliamentary Library I was finally able to get a copy of the New South Wales solicitors manual. After reading this in a cursory way, and not being a lawyer and not understanding every legal concept, I must say that, if this manual is fair dinkum, the Law Society should now be acting to take Mr Jones before its disciplinary body because on so many accounts I believe there is a prima facie case that he has acted contrary to the ethics of the Law Society of New South Wales as laid out in its manual. I will quote some of the sections of that manual. Firstly, under the heading `Acceptance of Instructions-The Solicitor's Retainer':

The lawyer is not the mere ``mouthpiece'' of his or her client, nor the champion of the client's cause at all costs. There must be found, in the blending of professional independence and professional responsibility, a balance between unqualified loyalty to the legitimate service of a client's interest and the unreserved adoption of a client's cause in defiance of the law or its just administration . . .
That is the start of the acceptance that no lawyer has the right to act utterly on behalf of a client no matter what. Further on, under the heading `The solicitor's paramount duty to the court':

Whilst the solicitor's duty is to avoid any circumstances in which the solicitor might serve any other interest (including his own) which might conflict with that of the client, the solicitor's duty is limited by boarder principles of policy in the public interest. The solicitor's duty, as a officer of the court, to avoid any action which might mislead the court is a primary limitation on the duty owed to the client.
That is a quotation from Lord Reid in Rondel v. Worsley in 1969. Further on:

Counsel must not mislead the court, he must not lend himself to casting aspersions on the other party or witnesses for which there is no sufficient basis in the information in his possession, he must not withhold authorities or documents which may tell against his clients but which the law or the standards of his profession require him to produce.

It is all there. What was Mr Jones doing when he was preparing these documents? Did he ever think to read this, or even have it in the back of his mind? Further in this section about the solicitor's paramount duty to the court, Mr Justice McTiernan, a distinguished judge of the High Court of Australia in years gone by, said:

. . . that it was a proposition which admitted of no debate that a solicitor for a party in an action was not at liberty to employ whatever tactics he thought might contribute to his client's success. A solicitor like anybody else was liable to be prosecuted if with the object of winning the case he did anything which was a criminal offence. As a solicitor he had an additional and particular responsibility. His professional status, which he derived from being accredited by the court as a fit and proper person to practise, laid upon him the strict obligation not to interfere or attempt to interfere with the course of justice under any pretext. If he violated that duty he was guilty of professional misconduct.
There is a clear prima facie case in these documents that this solicitor, Mr Jones, broke that particular professional ethic. Further on in this same section:

Fabrication of evidence, coaching to induce false evidence, hinting at the results which certain evidence will induce with the expectation that it will be altered, interviewing witnesses together, so as to induce agreement must be a departure from the solicitor's duty as an officer of the court.

I do not know whether this evidence has been fabricated, but clearly an attempt was made to produce evidence to scare customers of Westpac from proceeding because of the documents that had been produced. Another section of the same document is headed `Acting honestly in the service of a client':

Solicitors are not entitled, in the service of their client's interests, to ignore their other responsibilities imposed by the law and the ethics and conventions of their profession. The fairness and honesty which should mark solicitors' dealings with the courts, should also characterise solicitors' dealings with one another.
Again, this was absolutely thrown out of the window if the Westpac documents are true. The section goes on:
A solicitor should not assist a client in the commission of an illegal act.
Reading this I have to say there is a prima facie case that Mr Jones was guilty of assisting a client, namely, Westpac, in the commission of an illegal act. The section goes on:

It is consistent with a solicitor's duty to his or her client that a solicitor should thoroughly advise the client on questions of law and their interpretation which are relevant to the client's business and on which the client seeks advice.

It is clear that the advice Mr Jones was giving was not about the ethics of the responsibilities of Westpac within the legal system; it was how to avoid being caught and having to pay damages to people who had been misled in their business dealings with Westpac. Where were Mr Jones's thoughts as a senior lawyer in consideration of this section which, as I say, is about acting honestly in the service of a client? Further in the same document under the heading `The professional adviser and criminal complicity' Mr Justice McHugh is quoted:
He went on to point out that a person charged as an aider and abetter will be guilty if that person has knowledge of the ``factual matters which constitute the breach of the law''.
I must say, reading these documents, that a prima facie case exists. The section goes on:
A professional adviser whose advise aids the commission of an offence may be guilty of aiding and abetting . . .
What was Mr Jones doing other than advising? It is all here in this document about the ethics of how the profession should act. Further on:

On the question of participation in the commission of an offence, McHugh J noted that a person may be liable as an aider and abetter if that person's conduct is ``knowingly directed to the purpose which the principal has pursued and is likely to bring about or render more likely the attainment of that purpose''.

We know what the purpose was; it is in the document. It was to cheat people of their legal rights. I draw the attention of the Senate to this document which, as I said before, is the New South Wales solicitors manual.

If the legal profession which, in appearing before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, has argued the high cost of justice, is fair dinkum in its view that there is no need for government regulation of the ethics of its profession and its activities-leave it all to them-in the very near future the disciplinary committee of the New South Wales Law Society, in line with that society's manual, should take on Mr Jones and ask him to explain the action that he has taken in advising Westpac how to avoid justice for the ordinary people who dealt with that bank.

I believe that the days in which this community can say that the legal profession is entitled to unfettered self-regulation have come to an end following what has occurred in Australia in recent years in the legal profession, which has been hand in glove with commercial organisations to ensure that corporate Australia avoids as much tax as possible and avoids normal and commonsense responsibilities to the community. I am delighted that one of the measures mentioned by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his statement yesterday, which I do not think has received as much recognition as it should, is that he is writing to every State Premier asking that the existing exemptions of the Trade Practices Act come to an end and that the professions, which, under the Constitution of Australia, are regulated overwhelmingly by State laws, come under the powers of the Trade Practices Act.

I believe that the legal profession should be the one to be first considered in this regard. That would be a major step forward for justice in this community because at long last we may be able to begin the road back to showing the ordinary citizens of Australia that the legal system works for them and not for the lawyers. That is a very important issue that our community, our Parliament and the State parliaments will have to deal with.

I point out to the Senate that, whenever I have made public statements or I have been interviewed on radio or television about the high cost of justice, I have been astonished at the number of letters and telephone calls that I have received in my office from people from all over Australia who have some of the most dreadful tales to tell of how they have been robbed of their rights by the law, and incompetent legal operations and who find that they have no redress. When they try to get redress through the legal profession because a particular lawyer has not acted properly or has not conducted a case properly, they find it is almost impossible to get action taken to do so. On no issue since I have been in public life have I come across such a response from the public of Australia as I have whenever I have raised the issue of the high cost of justice or the way the system is working.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they're all right, too, everyone of them.
—Wouldn't have a clue how the system works.

—The interjection from Senator Macdonald portrays an appalling lack of knowledge about what is going on with ordinary Australian citizens regarding their relationships with the law. Senator Macdonald should start reading some of the evidence of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in the inquiry into the high cost of justice. He will see evidence that many ordinary citizens are being unduly penalised.

SPEECH.PARA: Micro-economic reform is a fashionable phrase used by those on all sides in this Parliament. We all support it. During the past few years blue collar workers, semi-skilled workers and white collar workers in industry have been taking the pain and making industry more efficient. Some have lost their jobs; some have been retrained; and some have had to go to other jobs. They have suffered the pain. But when we raise issues about getting a more efficient legal system in this country by changing it, we immediately get attacked by the legal profession, which says that we are trying to fiddle with the system of justice and that they and only they know what justice is about. It is an absolute fallacy. It must be met head on.

We must insist, if we are fair dinkum about micro-economic reform, that the legal profession can no longer be left unfettered to go about its business in the way it is at the moment. If we want an efficient economy, the legal profession must contribute. Legal costs represent a big cost for any business. If we want to reduce the cost for a business, we should reduce its legal costs. One way to reduce those legal costs is to reorganise the legal system and open up the restrictive practices in that system. The restrictive practices that applied to the Waterside Workers Federation and to the Seamen's Union of Australia for 30 or 40 years are kindergarten stuff by comparison with those in the legal profession. The most restrictive practices in any area of commercial activity and industrial activity in this country are in the legal profession.

When I suggest to lawyers that this is unfair, they accuse me or others of attacking the whole system of justice. That is wrong. I think that the citizens of this country, not just the lawyers, have a right to demand a better legal system where they know they will get a fair go and not be taken down by a legal system that is structured to ensure that lawyers' incomes are maintained at a high level.

A survey conducted in February last year by the Australian Bureau of Statistics shows that lawyers have the highest salaries of any profession. Of any profession surveyed, the salaries of those in the legal profession were shown to be 50 per cent higher those in the next profession. Why? Because they have restrictive trade. People have limited access to it. The profession does not allow advertising of fees, and so on. Every effort is made to ensure that that profession does not have to be responsible or to justify its charges.

When we asked the Chairman of the Victorian Law Society how the charging of legal fees was arrived at, he said that a committee consisting of eight people, seven of whom were legal practitioners, set them. That committee recommended to a subcommittee of the State Supreme Court. Three Supreme Court justices then looked at their recommendations, considered them and brought down a determination. When I asked how widely the costs were published and what that meant, he said, `Most of us couldn't understand it anyway'. When I asked him whether he thought it was reasonable for reasons to be given for the setting of legal fees at certain levels, he said, `Of course that is not given. It is a document of a couple of pages'. No justification is given, as is the case with other workers. Even politicians have to give reasons to the Remuneration Tribunal as to why our wages should be set at certain levels. The legal profession does not have to do that. It sets the fees in-house, and that is it. If the legal profession believes that that will go on in Australia without the community becoming extremely cynical about the operation of the profession, both the profession and Senator Macdonald are sadly mistaken.

I conclude by saying that I do not support this motion because at this stage, with two committees of inquiry of this Parliament, I do not believe that a judicial committee is needed, but I have to say that the evidence in the Westpac documents proves that, irrespective of what Westpac as a banking organisation is about, the legal profession is aiding and abetting the robbing of ordinary citizens; and it has to come to an end.

I believe that it is the responsibility of this Parliament and the State parliaments to deal with these issues and to bring major reforms to the way the profession operates so that Mr Jones and his ilk are forced to carry out the ethics of their own profession which they themselves have documented but which they themselves now ignore to the great cost of ordinary citizens of Australia. I welcome the opportunity to speak in this debate and look forward to the deliberations of the two parliamentary committees and their recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean's motion for a royal commission into banking is a disturbing one to have before this chamber. Among other things, it asks us to note that a bank abandoned its fiduciary obligation to its clients; advantaged itself at the expense of its clients; and was involved in false accounting and deception. It also asks us to note that one of Australia's significant law firms conspired to obstruct just outcomes to the bank's clients; aided and abetted a criminal offence; and is guilty of a conspiracy. They are the assertions and the quite clear allegations that have been put down.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the type of motion that one would expect to uncover in Baghdad, not in Canberra. Just as disturbing is the Government's decision to set this time aside for the motion to be debated here this evening. There is another agenda for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are devious. You dig your own political grave, my friend.

—I allowed Senator McLean to give his contribution uninterrupted and I ask for the same courtesy in response. The Government has its own agenda-something to which I will refer in a moment. I speak, obviously, to oppose the motion, which we consider both substantially out of order and ill-timed. Ill-timed is the point I want to make. Banks may not be the flavour of the month or the year or even the decade. There is in many areas substantive reason to take that view. But Senator McLean has set himself up, I believe, as judge and jury and has designs on widening that to include the role of the Senate to be judge and jury. We will have no part of that. No one on this side of the chamber-certainly I will not-will ever champion the actions of a bank when that bank has been proved through due judicial process to have been guilty of financial mismanagement or fraudulent decisions. But nor will we ever become part of an emotional lynch mob taking justice into our own hands. That, unfortunately, is what I believe the motion seeks to make senators of Australia do. This is an attempt this evening to force a judicial inquiry with assertions as have been included in the motion to which I have already referred.

SPEECH.PARA: We were against the tabling in the Senate of the Westpac Banking Corporation documents, not because of any view that Westpac should be protected from public disclosure of its actions, but because the case against Westpac was sub judice and a court had decreed that the documents were not to be released at this point in the course of justice. The documents were and are the central issue in a number of legal cases, both recent and longstanding, before the courts.

It is a time-honoured tradition, a principle, of Parliament that, while it has the right to consider any material it wishes, it does not raise sub judice matters. What Senator McLean wished us to do was to usurp the course of justice in Australia.

We will not be swayed from the point of view that determination of the truth of allegations against a bank or anyone is a matter for the courts, not the Senate. Taking the point further, we are against the release of the documents because it is imperative that the separation of powers be upheld in Australia. We have seen some recent instances in this country in some States where that has broken down. Once that system of the separation of powers breaks down, once Parliament begins to interfere with and negate the due processes of the courts, democracy, as we know it, is at risk in the long term because, once the gates are opened, once the principle is broken, it is difficult to contain. It is a dangerous and damaging precedent for which no-one, I hope, on this side of the chamber would wish to be responsible.

Sadly, throughout what is now known to everyone as the Westpac affair, Senator McLean has shown no regard at all for the upholding of the separation of powers or the upholding of either the judicial or parliamentary processes. This motion indicates that he has no trust in how the parliamentary process operates. That is what his actions today and in past weeks have shown. It is, without exaggeration, an almost daily public thrust of mistrust from the Senator. Otherwise, why would we have this motion before us this evening as yet another example? After all, why does Senator McLean seek to jump the gun with this motion for a full judicial inquiry-in other words, a royal commission-before he gives his three hours of evidence to the banking inquiry of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration-evidence that will be heard on Friday, a mere two days away? What does he really seek to achieve with this motion except to display no confidence in the parliamentary process of which he is part? He shows no confidence in the committee system and no confidence in our banking inquiry.
Senator Powell interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to Senator Powell that we have a committee of this Parliament investigating this very matter and Senator McLean will appear before it. I understand that three hours have been allocated to him this Friday to put all this evidence before that Committee. That being the case, why are we debating this motion here and now? The Senate has absolutely no specifics, no judicial decisions, against Westpac or any other bank before us today to indicate that a royal commission is warranted at this time. The time for such motions, if somewhat less emotionally framed, I might add, from anyone is after the banking inquiry reports to the Parliament; after a committee of this Parliament has done its job thoroughly, effectively and efficiently, has taken evidence from all witnesses, of which Senator McLean will be one, and has reported to the Parliament-not when the inquiry is in its infancy.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not at all meant to indicate that I want to whitewash the reported actions of Westpac; far from it. But it is up to the courts to make the determination that the bank has failed in its responsibilities and to administer justice for any failure of those responsibilities. That is what they are there for. It is not what we are here for.

To pass Senator McLean's motion would be to say to all Australians that this Parliament has lost not only its respect, but its trust, for the country's legal system. That is quite clearly wrong and, I think, an outrageous assumption to make and to enjoin others to make. That is what the motion seeks to do.

I think there has been some confusion in the Senator's role and responsibilities with regard to the law. It is not up to the Senator to decide and to declare that Westpac's lawyers have broken the law and conspired to obstruct outcomes to clients. In my view, that is an abuse of parliamentary privilege and it does little in the community to enhance the already somewhat tattered reputation of politicians.

We live in a civilised society. We do not condemn without trial and without evidence being put before an appropriate court. It saddens me that Senator McLean has become so overwhelmed with the Westpac affair that he has forgotten what I believe is such a basic principle of justice. But it must not be forgotten that it is similarly regrettable that some former employees of Westpac appear to have forgotten the principles of banking. But surely all banks and all those employed by banking organisations do not summarily stand condemned for the alleged actions of some. However, that conclusion seems to be the tenor of the motion.

There will always be rotten apples in every basket, be it of politicians, lawyers, businessmen, policemen, bankers or whatever. But do we brand all as unclean in retaliation for the reported actions of a few? I hope not. I hope we never get to that position in this country. I hope that all senators hope not. This sweeping and damaging motion tells me that I am mistaken.

This takes me to the Government's decision to allow the motion to be debated. The Government's agenda is to make banks look bad in the public eye at every opportunity. This evening is just another opportunity. Absolutely anything that is anti-banking is all right with the Government, so it is quite happy to allow a motion to be debated which furthers that aim.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has over the past few years taken bank bashing to an art form. Aided by his colleagues, he has used every media opportunity to attempt to convey the impression that the financial woes of Australia and Australians should be laid at the doors of the banks, not at the feet of the Federal Treasurer.

When his bankrupting, single-minded, tunnel visioned, high interest rate policy ripped through Australia's small business community he said it was the greedy banks' fault for not dropping interest rates fast enough, just as it was the uncaring banks' fault when they moved in to foreclose on collapsed businesses. When mortgagee sales festooned the suburbs it was again the banks' fault for not taking interest rates down when they could, or as much as they could, and for lending too much to their big customers at the expense of the small. Treasurer Keating's ongoing battle of words with the National Australia Bank's Nobby Clark, now Chairman of the State Bank of South Australia, laid bare this Government's determination that the banks must be painted all that is bad in a vain attempt to shift economic blame.

Before the last Federal election in my home State of South Australia, Labor's Peter Duncan in the very marginal mortgage belt seat of Makin ran a masterly anti-bank strategy. On the face of it, it was on behalf of his struggling constituents, but actually it was on behalf of his struggling Government. That strategy was repeated across Australia in similar problem marginal seats. It is what we have come to expect from the Government.

I am no apologist for banks. Their failure to react in 1987 to the implications of the share market crash has contributed enormously to their present problems, but the failure of Treasurer Keating in 1985 to recognise the difficulties and the temptations that deregulation would create for our banks in competition with foreign banks is really when the seeds of today's troubles were sown. The credit explosion that grew from deregulation and the fear that our trading banks had of losing their market share to foreign banks was largely translated into consumption. Enormous risks were taken to stay competitive, not just by our trading banks but also by our State banks chasing the deregulation pot of gold. We have all seen what happened to State banks when they tried to compete in the deregulation big league. It was a monumental blunder that with deregulation did not come a far more comprehensive system of prudential supervision for State banks.

Compulsory guidelines for reporting to the Reserve Bank of Australia were a necessary major step; not voluntary ones, as have failed so miserably with Victoria and South Australia. Treasurer Keating changed the game, but in his mode of self-congratulation he did not pay attention to changing the small print in the rules, and the banks and the taxpayers of Australia are now suffering as a result. As a South Australian concerned for more than two years about reported losses of the State Bank, I have had difficulty coming to terms with the Reserve Bank's assertion that it had known of problems with the bank through its voluntary reporting, but that it was under no obligation to inform the Treasurer or the bank's owner-the Premier of South Australia-or, in fact, to do anything about it. That may have been the simple, uncomplicated way things happened in the simple, uncomplicated days before deregulation, but the fact that a Treasurer and the Reserve Bank continued to allow it to happen after deregulation must be called into question.

Since deregulation, Australia should have implemented prudential requirements similar to those overseas where the Reserve Bank could make direct inspections and examinations of individual institutions. This would have allowed accurate information to be gathered on whether prudential standards, including a minimum capital ratio and a minimum liquidity ratio, were being observed, and whether management control systems were being followed and were operated efficiently. Still it seems that we do not learn from mistakes. While the Reserve Bank, through changes to the Banking Act, now has the power to make regular examinations of banks' books, it has indicated that it does not intend to use it except in special and exceptional circumstances. How special do State bank failures have to be to warrant change, warrant inspection and warrant action?

Yes, the blame for some reaction and action since deregulation can be apportioned to banks and big business, but the blame for the prudential standards failure, for Australia's economic policy and economic ills, and the pain of the high interest rate policy, belongs solely to Canberra and Treasurer Keating. In relation to the prudential requirements, what we ought to be seeing put in place is a very comprehensive range of standards, properly and effectively followed through. The prudential standards as we know them cover the provision of information and regular discussion with management boards and management systems being put in place, but the specific aspects of those prudential standards, guidelines and requirements ought to be capital adequacy and adequate liquidity in those banks, lending investment policies, subsidiaries and the raising of funds.

Clearly, some State banks, in their rush to be part of the big league banking industry of this country, have got it wrong in taking on risk areas that were beyond their capacity and ability to manage effectively and efficiently. As a result, we have seen in Victoria, for example, the taxpayers of Australia-through the Commonwealth Bank of Australia-becoming involved in a privatisation move to bale out the State Bank of Victoria. In the State Bank of South Australia, through an interchange of funds-creative accounting, I think one would call it-$1 billion has been invested at an annual cost of over $100m a year to the taxpayers of that State. It will further erode the competitiveness of South Australia vis-a-vis the other States. For a small State depending on its manufacturing base for its economy and its job opportunities, it is a sad blow because it removes and pegs back any gains of the past in terms of seeking to get into a position where it can compete in manufacturing with other States.

We have seen the drift to the eastern seaboard of Australia away from South Australia. We want to halt that drift and get it back so that South Australia as a State can continue to grow and prosper with its outstanding standard of living, and maintain within it a good manufacturing base for job opportunities for South Australians of the future.

Let me return specifically to the proposal before the Senate. It is a motion clearly stating that the Senate should be judge and jury of the actions of another when, in fact, those matters are currently before the courts and when, in fact, that subject is before a committee of this Parliament. I repeat that Senator McLean has the opportunity only this Friday to appear for three hours before the banking inquiry, to put all the evidence he has at his disposal-and it would appear that he has significant and substantial evidence-before the House of House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for that Committee to make a judgment on it and report to the Parliament.

The bank bashing that we have seen by the Government may deflect a few blows in the short term, but it is an underhand strategy and it is wearing thin. In my view, that strategy is the reason the Government allowed Senator McLean's motion to be debated this evening. It does the Government no credit. I do not believe that it is timely for this chamber to be debating a motion of this nature when, as I have said, the matter is before the courts and before a committee of this Parliament. When that Committee has completed its deliberations and reported will be the appropriate time for further consideration along the lines proposed by Senator McLean's motion. At this stage this side of the chamber will not support the motion.
