TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some concern that I bring to the attention of the Senate this evening a report of the forthcoming appearance by the Australian Democrats before the executive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). It was reported in the Australian last week that Senator McLean will be appearing before the ACTU executive tomorrow. He confirmed with me this evening that this meeting is taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: Apparently, Senator McLean, the Australian Democrats' spokesman on industrial relations, will be briefing Mr Bill Kelty and Mr Martin Ferguson and others about the Democrats' industrial relations policies. Let me say at the outset that there is nothing wrong with the Democrats briefing special interest lobby groups. Let us face it, there are few lobbies as powerful as the ACTU. As Martin Ferguson has said in his inimitable phrase, `The ACTU is part and parcel of the Hawke Government'.

The Democrats, as I will indicate, have already been of great assistance to this Government with its industrial relations policies. I wonder whether the Australian Democrats are not about to make the same mistake on industrial relations as they made in relation to their policies on foreign relations. Are we going to see a sell-out of the real interests of the Australian people once again?

It is worth recalling that the Australian Democrats paid a heavy price for their opposition to the United Nations (UN) endorsed forces in the Gulf. The voter support for the Democrats has virtually collapsed since the last election, falling from around 17 per cent to around 10 per cent.

Senator Powell's statements on the Gulf-which by and large were more noted for their unthinking anti-Americanism-did not provide any assurances to Democrat voters wanting a more reasoned and carefully considered response. Potential Australian Democrats voters, like all Australians, resiled in horror from the statement made by former Democrat Leader, Janine Haines, that she was prepared to `grovel' if necessary on her self-initiated mission to the bloody dictator, Saddam Hussein. I hope we are not going to see another example of grovelling tomorrow at ACTU headquarters.

Under the industrial relations approach taken by Senator Powell and Senator McLean, the interests of workers and the men and women who run small businesses have been sacrificed to the ambitions of union bosses. As I have pointed out in this chamber before on a number of occasions, some two-thirds of Australian Democrats voters supported Australia being part of the United States (US) led forces in the Gulf. The leadership of the Australian Democrats was out of touch not only with the Australian people but also with its own voters. Similarly, in the area of industrial relations the Democrats do not seem to understand that over 60 per cent of people who describe themselves as Australian Democrat supporters believe trade unions have too much power. Similarly, Australian Democrats should remember that over 85 per cent of Australians believe employers should have the right to take legal action against unions which indulge in intimidatory tactics. Yet Senator Powell and Senator McLean consistently support policies which reinforce the power and privilege of trade union bosses.

It does not cause me great distress to witness the decline of the Australian Democrats. It would be hypocritical of me to suggest otherwise. But I do see great dangers in the attitude of the Australian Democrats to industrial relations and their willingness to support the interests of the trade union bosses against trade union members and the interests of ordinary Australians.

It is no secret that members of the trade union movement are now contemplating in their eyes the unthinkable-a coalition government. Every attempt will be made to frustrate the resounding mandate that John Hewson led coalition forces will receive at the next election. In the dying days of this Government do not be surprised if we see legislation designed to buttress the power and privileges of the trade union bosses before a coalition government comes into office. Already there are rumours of the establishment of a labour court, which may restrict common law actions against unions.

The support of the Australian Democrats will be vital if this type of legislation is to go through the Parliament-absolutely vital. It is equally well known that the trade union bosses see the Democrats after the next election as playing a vital role in blocking industrial relations reforms which will be introduced by a coalition government should the Australian Democrats hold the balance of power in this chamber; legislation, it might be added, which will have the resounding mandate of the Australian public.

The Australian Democrats are clearly not the same party that they were under the leadership of their founder, Don Chipp. In those days the Democrats were known as vigorous supporters of small business. That is why the Democrats opposed the repeal of section 45d of the Trade Practices Act, which outlawed secondary boycotts. The Government attempted to remove this fundamental right in the Trade Practices Amendment Bill of 1984. Section 45d has been of enormous importance in containing the excesses of union power. It is a section which has afforded great protection to small business and forced the trade union movement to submit to the rule of law in Federal courts.

Honourable senators may recall that in December 1989 Senator McLean introduced a private member's Bill purporting to provide for the right to strike. What did this Bill really seek to achieve? Under the guise of proposing ballots before strikes, a policy which we in the coalition support, the Bill aimed to remove the common law liability of unions and trade union officials. Not even the Commonwealth Government in recent years has been prepared to support such radical proposals which would have the effect of putting trade unions above the law.

Once again, the Australian Democrats have parted company with Don Chipp, who is on record supporting the common law right to sue trade union officials who encourage employees to break work contracts. Don Chipp, a former senator, wrote in July 1990:
Legal contracts are enforced in every other activity in our society and appropriate damages sought and won for any significant breaches of them. Why not in the area of industrial relations?

I do not believe that that question has ever been properly answered by the Australian Democrats under the leadership of Senator Powell. It has always been a strong principle of the Australian Democrats to oppose compulsory unionism. On a reading of the Australian Democrats platform, it is true that this principle still remains. It has to be said that their commitment to this principle is, to say the least, very suspect. In effect, it has been often ignored when the Democrats have supported Government legislation which has virtually forced individuals to join unions.

We recall how willingly the Democrats supported the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill (1990), which is aimed at facilitating forced trade union amalgamations. This Bill also forces preference in employment to be given to union members. So much for the Australian Democrats' commitment to voluntary unionism.

Once again, former Democrat leader Senator Chipp vigorously opposed this Bill which sought to achieve the ACTU goal of forcing amalgamations of trade unions so that only 20 mega-unions remained. This Bill required that trade unions have a minimum of 10,000 members. Just two years previously the Democrats believed that the minimum number of members of a trade union should be 1,000. What was apparently correct in 1988 did not apply in 1990.

In fairness, it has to be said that some Democrats have remained true to their policies. Senator Lees and Senator Kernot earned the gratitude of students around Australia by joining with the coalition to defeat the Government's attempt to further entrench compulsory student unionism in its Higher Education Amendment Funding Bill (No.1) last year. Regrettably, the other Democrats, Senators Bourne, Coulter and McLean, decided to follow Senator Powell and support the Government on this oppressive legislation designed to entrench compulsory student unionism. Knowing Senator Bell's recognition of the importance of civil rights of students, I have to say that it was surprising that he voted with the Government on that particular piece of oppressive legislation.

I have shown how the Australian Democrats, by their efforts to remove common law actions against unions, by their support for union preference in employment and by their total about-turn on mega-unionism, have shown themselves to be friends not of union members but of union bosses.

There is one other area which I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate where the Australian Democrats under Senator Powell appear to have already been unduly influenced by the ACTU. Time and time again in this chamber we have seen the irrational opposition of the Democrats to privatisation policies. This is a stance which has undoubtedly further endeared the Australian Democrats to the ACTU. The Australian Democrats probably hold the notable record of being virtually one of the only parties in government in the Western world and, undoubtedly, in the Eastern world which are vigorously opposed to any privatisation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in government-in parliament. They could never be in government.

—I thank Senator Brownhill for that correction. I have, before now, made that statement challenging the Australian Democrats to indicate whether there is any area of privatisation-perhaps a little bit of contracting out-which the Australia Democrats could find it in their policies to support. Not one iota of privatisation fits into the Australian Democrats platform.

SPEECH.PARA: In my mind-and frankly I am supported by the aspirations of most Australian people in their attitude to trade unions-the Australian Democrats in recent years, under the influence of Senators Powell and McLean, have a very poor record in industrial relations. When Senator McLean emerges from his visit to the ACTU headquarters tomorrow, I hope that the media will press him on this particular question. Before I state the question, remember the great Democrats slogan about `keeping the bastards honest', that is, forcing the government of the day to keep its promises. This is a great slogan by Don Chipp which has gone down in Australian history. In other words, anyone who goes to an election on a certain policy or on a certain promise keeps that promise. That was a central principle of the Don Chipp-led Australian Democrats.

With that background, this is the question which Senator McLean must answer: if the electorate gives a clear mandate to a coalition government, including the right to introduce comprehensive industrial relations reforms, will the Australian Democrats guarantee to allow this policy to pass in the Senate if, by some mischance, they hold the balance of power? That is right in line with the old Democrat principle of going to an election on, for example, major industrial reforms and keeping that promise.

It will be very interesting when Senator McLean emerges tomorrow from his meeting with Mr Kelty and Mr Ferguson and is asked by the press to give a guarantee that a Hewson-led coalition government will be allowed to keep its promise on industrial relations. If Senator McLean refuses to answer this question, clearly the electorate will know that the Democrats have sold out to ACTU bosses. I guarantee that every voter in every electorate will learn of this treachery.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Economic Planning Advisory Council: South Australia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Normally I do not speak on parochial questions and I do not take up parish pump subjects in this place. I have been elected as a national representative, one who would speak on national questions, look at national legislation and subjects of interest around this nation. Tonight I am forced to speak on a very local question, which I find regrettable. It is with great regret that I must criticise a recent report that has been brought out by Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC). In criticising this report, I do so more in sorrow than in anger because I suppose I, among other people, can take blame for organisations such as EPAC being established. In the 1970s and early 1980s I was a member of the National Economics Platform Committee of the Australian Labor Party when proposals for organisations such as this were being examined.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to comment tonight on a report recently released by EPAC which concluded that South Australia is the worst place in Australia in which to live. The report is titled Urban and Regional Trends and Issues, January 1991, Council Paper No. 46. I am sure that Senator Foreman is as interested in this subject as I am. Having lived in South Australia and elsewhere, I cannot agree with EPAC's findings and I think I am fairly well placed to do so.

In my experience, the findings of EPAC that Adelaide is the worst capital city in which to live, or South Australia is the worst State in which to live, are wrong, ridiculous and ill-informed. I think I should set the record straight tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did it actually say that?

—It had an index which suggested that South Australia ranked worst of the six States in terms of quality of life. For people on low to middle incomes, I believe that the report is patently wrong. Maybe EPAC's focus was on the lifestyle of the upper middle class. It is very hard to tell, because clearly quality of life has to be looked at in terms of specific groups in the community. I have no doubt in my own mind that the cities of Adelaide and Perth, and the States of South Australia, Western Australia and other smaller populated areas are probably areas where people have a much higher quality of life, despite the findings of EPAC.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that is concerning about this EPAC report is that it bases its findings mainly on statistics. One of the problems with it is that many aspects of quality of life cannot be quantified or measured and certainly cannot be expressed directly in statistics. Mr Deputy President, I am sure that you would be aware of the difficulties in trying to quantify things in terms of quality of life.

The report points out that while Queensland, along with South Australia, similarly did not fare well in the survey, people are leaving other States to go to Queensland. On the one hand EPAC is saying that Queensland ranks very lowly in terms of quality of life, but many tens of thousands of Australians are going to make their homes in the State of Queensland. I simply put that forward as one piece of evidence.

I also suggest that people look at the weekend arrangements that Adelaidians look forward to. They do not have to sit in a car for over an hour to visit friends on another side of the city, the beach, or the Adelaide Hills; they are mere minutes away. They certainly do not have to drive for long distances to get to key recreation facilities in the Adelaide parklands.

Adelaide, of course, is a very well-planned city, one of the first totally planned cities in the world in terms of the central business district, nestled between the hills and the sea. It does ensure that residents do not have to spend up to half their day getting to a pleasant destination. In fact, Adelaide can be typified as the `20-minute city'. Access to most facilities is available within 20 minutes, despite the fact that it is the only city in Australia with over a million people that has no freeways. I think that is a very big achievement.

Adelaide, of course, has a far milder climate than some of the other southern cities in Australia. I think that can be quantified in terms of one specific factor: one does not need to own an overcoat in Adelaide. To buy a decent quality overcoat in Canberra costs many hundreds of dollars and that is a particular quality of life factor, a household budget factor, if you like, that EPAC has not quantified in comparing Adelaide, say, with Melbourne or Tasmania, which have far colder climates. Mr Deputy President, I am sure on that particular measure your State of Queensland would look even better, and certainly Western Australia as well. That is a specific factor.

EPAC in its analysis has not given enough weight to the cost of housing. Basically, it has looked at a number of statistical indicators and given each of them equal weighting. For example, when we look at the rate for armed robbery, it is given the same weighting as access to housing. I think that is a somewhat distorted view of quality of life.

Most Australians still aspire to have their own home and this is a very important factor in the quality of life in this country. It is very clear from all the evidence that Adelaide has among the cheapest housing in Australia. For example, a good three-bedroom home 15 minutes from the centre of the city can still be purchased for under $90,000. That certainly would not buy anything of the same quality in Sydney or Melbourne. Adequate shelter is absolutely essential to quality of life.

For those who cannot afford their own home, I am sure that South Australia is the best place in which to live. It has the lowest rents by far and the highest level of public housing per capita anywhere in Australia. In fact, on the latest figures, there are 43.8 public rental dwellings per 1,000 people in South Australia compared with only 13.7 in Victoria and 19.6 in New South Wales. On one particular indicator, not really quantified by EPAC, South Australia has multiples of what is available to people in comparable circumstances in New South Wales and Victoria. For people who do not have high disposable incomes, I believe that Adelaide provides by far and away the best quality of life because it gives them the cheapest housing, either rented or owned, in Australia.

I would also like to put on the record some figures about the South Australian Housing Trust. While South Australia has the fifth largest population of the Australian States, it has the second largest number of public rental dwellings. Only New South Wales has more public rental dwellings than South Australia. In Victoria, which is the State that came out of this EPAC study ranked No. 1 with the highest alleged quality of life, the Housing Commission owns some 59,000 of the total stock of rental dwellings. In South Australia, which has a third of the population of Victoria, the Housing Trust owns 62,000 rental dwellings. As I say, Victoria was the State that EPAC mistakenly ranked as having the highest quality of life in Australia.

I would also like to look at the subject of food. Along with housing, food is absolutely essential to life. For example, in South Australia fruit is cheap and plentiful. If one looks at the prices paid for fruit in other parts of the world, it is a real luxury. The thing that is striking about South Australia is that it is still completely fruit-fly free. It is very hard to say those three words in a row, but it is still completely fruit-fly free. I know of many people who have shifted to work in Adelaide to take professional positions and so forth. They are absolutely amazed. They can sit on their veranda, pick fruit off their tree and find no fruit-flies. In South Australia we take for granted that we can grow our own fruit. We do not have any problems with fruit-fly as distinct from a number of places along the eastern seaboard. That is one of the quality of life indicators which is important to family budgets and to diet, which EPAC did not measure and probably does not even know about, for that matter.

I refer to the subject of travel to work because this is one of the clear indicators where the smaller capital cities are offering quality of life. EPAC really did not look at this subject. Adelaidians generally travel to work for some 20 minutes, maybe 30, unlike their eastern State cousins who often have to travel for over an hour in very slow traffic or in crowded public transport to arrive at work. That is the reality in Adelaide.

As I mentioned earlier, I am proud to say that Adelaide has no freeways-I believe that is a quality of life indicator itself-compared with other capital cities such as Melbourne which is usually in the process of building another freeway each time I visit the city. Having travelled on one particular freeway in Melbourne during peak hour traffic, I felt that the word `freeway' was not quite accurate. Bumper to bumper crawl I think would be more apt. Getting to Melbourne airport is quite an experience compared to getting to Adelaide airport. One is advised to leave the central business district an hour before departure time. In Adelaide one can do it in a fraction of the time living on the other side of the central business district from the airport.

I am pleased that 20 years ago Adelaide explicitly vetoed having freeways. It was one of the far-sighted decisions made 20 years ago. We scrapped the Metropolitan Adelaide Transport Study, which was authored by somebody in the United States who thought we should have freeways in Adelaide. We recognised 20 years ago that cars must not be allowed to dominate the city. To this day, Adelaide remains the only city in Australia with over a million people and no freeways. We have no cloverleaves; we have no flyovers; we have no freeways spoiling river systems in metropolitan areas; and we do not have any urban scars due to freeways. I can certainly point to those in a couple of cities. Yet, despite all of that, it is still a 20-minute city. People can travel to work in 20 minutes and they can travel to recreation centres in 20 minutes-all due to very good urban planning over 100 years.

I would like to focus specifically tonight on the health indicators in this EPAC report in terms of life quality. It looks at a range of indicators, gives them equal points, adds them up and gets an index number. One that it looks at is doctor consultations. It seems to imply that South Australia has the highest measure on this indicator called `doctor consultations'. Presumably that means that South Australia has the most consultations with general practitioners per head of population. I will take it at face value; I presume that is what it means. Some people in the community will say that it is a good thing-I might not be among them-if there is a high number of doctor consultations so that people get access to the health services they need.

Some others would point out that South Australia, which seems to be the highest on this index according to EPAC, has a relatively elderly population. I think one association that people would make is that South Australia has the highest average population age in Australia. They would make that sort of link. I would like to explore this EPAC analysis by referring to the report released, I think, by the Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Brian Howe, titled Medical Services Through Medicare, tabled in this place late in February. That has a very interesting analysis of access to health services. It shows the use of health services and it exposes some of the flaws in this EPAC report. On page 72 of this background paper No. 2 there is a table, No. 4, titled `Average Use of Medical Services per Person by State'. It is very contemporary. It has a summary of all Medicare services-many tens of millions of Medicare services-for 1989-1990.

It is very interesting for members of parliament because it works out per capita services in every Federal electorate in Australia, which is very illuminating. For 1989-90, the Australian average for medical services per person was 8.8. South Australia, despite EPAC saying that it had the highest number, was below the national average. In this particular study by Medicare, which includes every medical service in Australia charged to Medicare, South Australia had 8.37 services per person; it did not come out on top of the index. New South Wales was by far and away the highest, with 9.8 services per person, followed by Queensland with 9.01. So two States in this very thoroughgoing and comprehensive analysis of medical services-New South Wales and Queensland-were well ahead of South Australia, despite the EPAC suggestion that South Australia was the worst.

Again, I am doing this more in sorrow than in anger. But there I think we have exposed very tangibly a clear example put forward by EPAC. It is a fact that South Australia does have the highest average age population. Despite that, and there is a very clear association between the age of the population and use of medical services, South Australia still comes in at number three.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean South Australians live longer because of the high quality of--

—Because of the Labor Government, Senator Collins. Table 5 on page 73 examines the medical services according to age group. This really demonstrates this very clear link between age and the use of medical services. For example, nationally-I have only national figures-adults aged 20 to 59 years used medical services 8.7 times on average; they had 8.7 consultations on average. For people aged 60 years and over, the average was 15.1 consultations per person. So there is quite a clear link between people's ages and the use of medical services. We all know that that is true anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have a State which has clearly the highest average age in the community and, therefore, one would expect it to have the highest use of medical services per head of population. But in fact it comes in with a lower usage of services per head of population than New South Wales and Queensland. So I think, according to this particular indicator, it is very much back to the drawing board for EPAC. I think that it-or the consultants it hired-should go back and look at this analysis, because in just 10 minutes this evening I have been able to prove, and demonstrate very clearly, that one of its indicators is totally and comprehensively wrong.

Having said that, I could go on this evening about the advantages of living in South Australia. For example, I could simply refer to the lack of polluted beaches in South Australia. But I will not take up any more time of the Senate. I will simply conclude my remarks, for fear of starting a stampede south and jeopardising the best quality of life in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to delay the Senate for very long. I notice that Senator Collins is over there devouring his tie. I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate something which could be termed a parochial issue, but it is something which has affected me. In this day and age we talk about the rural recession and the droughts and floods which are affecting rural people. But there has always been one inherent danger facing rural people, and that is the danger of tractor accidents.

SPEECH.PARA: A short while ago I was talking to Senator Brownhill, who told me that in the last week or two three tragic tractor accidents had occurred in northern New South Wales. But I wish to refer briefly to a very tragic tractor accident which occurred last Friday in my own State of Tasmania in the historic village of Oatlands. A very old friend of mine whom I went to school with, Colin Lester, was killed in that accident. This has certainly been a cause of sadness for me, but it has been a great tragedy for that small township.

Oatlands is situated in the centre of Tasmania. It is the centre of a great wool growing area. Naturally, Col Lester was a member of a farming family that had been in that area for quite a few years. Col had always lived on the farm and farmed his property. He was a great community man and he was the current President of the Returned Services League and Citizens Club, which included a bowls club which was almost the hub of social life in Oatlands. He had a long-time association with the parents and friends association of the Oatlands High School and he gave a lot of genuine time to the school. He was a member of the Wool Advisory Council of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association and was a very well-respected and loved person in that small community.

What made his death even more tragic was the fact that his son was going to be married the next day in Launceston. I must say that it was typical of the family and their spirit that that wedding went ahead on Saturday. I must say I think Col would have been proud of that. I am sure that he would also have been there in spirit. I know that his spirit and his memory will remain in that small community of Oatlands for many years to come. He was a great community man and he had great love for his family. He also had a great love for golf-it was one of his great loves in life. His wife, Helen, was a member of the State golf team at one stage. I would like to put on the record my sincere sympathy for his wife, Helen, their family and all of their friends in Oatlands.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Economic Planning Advisory Council: South Australia-Tractor Accidents

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly will not detain the Senate long on the issues that have been canvassed tonight. I thought Senator Maguire's defence, despite his sadness, of his home State was admirable. The only thing I must say I have had difficulty with in his home city of Adelaide is the water supply there. I really do not know how Senator Maguire could defend that.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I was not aware that there had been a further tragic tractor accident in Tasmania. I certainly feel for Senator Calvert and the friend that he has lost from that accident, and for the family. But the reason it struck a chord with me is that I have noted the quite extraordinary run of tractor fatalities in the very recent past. It struck a chord with me because in my time I have driven I think every tractor ever manufactured and known to man. I have certainly operated every Caterpillar bulldozer ever manufactured, from a D9 down to a D4, and I have driven combine harvesters, cotton pickers and every piece of agricultural equipment known to man as well.

I asked my staff the other day, and they are doing it, to find out just for my own interest whether any of those fatalities had occurred on tractors without roll bars. When I was farming we never even thought about things like that, and there were many tractor fatalities in those days. In fact, in my cotton growing days we drove very dangerous tractors indeed. I still remember the Inters, the three-wheeled variety, with just one wheel at the front instead of two. They were constantly rearing up and rolling over backwards on operators.

I simply note my own concern at the recent very sad rash of deaths on tractors. It did cross my mind at the time that, in terms of the rural families involved in all of those tragedies, things are very difficult on the land at the moment. Of course, the very last thing that a rural family needs at the moment on top of very difficult financial circumstances is the tragedy of losing a husband, a brother or a father unnecessarily in a tractor accident. I will be very interested to find out, in relation to what I now find out are four deaths in recent times from tractors, whether any of those tractors were fitted with roll bars, because I know from my own days that they would have saved many a life had they been fitted to the tractors concerned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 19 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the basis of the agreement signed recently in Canberra between Australia's Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) and France's Directions des Recherches Etudes et Techniques (DRET) to exchange Defence science technology and information.
(2) What are the yield cost savings expected in the agreement.
(3) What is Australia's commitment under this agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The basis of the agreement is that DSTO and DRET have agreed, where collaboration is believed to provide mutual benefit and is within the limits of existing security agreements, to exchange information on defence research, including information on test facilities. They will also consider sharing of resources in basic research and possible collaboration in joint research programs having regard to each country's intellectual property rights.

(2) Savings are expected to result from the pooling of resources and the sharing of benefits from joint defence research programs. The magnitude of the savings will depend on the number and scope of any programs undertaken.
(3) The agreement imposes no commitment on Australia other than to participate in a balanced exchange of information on defence research programs and to consider proposals for research collaboration.
